  1. Question 1 of 74
    1. Question

    A DevOps engineer is tasked with implementing baseline security requirements for an existing set of AWS accounts within an organization under AWS Organizations. The accounts will be managed by each department’s account administrators. The objective is to enable AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config in all available AWS Regions for each account.

    Additionally, the engineer needs to ensure that each account administrator cannot modify or delete baseline resources while still retaining the ability to manage their CloudTrail trails and AWS Config rules.
    What is the most operationally efficient way that will meet these requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    An efficient way to bring multiple existing AWS accounts into AWS Control Tower is to extend governance by AWS Control Tower to an entire organizational unit (OU).

    To enable AWS Control Tower governance over an existing OU that was created with AWS Organizations and its accounts, register the OU with your AWS Control Tower landing zone. You can register OUs that contain up to 300 accounts. If an OU contains more than 300 accounts, you cannot register it in AWS Control Tower.

    When you register an OU, its member accounts are enrolled into the AWS Control Tower landing zone. They are governed by the controls that apply to their OU. In the AWS Control Tower console, on the Organizational Units page, select the OU to be registered and click Register OU:

    When an AWS Account is enrolled in AWS Control Tower it enables AWS Config and configures it to record all resources in the account and baselines the account, which includes deploying these stack sets:

    – AWSControlTowerBP-BASELINE-CLOUDTRAIL

    – AWSControlTowerBP-BASELINE-CLOUDWATCH

    – AWSControlTowerBP-BASELINE-CONFIG

    – AWSControlTowerBP-BASELINE-ROLES

    – AWSControlTowerBP-BASELINE-SERVICE-ROLES

    – AWSControlTowerBP-VPC-ACCOUNT-FACTORY-V1

    Once the organization is enrolled in the AWS Control Tower, AWS config and CloudTrail will be automatically enabled as part of the baseline security requirements of the AWS.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Use AWS Control Tower. Enroll the existing organization in AWS Control Tower. Create an SCP that will deny updates and delete specific AWS Config and CloudTrail resources from all principals that are not an administrator of the organization’s management account.

    The option that says: Create an organization trail from the organization management account. Deploy AWS Config from management account using AWS CloudFormation StackSets. Grant each account administrator access to AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config is incorrect. Even though this can satisfy the requirement of enabling AWS Config and AWS CloudTrail in all accounts at all available regions, it did not give a clear solution to preventing each department account administrator from deleting and modifying the baseline AWS Config and AWS CloudTrail resources.

    The option that says: Use AWS Service Catalog to create a portfolio with the necessary products that match the workloads. Integrate Service Catalog with AWS Organizations by enabling trusted access. Grant each account administrator access to AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config is incorrect. AWS Service Catalog is primarily used in letting you centrally manage your cloud resources to achieve governance at the scale of your infrastructure as code (IaC) templates written in CloudFormation or Terraform. Although AWS Service Catalog can be integrated with AWS Organizations, using this service alone will not fulfill the necessary security features.

    The option that says:  Create an organization trail from the management account. Deploy AWS Config. Set up an SCP that will deny updates and delete specific AWS Config and CloudTrail resources from all principals that are not an administrator of the organization’s management account is incorrect. Although this is a possible solution and satisfies all the requirements, the AWS Control Tower solution is more operationally efficient. It provides a more centralized approach and automation and can enforce consistent security configurations and policies across all enrolled accounts.

     

    References:

    https://catalog.us-east-1.prod.workshops.aws/workshops/13304db2-f715-48bf-ada0-92e5c4eea945/en-US/90-control-tower/20-setup-control-tower

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/controltower/latest/userguide/importing-existing.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/controltower/latest/userguide/enroll-account.html

     

    Check out this AWS Control Tower Cheat Sheet:

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-control-tower/

  2. Question 2 of 74
    2. Question

    A global company has established an AWS Control Tower landing zone to enforce governance and best practices across multiple AWS accounts. One of the key requirements is to demonstrate compliance with the National Institute of Standards and Technology’s Special Publications (NIST SP 800-53 Rev. 5) as well as to the Center for Internet Security (CIS) Benchmarks for AWS Foundations security standards.

    Both the Audit and Security teams of the company utilize the AWS Security Hub to monitor and view compliance across all accounts within the organization. They should be the only ones allowed to access the aggregated Security Hub findings. Additionally, individual users should be able to view findings specific to their accounts. Furthermore, all accounts created within the organization should be enrolled automatically in Security Hub for compliance monitoring.

    What are the steps that will meet these requirements the MOST operationally efficient? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    The AWS Control Tower management account designates the Security Hub administrator account in each Region. The Security Hub administrator account then enables organization accounts as member accounts.

    Once a security hub administrator is designated, it can manage Security Hub membership for an organization. It is granted permission to view the findings that are associated with its member accounts. It automatically has access to all of the accounts in the organization and determines which organization accounts to enable as member accounts.

    The AWS Control Tower management account can use the Security Hub console to designate the Security Hub administrator account.

    AWS recommends that you do not designate the AWS Control Tower management account itself as the Security Hub administrator account. This is because the users who have access to the management account to manage billing are likely to be different from the users who need access to Security Hub for security management.

    Enable the NIST Special Publication standard from Security Hub Console.

    In this scenario, you should designate a Security Hub administrator account first, different from the AWS Control Tower management account. Once the Security Hub administrator account is configured, you should turn on automatic account enablement. This will allow the administrator account to enable and manage the security hub for every provisioning of a new account.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – In the AWS Control Tower Management account, delegate the Audit account as the Security Hub administrator. Then sign in to the Audit account and enable NIST Special Publication and CIS Benchmarks standards from the Security Hub console.

    – Configure permission set in AWS IAM Identity Center with the appropriate permissions using ProvisionPermissionSet API. Assign the permission set to the Audit account via the CreateAccountAssignment API operation and then assign the security team’s group to Audit account with the respective permission set.

    – In the Audit account’s Security Hub, turn on auto-enable accounts.

    The option that says: In the AWS Control Tower management account, enable NIST Special Publication and CIS Benchmarks standards from the Security Hub console is incorrect. While this will allow the NIST Special Publication and CIS Benchmark standards to all member accounts’ Security Hub, it is not considered a best practice to set the AWS Control Tower management account as the Security Hub administrator account due to security issues. Since there is no particular requirement to do this setup, it would be better to delegate another AWS account as a Security Hub administrator account.

    The option that says: Configure permission set in AWS IAM Identity Center with the appropriate permissions. Assign the security team’s group with the respective permission set. Create an SCP that will deny access to the Security Hub for any user that is not part of the security team is incorrect. Creating this SCP policy would also deny all individual users to manage their own Security Hub findings in their respective accounts, which will not satisfy the requirements.

    The option that says: Configure Account Factory Customizations (AFC) during Account Factory account vending. Use a Service Catalog product that will deploy a CloudFormation template for enabling Security Hub to the newly created account is incorrect. Although this will enable the Security Hub to newly provisioned accounts, this adds complexity and operational overhead. You can turn on auto-enable in the Security Hub administrator account to automatically enable the Security Hub for every newly provisioned account.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/designate-orgs-admin-account.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/accounts-transition-to-orgs.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/securityhub/latest/userguide/securityhub-accounts.html

     

    Check out this AWS Security Hub:

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-security-hub/

  3. Question 3 of 74
    3. Question

    You are using a cluster of Amazon Linux EC2 instances to host an online forum. AWS CodeDeploy is used for deploying the new version of the application. The AppSpec file has been modified to use custom, non-default settings to fit your application deployment needs. You configured a deployment script during the lifecycle event to download the application code and install a few packages needed for operation. This deployment script completes in about 1 to 2 minutes. During deployment, CodeDeploy reports that the deployment has failed but upon checking the generated logs, the deployment script has successfully finished.

    Which of the following could be the possible cause of the failed deployment?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    For deployments to Amazon Linux, Ubuntu Server, and RHEL instances, if you have a deployment script that starts a long-running process, CodeDeploy might spend a long time waiting in the deployment lifecycle event and then fail the deployment. This is because if the process runs longer than the foreground and background processes in that event, CodeDeploy stops and fails the deployment, even if the process is still running as expected.

    You can enable CodeDeploy to continue after the process (or script) starts running by redirecting Standard Output and Standard Input to /dev/null. Alternatively, you can also use /dev/null as Standard Input.
    In CodeDeploy, you can configure a timeout as part of your deployment lifecycle event hook. The timeout value is a specific amount of time for the script to complete its execution before the deployment is considered failed. The default value is 3600 seconds (1 hour). If the script exceeds this limit, the deployment stops, and the deployment to the instance fails.
    The scenario mentioned that the AppSpec file had been modified to use custom, non-default settings. This means that the default timeout value has been changed and possibly set to a shorter time span ( e.g., 1 minute ). Therefore, this could cause an issue in this scenario in which CodeDeploy reports that the deployment has failed even though it has successfully finished.
    Hence, the correct answer is: CodeDeploy has reached timeout while waiting for the long-running script to finish.

    The option that says: CodeDeploy has reached timeout because of misconfigured health check on ALB is incorrect. Misconfigured health check on an ALB would likely cause issues with the availability of the application rather than issues with the deployment itself. In this scenario, the issue is specifically related to the deployment process, as reported by CodeDeploy.

    The option that says: The deployment script is missing package dependencies and is unable to run is incorrect. If the script were missing package dependencies, it would not have been successfully completed as described in the scenario.

    The option that says: The deployment script returns a zero value signaling CodeDeploy that it failed is incorrect as a return value of zero means the script finished successfully.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/troubleshooting-deployments.html#troubleshooting-long-running-processes

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/instances.html

     

    Check out this AWS CodeDeploy Cheat Sheet:

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-codedeploy/

  4. Question 4 of 74
    4. Question

    A software development company is using AWS Organizations to manage their AWS resources. They have a single Organizational Unit (OU) that contains multiple AWS accounts, each running several Amazon EC2 instances for various development and testing environments.

    The company wants to ensure that the credentials of each EC2 instance are used exclusively by the instance they are assigned to, preventing any potential misuse or unauthorized access. A DevOps engineer is tasked with implementing a solution to meet these security requirements.

    Which of the following options should the DevOps engineer should implement?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Organizations is a cloud service that allows you to centrally manage and enforce policies for multiple AWS accounts. With AWS Organizations, you can create Service Control Policies (SCPs) that centrally control AWS service use across multiple AWS accounts. SCPs offer central control over the maximum available permissions for all accounts in your organization, allowing you to ensure your accounts stay within your organization’s access control guidelines.

    Attaching an SCP in the organization and applying all the aws:VpcSourcelp, aws:EC2InstanceSourcePrivateIPv4, aws:EC2InstanceSourceVPC, and aws:SourceVpc condition keys in the SCP, the company can restrict access based on the source IP of the VPC, the private IPv4 address of the EC2 instance, the source VPC of the EC2 instance, and the source VPC. This ensures that the credentials of each EC2 instance are used exclusively by the instance they are assigned to, preventing any potential misuse or unauthorized access.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Attach an SCP that evaluates if the aws:EC2InstanceSourceVPC and aws:SourceVpc condition keys hold identical values. If they don’t, prohibit access. Then, within this policy evaluation, assess if the aws:EC2InstanceSourcePrivateIPv4 and aws:VpcSourceIp condition keys hold identical values. If they don’t, prohibit access. Enforce this policy at the OU.

    The option that says: Implement an SCP that contains a collection of permissible VPC values and verifies if the aws:SourceVpc condition key’s value is present in this collection. Then, within this policy evaluation, establish a collection of allowable IP address values and verify if the aws:VpcSourceIp condition key’s value is included in this collection. If either condition is not met, access is denied. Implement this SCP across all accounts within the organization is incorrect because it focuses on verifying if certain values are present in a collection of permissible values. This approach does not directly tie the credentials to the specific EC2 instance they are assigned to, which is the main requirement.

    The option that says: Implement an SCP that verifies whether the aws:EC2InstanceSourceVPC and aws:VpcSourceIp condition keys match. If they don’t match, block access. Then, within this policy evaluation, verify whether the aws:EC2InstanceSourcePrivateIPv4 and aws:SourceVpc condition keys correspond. If either condition is not met, access is denied. Enforce this policy for all accounts within the organization is incorrect because it proposes matching condition keys that do not necessarily ensure exclusive use of credentials by the assigned EC2 instance. The aws:EC2InstanceSourcePrivateIPv4 and aws:SourceVpc condition keys do not provide a strong binding between the instance and its credentials.

    The option that says: Attach the SCP in the organization and apply both the aws:EC2InstanceSourceVPC and aws:SourceVpc condition keys in the SCP to restrict access based on the source VPC of the EC2 instance and the source VPC is incorrect because it only restricts access based on the source VPC of the EC2 instance and the source VPC. This does not ensure that the credentials are used exclusively by the instance they are assigned to. It lacks the additional check for the aws:EC2InstanceSourcePrivateIPv4 and aws:VpcSourceIp condition keys, which are crucial for ensuring exclusive use of credentials.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/organizations/latest/userguide/orgs_manage_policies_scps.html

    https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/how-to-use-policies-to-restrict-where-ec2-instance-credentials-can-be-used-from/

     

    Service Control Policies (SCP) vs IAM Policies:

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/service-control-policies-scp-vs-iam-policies/

  5. Question 5 of 74
    5. Question

    A multinational company manages a diverse portfolio of applications using AWS Control Tower to oversee multiple AWS accounts. Each application team is assigned a dedicated AWS account within the organization’s consolidated AWS Organizations setup. Additionally, a specific member account within AWS Control Tower acts as a centralized DevOps hub, providing CI/CD pipelines for application deployment across various target AWS accounts. The centralized DevOps account contains an IAM role designed for deployment purposes.

    The application team is currently deploying their application onto an Amazon Elastic Container Service (ECS) cluster residing in their assigned application AWS account. The application AWS account has its own IAM role for deployment. The deployment workflow is through an AWS CodeBuild project configured within the centralized DevOps account, utilizing an IAM service role dedicated to CodeBuild. However, the deployment encounters repeated failures due to an unauthorized error when attempting to establish connections from CodeBuild to the cross-account ECS cluster.

    Which solution should be implemented to resolve this error?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    You can use the AWS Security Token Service (AWS STS) to create and provide trusted users with temporary security credentials that can control access to your AWS resources. One of the common use cases is roles for cross-account access.

    You can use IAM roles to delegate access to your AWS resources. With IAM roles, you can establish trust relationships between your trusted account and other AWS trusted accounts. The trusting account owns the resource to be accessed, in this case, the application account and the trusted account contains the users who need access to the resource.

    You can assume a role from the application account IAM role to the centralized DevOps account IAM role, instead of using user to role with role chaining.

    Implement this in the scenario’s setup with the following steps:

    – You must create a trust relationship with the DevOps Account from the application account by adding the arn:aws:iam::{DevOps Account}:root to the principal of the trust policy.

    – Make sure to add the necessary ECS cluster permissions to the application account deployment role.

    – In the DevOps account, allow sts:AssumRole action in the deployment role and add the application account role at the resources.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Create a trust relationship between the deployment IAM role in the application account and the centralized DevOps account. Configure the trust relationship to allow the sts:AssumeRole action. Adjust the permissions of the deployment IAM role in the application account to ensure it has the necessary access to the ECS Clusters.

    The option that says: Create a trust relationship between the deployment IAM role in the application account and the centralized DevOps account. Configure the trust relationship to allow the sts:AssumeRole action. Adjust the permissions of the deployment IAM role in the centralized DevOps account to ensure it has the necessary access to the ECS Clusters is incorrect because the ECS permissions should be present on the application account deployment role not at the centralized DevOps account deployment role. The ECS resources are at the application account which is why ECS permission should exist on the application account’s deployment role.

    The option that says: Create a trust relationship between the deployment IAM role in the application account and the AWS Control Tower management account. Configure the trust relationship to allow the sts:AssumeRole action. Adjust the permissions of the deployment IAM role in the application account to ensure it has the necessary access to the ECS Clusters through the aws-auth ConfigMap AWS IAM Authenticator is incorrect. Since the CodeBuild project that needs to access ECS is at the centralized DevOps account, the trust relationship must be built with the centralized DevOps account. There are some cases in which you would need to build a trust relationship with the AWS Control Tower management account, but this cross-account access scenario for ECS cluster is not included in that case. Moreover, the aws-auth ConfigMap AWS IAM Authenticator is only applicable for Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) and not for Amazon ECS.

    The option that says:  Create a trust relationship between the deployment IAM role in the application account and the centralized DevOps account. Configure the trust relationship to allow the iam:Passrole action. Enable the IAM principal access to the Amazon ECS cluster via the aws-auth ConfigMap AWS IAM Authenticator is incorrect because allowing iam:PassRole will NOT build a trust relationship between the accounts. The iam:PassRole is commonly used for allowing a user to attach an IAM role to another AWS Service. This is NOT a requirement for this scenario. In addition, the aws-auth ConfigMap AWS IAM Authenticator is applicable for Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) only, so this solution won’t really work.

  6. Question 6 of 74
    6. Question

    A platform engineering org is tasked with deploying instances of their company’s in-house observability system to each of the company’s business units’ AWS accounts. To do this, the team is leveraging AWS Organizations and AWS CloudFormation StackSets. However, stack operations are failing, and stacks show an OUTDATED status.

    What are some possible steps to keep this from happening? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS CloudFormation is a service that helps model and set up AWS resources, enabling less time to be spent managing those resources and more time focusing on application and business logic.

    Using CloudFormation involves working with templates and stacks. Templates are JSON or YAML documents that describe a collection of AWS resources that work as a single unit. A template acts as a blueprint for instantiating resources into a stack.

    AWS CloudFormation StackSets extends the capability of stacks by enabling the creation, update, or deletion of stacks across multiple accounts and AWS Regions with a single operation. Using an administrator (or management) account, define and manage an AWS CloudFormation template, and use the template as the basis for provisioning stacks into selected target accounts across specified AWS Regions.

    In relation to the scenario, the following are several common causes for stack operation failure:

    – Insufficient permissions in a target account for creating resources that are specified in your template.

    – The AWS CloudFormation template might have errors. Validate the template in AWS CloudFormation and fix errors before trying to create your stack set.

    – The template could be trying to create global resources that must be unique but aren’t, such as S3 buckets.

    – A specified target account number doesn’t exist. Check the target account numbers that you specified on the Set deployment options page of the wizard.

    – The administrator account does not have a trust relationship with the target account.

    – The maximum number of a resource that is specified in your template already exists in your target account. For example, you might have reached the limit of allowed IAM roles in a target account, but the template creates more IAM roles.

    – You have reached the maximum number of stacks that are allowed in a stack set. See AWS CloudFormation limits for the maximum number of stacks per stack set.

    Therefore, the correct set of options are:

    – Ensure that the number of existing resources in target account is within the maximum indicated for that resource in the template.
     – Ensure any global namespaced target resources are unique.
    – Ensure a trust relationship between the delegated administrator account and the target account.

    The option that says: Ensure deployment is done using the management account and not an administrator account is incorrect. An administrator account is equally useful here and actually, the preferred method here so as to keep management concerns (eg. billing and payments) and administrative concerns separate.

    The option that says: Ensure that the stack sets and the target resources belong to the same region is incorrect. A stack set and resources for target accounts may belong to different regions.

    The option that says: Ensure resources are not termination protected is incorrect. Termination protection does not cause failure in stack creation but only in stack deletion.

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/organizations/latest/userguide/orgs_introduction.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/Welcome.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/stacksets-troubleshooting.html

  7. Question 7 of 74
    7. Question

    A company has API servers hosted on a cluster of EC2 instances deployed using Elastic Beanstalk. The development team must deploy a new version and change the instance type to a larger one. Since this is a production workload already operating at 80% capacity, it is crucial to maintain the current capacity during the deployment to avoid any performance degradation or downtime.

    Which deployment policy would meet the requirements with the least amount of cost?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    When a configuration change requires replacing instances, Elastic Beanstalk can perform the update in batches to avoid downtime while the change is propagated. During a rolling update, capacity is only reduced by the size of a single batch, which you can configure. With rolling deployments, Elastic Beanstalk splits the environment’s EC2 instances into batches and deploys the new version of the application to one batch at a time, leaving the rest of the instances in the environment running the old version of the application. During a rolling deployment, some instances serve requests with the old version of the application, while instances in completed batches serve other requests with the new version.

    To maintain full capacity during deployments, you can configure your environment to launch a new batch of instances before taking any instances out of service. This option is known as a rolling deployment with an additional batch. When the deployment completes, Elastic Beanstalk terminates the additional batch of instances.

    Refer to the table below for the characteristics of each deployment method as well as the amount of time it takes to do the deployment, as seen in the Deploy Time column:

    Hence, the correct answer in this scenario is: Use Rolling with additional batch as deployment policy to maintain the capacity of the cluster during the deployment. 

    The option that says: Use Rolling as the deployment policy to maintain the capacity of the cluster during the deployment is incorrect because this type will remove a batch of instances from the cluster while deploying the new instances. Hence, this will increase the load to the current EC2 instances. A better solution to implement in this scenario is to use Rolling with additional batch.

    The option that says: Use All at once as deployment policy to deploy the new version with complete capacity is incorrect because this type will cause a brief downtime during deployment. Hence, this is not ideal for critical production applications.

    The option that says: Use Immutable as deployment policy to deploy the new version with complete capacity is incorrect. Although this type can maintain the compute capacity of the cluster, it entails a significant amount of cost since a new batch of instances will be launched.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticbeanstalk/latest/dg/using-features.rolling-version-deploy.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticbeanstalk/latest/dg/using-features.rollingupdates.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/elasticbeanstalk/latest/dg/environmentmgmt-updates-immutable.html

  8. Question 8 of 74
    8. Question

    You are working as a DevOps Engineer for a leading pharmaceutical company. After the recent annual IT audit, several Amazon EC2 instances were discovered running an outdated operating system, and there were many security vulnerabilities left unpatched. To safeguard your systems from various cybersecurity attacks, mitigating these vulnerabilities as soon as possible is crucial. You are also required to record all of the changes to patch and association compliance statuses.

    Which among the following options is the MOST efficient way to solve this issue?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager automates the process of patching managed instances with security-related updates. For Linux-based instances, you can also install patches for non-security updates. You can patch fleets of Amazon EC2 instances or your on-premises servers and virtual machines (VMs) by operating system type. This includes supported versions of Windows, Ubuntu Server, Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL), SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES), Amazon Linux, and Amazon Linux 2. You can scan instances to see only a report of missing patches, or you can scan and automatically install all missing patches.

    Patch Manager uses patch baselines, which include rules for auto-approving patches within days of their release, as well as a list of approved and rejected patches. You can install patches on a regular basis by scheduling patching to run as a Systems Manager maintenance window task. You can also install patches individually or to large groups of instances by using Amazon EC2 tags. (Tags are keys that help identify and sort your resources within your organization.) You can add tags to your patch baselines themselves when you create or update them.

    Since you are also required to record all of the changes to patch and association compliance statuses, you can use AWS Config to meet this requirement. AWS Config is a service that enables you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. Config continuously monitors and records your AWS resource configurations and allows you to automate the evaluation of recorded configurations against desired configurations.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Manage, record, and deploy the OS security patches of the Amazon EC2 instances using a combination of AWS Systems Manager and AWS Config.

    The option that says: Configure each of the Amazon EC2 instances to automatically install the required security patches for its operating system every week on the provided maintenance window is incorrect because Amazon EC2 does not have a built-in function to automatically install the security OS patch on a regular basis. You should use AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager instead.

    The option that says: Set up Kibana and Amazon QuickSight to apply, monitor, and visualize the patch statuses of all Amazon EC2 instances in the VPC is incorrect because QuickSight and Kibana are primarily used for data visualization and not for patch management. You can use Amazon OpenSearch with Kibana but this service is not suitable for this scenario.

    The option that says: Manage, record, and deploy the security patches for the OS for the Amazon EC2 instances using AWS Systems Manager and Amazon OpenSearch Service is incorrect. While AWS Systems Manager is designed to help with management tasks such as patching, Amazon OpenSearch Service is more focused on search and analytics. Therefore, using Amazon OpenSearch Service for patch management would not be an efficient or effective solution. The most efficient way to solve the issue described in the question would be to use a combination of AWS Systems Manager and AWS Config.

  9. Question 9 of 74
    9. Question

    A company operates a web application, leveraging an Amazon CloudFront distribution with an ALB (Application Load Balancer) as its primary origin within an AWS Region. The application has been architected with a zero-second Recovery Time Objective (RTO). In response to recent service disruptions, the application has been set up in a warm standby mode across a secondary AWS Region.

    A DevOps engineer needs to automate failover and redirect HTTP safe methods (GET, HEAD, OPTIONS) to ensure quick response during regional outages.

    Which solution would be suitable to meet these requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    A CloudFront distribution is a configuration that controls and manages the delivery of content from multiple origins to end users with low latency and high data transfer speeds.

    An origin is the location where the content is stored that CloudFront delivers to end users. It can be an S3 bucket, EC2 instance, load balancer, etc.

    You can specify multiple origins, like primary and secondary origins, for high availability.

    The principal origin is the main origin that CloudFront routes requests to by default. It is considered the primary source of content.

    A secondary origin is an additional origin that can be used as a backup or failover option in case the primary origin becomes unavailable.

    Origin group – A configuration that contains two origins (primary and secondary) along with failover criteria. This allows CloudFront to automatically failover requests from the primary origin to the secondary origin when the failover conditions are met.

    Common use cases for multiple origins include disaster recovery, distributing load, or routing users to geographically closer origins for lower latency.

    The application needs to be configured to use the origin group so it can take advantage of the failover functionality provided by CloudFront.

    Application Load Balancer (ALB) – A load balancer that operates at the application layer (layer 7) of the OSI model and distributes traffic across multiple targets like EC2 instances. It supports HTTP and HTTPS and can handle millions of requests per minute.

    Zero-second RTO – A recovery time objective of zero seconds which means the system must recover immediately from any disruption or outage with no downtime experienced by the users.

    CloudFront is designed to fail over to the secondary origin when the HTTP method of the viewer request is a safe method such as GET, HEAD, or OPTIONS. By creating an origin group with the primary ALB and secondary ALB, CloudFront can automatically failover to the secondary origin if issues occur with the primary. Origins groups in CloudFront allow specifying failover conditions, such as HTTP 5xx status codes, that trigger CloudFront to switch origins. This ensures the application requests are promptly redirected during outages in the primary region by leveraging the warm standby in the secondary region. The application simply needs to be configured to use the origin group, so it can take advantage of the failover functionality without requiring code changes each time a failover occurs. This meets all the requirements outlined to ensure high availability, zero RTO, and automated failover of the application between regions.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Add a new origin group in CloudFront for the secondary Application Load Balancer and set the primary Application Load Balancer as the default origin. Adjust group configuration to initiate failover upon receiving HTTP 5xx status codes and modify the application to use the origin group.

    The option that says: Add a new CloudFront distribution with secondary region ALB as primary origin. Configure Route 53 alias records with failover policy, evaluate Target Health for both distributions, and update the app to use the new distribution setup is incorrect because it introduces unnecessary complexity and cost by adding a new CloudFront distribution. The failover mechanism can be managed more efficiently within a single distribution using origin groups.

    The option that says: Configure Amazon Route 53 alias records with Evaluate Target Health enabled and failover policy for both ALBs. Configure the CloudFront distribution to use the new DNS settings, setting TTL to zero is incorrect as it relies solely on DNS changes for failover, which may not be as rapid or seamless as handling failover within CloudFront using origin groups. DNS changes also have the potential for caching issues that could delay the failover process.

    The option that says: Implement Amazon Route 53 health checks on the primary ALB, configure DNS failover to the secondary ALB in another region, and update the CloudFront distribution for traffic routing based on Route 53 health checks is incorrect because, while it provides a method for failover, it doesn’t utilize the built-in capabilities of CloudFront for managing origins and can result in longer failover times. The simplicity and efficiency of origin groups make them a more suitable choice for this scenario.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudFront/latest/DeveloperGuide/high_availability_origin_failover.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonCloudFront/latest/DeveloperGuide/Introduction.html

     

    Check out the following Cheat Sheets:

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-well-architected-framework-disaster-recovery/

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/application-load-balancer-vs-network-load-balancer-vs-gateway-load-balancer/

  10. Question 10 of 74
    10. Question

    You are developing a marketplace app for emoji stickers hosted in Docker containers deployed on Amazon ECS. For each deployment, you need to verify that the set of core APIs are working before continuing to allow production traffic to flow on the new app version. If the API tests are unsuccessful, the deployment will automatically rollback to the older version. Your validation scripts are a set of functions on AWS Lambda which should run for each deployment.

    How can you implement this verification effectively?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    You can use a Lambda function to validate part of the deployment of an updated Amazon ECS application. To add a validation test, you first implement the test in a Lambda function. Next, in your deployment AppSpec file, you specify the Lambda function for the lifecycle hook you want to test. If a validation test fails, the deployment stops, is rolled back, and marked failed. If the test succeeds, the deployment continues to the next deployment lifecycle event or hook. During an Amazon ECS deployment with validation tests, CodeDeploy uses a load balancer that is configured with two target groups: one production traffic listener and one test traffic listener.

    The content in the ‘hooks’ section of the AppSpec file varies, depending on the compute platform for your deployment. The ‘hooks’ section for an EC2/On-Premises deployment contains mappings that link deployment lifecycle event hooks to one or more scripts. The ‘hooks’ section for a Lambda or an Amazon ECS deployment specifies Lambda validation functions to run during a deployment lifecycle event. If an event hook is not present, no operation is executed for that event.

    When the deployment starts, the deployment lifecycle events start to execute one at a time. Some lifecycle events are hooks that only execute Lambda functions specified in the AppSpec file. An AWS Lambda hook is one Lambda function specified with a string on a new line after the name of the lifecycle event. On the AfterAllowTestTraffic hook, you can specify Lambda functions that can validate the deployment using the test traffic.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Define your Lambda functions in the AfterAllowTestTraffic lifecycle hook of the AppSpec.yaml file. Configure the Lambda functions to validate the deployment using the test traffic and rollback if the tests fail.

    The option that says: Define your Lambda functions in the AfterInstall lifecycle hook of the AppSpec.yaml file. Configure the Lambda functions to validate the deployment after installing the new version and rollback if the tests fail is incorrect because in the AfterInstall lifecycle hook, the new task version is not yet attached to the test listener and application load balancer so no traffic is flowing yet on this cluster.

    The option that says: Define your Lambda functions in the BeforeAllowTraffic lifecycle hook of the AppSpec.yaml file. Configure the Lambda functions to validate the deployment before allowing production traffic and rollback if the tests fail is incorrect because, in the BeforeAllowTraffic lifecycle hook, validation has succeeded and you can use this hook to perform additional actions before allowing production traffic to flow to the new task version.

    The option that says: Define your Lambda functions in the AfterAllowTraffic lifecycle hook of the AppSpec.yaml file. Configure the Lambda functions to validate the deployment using production traffic and rollback if the tests fail is incorrect because in the AfterAllowTraffic lifecycle hook, production traffic is rerouted from the old task set to the new task set. You want to verify the application “before” opening it to production traffic, and not “after”.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/tutorial-ecs-deployment-with-hooks.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/reference-appspec-file-structure-hooks.html#appspec-hooks-ecs

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/deployment-steps.html#deployment-steps-what-happens

    11. Question

    A company with a PaaS offering built on AWS implements tenant isolation by leveraging AWS Organizations and creating member accounts. A solution is required to provide compliance guard rails across accounts for IAM entity configurations.

    Which combination of options will achieve this? (Select TWO.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Organizations is a management service that enables centralized governance and management of multiple AWS accounts. It allows organizations to create a hierarchical structure of member accounts, facilitating resource sharing, cost management, and security controls across the accounts. For workload isolation, AWS Organizations can be used to segregate tenants into separate AWS accounts, ensuring the isolation of resources and data while enabling centralized management and governance.

    AWS Config is a service that continuously monitors and records configurations of AWS resources, providing visibility into resource changes and compliance status. Using aggregators, AWS Config can be leveraged with AWS Organizations to monitor compliance using Config rules across all member accounts within the organization. By centrally managing Config rules at the organization level, administrators can define and enforce standards, such as security best practices or regulatory requirements, across multiple AWS accounts.

    Therefore, the correct set of options are:

    – Implement AWS Config rules to align IAM entities across all member accounts with corporate IAM policies.
     – Set up an AWS Config aggregator with member accounts set as sources.

    The option that says: Enable AWS Security Hub in the organization’s main account. Set up Security Hub to detect any breaches of corporate IAM policies is incorrect. Without setting up AWS Config rules and aggregators, AWS Security Hub will collect general security data. It may flag IAM-related non-compliance but only with respect to best practices and security standards and nothing specific to your organization’s security policies.

    The option that says: Create a CloudFormation template. Leverage CloudFormation StackSets to create the necessary IAM entities in the member accounts is incorrect. CloudFormation templates can be used to scaffold appropriate IAM identities for multiple accounts but they do not help in identifying deviance from corporate IAM policies.

    The option that says: Implement appropriate AWS Control Tower preventive controls to detect non-compliance is incorrect. AWS Control Tower preventive controls use AWS Organizations service control policies and, as its name suggests, only prevent or limit what IAM entities can perform in your organization. They do not help in scenarios when those limits have been broken.

  12. Question 12 of 74
    12. Question

    An e-commerce company must cater to the rising demand for AWS development environments. Currently, these environments are manually created in the AWS Management Console in the same us-east-1 region and account.

    This leads to time-consuming processes and potential errors. The networking team utilizes AWS CloudFormation for networking infrastructure management and exports stack output values for Amazon VPC and subnets. Development environments adhere to common standards, including Amazon RDS, Application Load Balancers, and Amazon EC2 Scaling groups.
    Due to expected growth, the DevOps engineer must automate the creation of the development environments to keep up with the demand and can easily update the existing resources. The engineer will utilize CloudFormation to create development environments.

    Which solution can satisfy these requirements with the LEAST management overhead?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Nested stacks are stacks created as part of other stacks. You create a nested stack within another stack by using the AWS::CloudFormation::Stack resource.

    As your infrastructure grows, common patterns can emerge in which you declare the same components in multiple templates. You can separate out these common components and create dedicated templates for them. Then use the resource in your template to reference other templates, creating nested stacks.

    To share information between stacks, export a stack’s output values. Other stacks that are in the same AWS account and region can import the exported values.

    To export a stack’s output value, use the Export field in the Output section of the stack’s template. To import those values, use the Fn::ImportValue function in the template for the other stacks.

    When you need to update a stack, understanding how your changes will affect running resources before you implement them can help you update stacks with confidence. Change sets allow you to preview how proposed changes to a stack might impact your running resources, for example, whether your changes will delete or replace any critical resources, AWS CloudFormation makes the changes to your stack only when you decide to execute the change set, allowing you to decide whether to proceed with your proposed changes or explore other changes by creating another change set.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Create nested stacks to define common infrastructure components. Utilize Fn::ImportValue intrinsic functions to retrieve VPC and subnet values within the nested stacks. For updating existing development environments, invoke the CreateChangeSet and ExecuteChangeSet commands.

    The option that says: Create StackSets to define common infrastructure components. Utilize the AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store to retrieve VPC and subnet values within the nested stacks. For updating existing development environments, use the UpdateStackSet and ExecuteChangeSet commands is incorrect. While this is a possible solution, implementing this will require the networking team to change their implementation from exporting values to storing values in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store. This additional configuration for the Systems Manager Parameter Store entails management overhead. Additionally, AWS CloudFormation StackSets are meant for deploying your application to multiple AWS accounts or AWS Regions with a single operation. The scenario explicitly said that the company only uses a single AWS account and one AWS region; thus, using StackSets is not required.

    The option that says: Create nested stacks to define common infrastructure components. UtilizeFn::ImportValue intrinsic functions to retrieve VPC and subnet values within the nested stacks. For updating existing development environments, run the update-stack operation via the AWS CLI is incorrect. Even though using Fn::ImportValue will allow the template to fetch exported VPC and subnet values from other templates, using the CreateChangeSet and ExecuteChangeSet commands is still a better and safer approach for updating the existing resource. This is because it allows the DevOps engineer to understand how the changes will affect the running resources before implementing them.

    The option that says: Create nested stacks to define common infrastructure components. Utilize custom resources to execute the DescribeStacks API operation from Lambda to get the VPC and subnet values. For updating existing development environments, leverage CreateChangeSet and ExecuteChangeSet commands is incorrect. Same with the previous option, you have to take advantage of the existing implementation to lessen the management overhead. The networking team is already exporting the values the engineer needed in the template. Although executing the DescribeStacks API operation will fetch the exported output values, it will only add complexity to the solution as the engineer would need to include custom resources in the template.

    13. Question

    A DevOps engineer is responsible for updating golden image AMIs used in its ECS clusters through AWS CloudFormation. A solution is required to ensure a streamlined process that includes version control of the AMI build spec and stack source/s and facilitates peer review for stakeholders. The solution must also keep the building of the AMI from its configuration into the ECS clusters decoupled.

    Which set of steps will meet these requirements? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Github ensures version control and facilitates peer review for both the AMI build spec and the CloudFormation stack source code.

    Complementing AWS CodeBuild is a cloud-based build service, which eliminates the need for self-managed build servers. It provides prepackaged build environments for various languages and tools.

    AWS CodePipeline ties together these services (along with CodeDeploy, though not used in this scenario).CodePipeline automates software release steps, allowing users to model and automate deployment stages. It can also integrate with existing solutions like Jenkins. However, built-in integrations between these cloud-native services make it easier to develop solutions for your software development lifecycle when starting from scratch.

    In this scenario, 2 independent CodePipeline pipelines are triggered by 2 independent (by design) events:
    1. a change in the build spec of the AMI
    2. a change in the CloudFormation stack source
    The output of the first one being the golden image AMI and that of the second one being the CloudFormation stacks with the updated golden image.

    Therefore, the correct options are:

    – Set up a GitHub repository each for the AMI build spec and for the CloudFormation stack source code.
    – Establish an AWS CodePipeline pipeline with the AMI build spec repository as its source. In this pipeline, set up an AWS CodeBuild action that builds the golden image.
    – Configure an AWS CodePipeline pipeline with the CloudFormation stack repository as its source. Set up a CloudFormation action to apply.

    The option that says: Set up a GitHub repository to host the build spec and stack source code. Establish an AWS CodePipeline pipeline with the GitHub repository as its source is incorrect. Joining the build spec and stack source code entangles pipelines as making any change in the AMI build steps would inadvertently trigger whatever pipeline has the stack source repo as the source.

    The option that says: Set up a CloudFormation action that deploys/updates the stack with an updated version of the golden image. In the same pipeline, set the image version as an output variable from the CodeBuild action that builds the image is incorrect. This explicitly states that the upstream CodeBuild action building the image is executed in the same pipeline as the CloudFormation action, which is against the requirement specified by the scenario. If, however, the CloudFormation action is configured in a separate pipeline, it cannot access the version variable as it is only pipeline-scoped.

    The option that says: Set up an action for an AWS Lambda function to sync changes to the CloudFormation stack is incorrect. Although it is possible to set up a CodePipeline action that uses an AWS Lambda function, it would be just unnecessary overhead in this scenario not to use the native CloudFormation action format.

    14. Question

    A DevOps team is tasked with integrating a code compliance solution within an AWS environment. The solution aims to ensure that all code changes adhere to security standards and policies before deployment. The system utilizes AWS CodePipeline to orchestrate the deployment process. The security team has vetted a third-party SaaS with a CLI interface to scan code changes. It requires authentication with a license key.

    Which set of changes would result in the most secure solution?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS CodeBuild is a fully managed build service in the cloud. CodeBuild compiles your source code, runs unit tests, and produces artifacts that are ready to deploy. CodeBuild eliminates the need to provision, manage, and scale your own build servers. It provides prepackaged build environments for popular programming languages and builds tools such as Apache Maven, Gradle, and more.

    In this scenario, using CodeBuild along with AWS CodePipeline — a continuous delivery service that models, visualizes, and automates the steps required to release software — leverages the natural integration between these services. There is a bit of an overlap as to which service to put a test action to, but in most cases, CodePipeline acts more as an orchestration service.

    With regards to secrets like login credentials, CodeBuild integrates with AWS Secrets Manager so they can be provisioned to and referenced within a build as environment variables.

    version: 0.2

    env:
    secrets-manager:
    SECRET_VALUE: “arn:aws:secretsmanager:us-west-2:xxxx:secret:learnaws/test/secret-l3IJg9:super_secret_key”

    phases:
    build:
    commands:
    – echo $SECRET_VALUE

    Therefore, the correct answer is: Store the license key in Secrets Manager. Set up a new AWS CodeBuild project. Leverage built-in integration with Secrets Manager and reference the secrets as environment variables in running the CLI steps. Add a new scan stage in the CodePipeline pipeline. Include a test action using the AWS CodeBuild project in the scan stage.

    The option that says: Set up a new AWS CodeBuild project. Input the license key directly as an environment variable. Configure AWS CodeBuild to run CLI steps using the environment variable. Configure a new scan stage in the CodePipeline pipeline. Include a test action using the AWS CodeBuild project in the scan stage is incorrect. A hardcoded environment variable exposes sensitive information to users who most likely shouldn’t have direct access to it. Also, it only prevents the secret from being programmatically used. So if it needs to be changed, it would have to be changed in multiple places, that is, if all instances are able to be found at all.

    The option that says: Use Amazon AppFlow to securely integrate with the third-party SaaS. Configure Amazon AppFlow to transfer the license key and other relevant data to the SaaS for compliance scanning. Set the Amazon AppFlow to handle authentication with the SaaS CLI interface and securely transmit the license key is incorrect. Amazon AppFlow is primarily designed for securely transferring data between AWS services and SaaS applications, but it does not specifically address the integration with a CLI-based solution like the one described for scanning the code. Additionally, AppFlow would require a more complex setup and may not be necessary for this use case.

    The option that says: Store the license key as an encrypted string in an Amazon DynamoDB table housing similarly sensitive credentials. Restrict table access to AWS CodeBuild service role. Set up a new AWS CodeBuild project. Include fetching the key in CLI steps to run the actual scan. Add a new scan stage to the CodePipeline pipeline. Set up a new test action with the AWS CodeBuild project in the scan stage is incorrect. DynamoDB is not a service designed to keep very sensitive information such as license keys. Although building a solution utilizing DynamoDB might be possible, it would require significant engineering investment just to keep it in feature parity with Secrets Manager.

The AWS CDK assertions module is a library that allows developers to write unit tests for AWS Cloud Development Kit (CDK) applications. It provides methods like template.hasResourceProperties to validate resource configurations, ensuring the infrastructure code is correct before deployment.

    The option that says: Update the CodeBuild build phase commands to run cdk synth and test using cdk deploy with the --no-execute flag to validate resources without performing the actual deployment is incorrect because it only validates resources but does not integrate unit tests. The scenario specifies running tests within the same pipeline.

    17. Question

    A development team is managing a Kubernetes application deployed on a fleet of EC2 instances.     • 2.

    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    You can use subscription filters to get access to a real-time feed of log events from CloudWatch Logs and have it delivered to other services such as an Amazon Kinesis stream, an Amazon Data Firehose stream, or AWS Lambda for custom processing, analysis, or loading to other systems. When log events are sent to the receiving service, they are Base64 encoded and compressed with the gzip format.

    You can use filter expressions to interpret the data in each log event and restrict what gets delivered to the destination AWS resource (e.g, AWS Lambda, Amazon Kinesis).

    Here is an example of a filter expression that filters log events containing 5xx errors.

    In this scenario, the best course of action is to publish the logs of EKS components to Amazon CloudWatch Logs. Then, create a subscription filter with Lambda as the subscription feed destination. Use filter expressions to filter only particular events that get delivered to Lambda. Lambda will further evaluate, process the log event, and send an email notification to an SNS topic.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Publish the EKS components logs to Amazon CloudWatch Logs. Configure a subscription filter for each component log and select a Lambda function as the subscription feed destination.

  18. Question 18 of 74
    18. Question

    A company utilizes AWS for its applications, where each application team has its own AWS account within an AWS Organizations organization. To ensure adherence to security standards, the strict use of AWS CloudFormation for every deployment is enforced to prevent misconfigurations. The production support team can resolve application-related issues by modifying resources through the AWS Management Console.

    A DevOps engineer is tasked with implementing a solution that promptly detects any AWS service misconfigurations leading to non-compliance. The solution must automatically remediate these issues within 15 minutes of identification and provide a centralized dashboard primarily focused on security findings, compliance, and actionable insights. The enforcement of common security standards such as CIS AWS Foundations Benchmark and AWS Foundational Security Best Practices Standard are not required.

    Which solution will meet the requirements with the LEAST operational overhead?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Security Hub provides you with a comprehensive view of your security state in AWS and helps you check your environment against security industry standards and best practices. One of the benefits of AWS Security Hub is a consolidated view of findings across accounts and providers.

    AWS Security Hub uses service-linked AWS Config rules to perform most of its security checks for controls.

    To support these controls, AWS Config must be enabled on all accounts—both the administrator account and member accounts—in each AWS Region where Security Hub is enabled. At a minimum, AWS Config must be configured to record resources that are required for the controls that you have enabled in each enabled standard.

    To enable AWS Config, you can easily enable AWS Config with the CloudFormation template Enable AWS Config. You can use the AWS Cloudforation StackSets sample templates.

    To have automatic remeditation, you can deploy a conformance pack. A conformance pack is a collection of AWS Config rules and remediation actions that can be easily deployed as a single entity in an account and a Region or across an organization in AWS Organizations. AWS Config includes automatic remediation capability with AWS Config rules. Automatic Remediation feature gives you the ability to associate remediation actions with AWS Config rules and the choice to execute them automatically to address non-compliant resources without manual intervention, thereby reducing time to remediate these resources.

    Security Hub can provide you with a centralized dashboard primarily focused on security findings, compliance, and actionable insights. However, you need to make sure to enable the AWS Config first for all accounts. To implement auto-remediation, utilize the conformance pack in AWS Config.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Use the CloudFormation stack set to enable AWS Config to all the accounts within the organization. Configure automatic remediations by deploying AWS conformance packs within the organization. Designate an AWS Security Hub administrator account and set up a centralized dashboard from the designated administrator account. Disable the security standard option in AWS Security Hub via the EnableSecurityHub API operation or the --no-enable-default-standards AWS CLI flag.

    The option that says: Enable AWS Config in each account and turn on the recorder to detect non-compliant resources. Use CloudWatch Logs filters for drift detection and AWS Systems Manager for automatic remediation. Set up an organization-wide aggregator in AWS Config using a delegated administrator account to provide a centralized dashboard is incorrect. Even though enabling AWS Config to all accounts can help identify non-compliant resources, using an organization-wide aggregator in AWS Config can let you monitor and track resource configurations for compliance purposes. AWS Security Hub can provide a centralized view focused on security findings, compliance, and actionable insights. Therefore, setting up a centralized dashboard in Security Hub is a much better solution with less operational overhead.

    The option that says: Use CloudFormation StackSet to enable AWS Config to all the accounts within the organization. Utilize AWS Lambda and AWS Systems Manager for automatic remediation. Designate an AWS Security Hub administrator account and set up a centralized dashboard from the designated administrator account is incorrect. Overall, this is a possible solution; however, utilizing AWS Lambda and AWS Sytems Manager for automatic remediation might add complexity. You would have to configure custom function scripts and SSM Documents and would also need to figure out how to trigger these functions and SSM Documents. As explained above, the conformance packs can come with automatic remediation. It would be better to utilize this feature for a lesser operational overhead.

    The option that says: Enable AWS Config in each account and turn on the recorder to detect non-compliant resources. Set up automatic remediations by deploying AWS conformance packs throughout the organization. Set up an organization-wide aggregator in AWS Config using a delegated administrator account to provide a centralized dashboard is incorrect. Same with the previous options, AWS Security Hub would be a better option for a centralized view of findings instead of setting up an organization-wide aggregator in AWS Config. Enabling AWS Config in each account and turning on the recorder would also add to operational overhead. Utilize Cloudformation Stacksets instead when deploying to the organization.

    19. Question

    A company is planning to deploy a new version of their legacy application in AWS which is deployed to an Auto Scaling group of EC2 instances with an Application Load Balancer in front. To avoid any disruption of their services, they need to implement canary testing first before all of the traffic is shifted to the new application version.

    Which of the following solutions can meet this requirement?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    The purpose of a canary deployment is to reduce the risk of deploying a new version that impacts the workload. The method will incrementally deploy the new version, making it visible to new users in a slow fashion. As you gain confidence in the deployment, you will deploy it to replace the current version in its entirety.

    To properly implement the canary deployment, you should do the following steps:

    – Use a router or load balancer that allows you to send a small percentage of users to the new version.

    – Use a dimension on your KPIs to indicate which version is reporting the metrics.

    – Use the metric to measure the success of the deployment; this indicates whether the deployment should continue or rollback.

    – Increase the load on the new version until either all users are on the new version or you have fully rolled back.

     

    Hence, the correct answer is: Prepare another stack that consists of an Application Load Balancer and Auto Scaling group which contains the new application version for blue/green environments. Create weighted Alias A records in Route 53 for the two Application Load Balancers to adjust the traffic.

    The option that says: Do a Canary deployment using CodeDeploy with a CodeDeployDefault.LambdaCanary10Percent30Minutes deployment configuration is incorrect because this specific configuration type is only applicable for Lambda functions and for the applications hosted in an Auto Scaling group.

    The option that says: Prepare another stack that consists of an Application Load Balancer and Auto Scaling group which contains the new application version for blue/green environments. Use an Amazon CloudFront web distribution to adjust the weight of the incoming traffic to the two Application Load Balancers is incorrect because you can’t use CloudFront to adjust the weight of the incoming traffic to your application. You should use Route 53 instead.

    The option that says: Set up an Amazon API Gateway private integration with an Application Load Balancer and prepare a separate stage for the new application version. Configure the API Gateway to do a canary release deployment is incorrect because you can only integrate a Network Load Balancer to your Amazon API Gateway. Moreover, this service is only applicable for APIs, not full-fledged web applications.

  21. Question 21 of 74
    21. Question

    A DevOps Engineer is managing the deployment of a microservice, Microservice1, in an AWS environment using AWS CodeDeploy. A single group of tags is used by the deployment group of Microservice1 to determine which instances are eligible for deployment. This tag group targets instances that have both Type=DataProcessing and Name=Microservice1 tags.

    Recently, a new Amazon EC2 instance was launched with Type=DataProcessing, Team=HR, and Name=Microservice2 tags. However, during the next CodeDeploy deployment of Microservice1, Microservice1 was unexpectedly installed on the new instance.

    The DevOps Engineer must modify the current deployment group to avoid the installation of Microservice1 on the newly created instance.

    Which of the following options would meet these requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    To help manage your Amazon EC2 instances and on-premises instances, you can use tags to assign your own metadata to each resource. Tags enable you to categorize your instances differently (for example, by purpose, owner, or environment). This is useful when you have many instances. You can quickly identify an instance or group of instances based on the tags you’ve assigned to them. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, which you define.

    When configuring instance selection by EC2 tags, deployment groups can include one or more tag groups. In a single tag group, all specified tag filters are evaluated using an OR operator; hence, an instance matching any one of the filters becomes eligible for deployment. In contrast, when multiple tag groups are defined, CodeDeploy requires that an instance match at least one tag filter in each tag group, effectively implementing a AND condition across tag groups. By converting the single tag group into two separate tag groups, the deployment group will only include instances that satisfy both conditions. This change prevents the inclusion of instances (such as the new one) that match only one of the desired tags.

    The unexpected deployment occurred because the original single tag group used OR logic between its tag filters. Consequently, an instance with Type=DataProcessing (even without Name=Microservice1) was incorrectly considered eligible. Splitting the filters into separate tag groups enforces the necessary AND logic, ensuring only instances with both tags are selected.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Modify the deployment group by converting the single tag group into multiple tag groups. One for Type=DataProcessing and another for Name=Microservice1.

    The option that says: Add a new tag group to the deployment group for Microservice1 that targets instances with the Team=HR tag is incorrect because it would only worsen the problem. Instead of preventing Microservice1 from being installed on the new instance, it would potentially lead to Microservice1 being installed on even more instances than it shouldn’t be.

    The option that says: Remove the Type=DataProcessing tag from the tag group in the deployment group for Microservice1 is incorrect because it would just make the targeting criteria broader. Without the Type=DataProcessing tag, the deployment group could potentially target instances that aren’t meant for any microservice at all, leading to incorrect deployments.

    The option that says: Modify the tag group in the deployment group for Microservice1 to target instances that have the Type=DataProcessing tag only is incorrect because it would also make the targeting criteria too broad. It would potentially target instances meant for other microservices, not just Microservice1, leading to incorrect deployments.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/instances-tagging.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/deployment-groups.html

  22. Question 22 of 74
    22. Question

    A company wants to employ a new standard that requires the creation of resources through AWS CloudFormation. Due to this, IT administrators need to make sure that users can only deploy stacks from pre-approved CloudFormation templates. They also need to implement a monitoring solution that automatically detects resources that drift from the expected configuration.

    Which actions will accomplish these requirements? (Select TWO.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Service Catalog allows IT administrators to create, manage, and distribute catalogs of approved products to end-users, who can then access the products they need in a personalized portal. A product is a service or application for end-users. Administrators create catalogs of products by importing AWS CloudFormation templates. Administrators can control which users have access to each product to enforce compliance with organizational business policies. Administrators can also set up adopted roles, so that end users only require IAM access to AWS Service Catalog in order to deploy approved resources.

    An AWS Service Catalog launch constraint specifies the AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that AWS Service Catalog assumes when an end-user launches a product. Without this, end-users must launch and manage products using their own IAM credentials. To do so, they must have permissions for AWS CloudFormation, AWS services that the products use, and AWS Service Catalog. By using a launch role, you can instead limit the end users’ permissions to the minimum they require for that product.

    You can use the cloudformation-stack-drift-detection-check managed rule in AWS Config for the automated monitoring solution. This Config rule checks if the actual configuration of a CloudFormation stack differs, or has drifted, from the expected configuration.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – Use AWS Service Catalog with launch constraint to authorize users to deploy CloudFormation stacks.

    – Create an AWS Config rule that evaluates whether a CloudFormation stack has drifted from the expected configuration.

    The option that says: Use CloudFormation service role to authorize users to deploy CloudFormation stacks is incorrect. A CloudFormation service role is simply an IAM role that allows AWS CloudFormation to make calls to resources in a stack on behalf of a user. The correct permissions must be defined in the service role in order for the resources to launch successfully. The service role is implicitly needed and does not impose any constraints on the CloudFormation template.

    The option that says: Use AWS Service Catalog with template constraint to authorize users to deploy CloudFormation stacks is incorrect. The template constraint just limits the options that are available to end-users when they launch a product. It works by narrowing the allowable values for parameters that are defined in the product’s underlying AWS CloudFormation template.

    The option that says: Utilize the CloudFormation drift detection feature to detect whether a CloudFormation stack has drifted from the expected configuration is incorrect because this is still a manual process. You can, however, automate this process by running a scheduled Lambda function that calls the DescribeStackDriftDetectionStatus
     API operation.
