  23. Question 23 of 74
    23. Question

    An organization stores critical files in an Amazon S3 bucket in the us-east-1 region and requires these files to be replicated to a secondary bucket in the us-west-2 region for disaster recovery purposes. Cross-region replication has been configured to ensure that all objects and their metadata are available in both regions. Despite this setup, some objects occasionally fail to replicate due to transient errors.
    All the objects and object metadata from both regions must be accessible to each application.

    A DevOps engineer has been assigned to create a solution that automates retries for objects that fail to replicate.

    What solution requires the LEAST operational overhead while meeting the specified requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon S3 Batch Operations allow you to perform actions like copying, tagging, or deleting objects across multiple S3 objects with a single API call or console action. This helps manage large volumes of objects efficiently. You can create batch jobs that specify the action, target objects, and any necessary parameters. S3 then handles executing the actions across objects, retries and provides completion reports.

    AWS Lambda is a service that enables you to write and execute code without worrying about managing servers. You can write Lambda functions in Node.js, Python, Java, and other languages. These functions can be triggered by S3 batch operations to take action on target objects. For example, you could resize images or convert file formats across a set of objects.

    S3 Event Notifications allow buckets to trigger targets like Lambda or SNS when objects are created, deleted etc. You can configure notifications on a bucket to send events to other AWS services. For example, receiving create notifications in a SNS topic or triggering a Lambda function to process new objects. The function would receive data about the bucket and object in the event to take further action.

    By setting up an S3 event notification, any replication failures can automatically trigger a Lambda function without manual intervention. The Lambda function can then use S3 batch operations to efficiently retry replicating multiple failed objects in parallel. This solution provides an asynchronous way to handle the failed replications outside of the initial replication workflow. The S3 batch operations allow replicating objects efficiently in batches, making the solution scalable for a large number of objects. Lastly, this solution is automated and requires minimal operational effort once configured.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Configure an S3 event notifications to trigger an AWS Lambda function upon replication failures. Configure the AWS Lambda function to utilize S3 batch operations to retry the replication of failed objects.

    The option that says: Create an AWS Lambda Function that re-uploads failed replication objects using the s3.putObject() command to the destination bucket. Configure an Amazon EventBridge rule that listens to S3 Event Notifications for failed replication events and triggers the Lambda Function is incorrect. This solution introduces unnecessary complexity, and this approach is less efficient because it handles each failed replication individually rather than in batches, increasing the complexity and resource consumption.

    The option that says: Configure an Amazon SQS queue to receive S3 replication failure notifications via S3 Event Notifications. Create an AWS Lambda function to process these notifications from the queue and re-upload the failed objects using s3.putObject() command to the destination bucket is incorrect. While this method provides a robust solution for error handling by decoupling the notification reception from the processing logic, it introduces additional components (SQS), which increases the operational overhead compared to directly using S3 event notifications, s3 batch operations, and Lambda.

    The option that says: Configure an Amazon S3 Lifecycle policy to automatically retry the replication of objects that fail on the first attempt and S3 batch operations to manage the retries is incorrect. S3 Lifecycle policies are typically used for managing object lifecycles (like expiration and transitions) rather than handling replication retries directly; S3 Lifecycle policies do not natively support action on replication failure.

     

    References:

    A security team manually controls the rotation of AWS KMS customer-managed keys within its company’s AWS account. The regulatory compliance requires keys to be rotated within 80 to 90 days. The team wants to be alerted when keys are over 90 days old.

    Which strategy will accomplish this?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    You can develop custom rules and add them to AWS Config. You associate each custom rule with an AWS Lambda function, which contains the logic that evaluates whether your AWS resources comply with the rule. You associate this function with your rule, which invokes the function either in response to configuration changes or periodically. The function then evaluates whether your resources comply with your rule, and sends its evaluation results to AWS Config.

    In the scenario, you can create an AWS Config custom rule using a Lambda function that calls the DescribeKey API command in AWS KMS. This returns information about a KMS key, including its creation date. You can then use this data to check if the KMS key has not been rotated for more than 90 days.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Create an AWS Config custom rule to check for KMS keys that have not been rotated for over 90 days. Send a notification on an SNS topic once a KMS key has been identified.

You can view the full list here.

    The option that says: Use the AWS KMS Console to send a notification to an SNS topic if a KMS key has not been rotated for more than 90 days is incorrect because AWS KMS Console simply does not have a built-in feature to monitor KMS key rotation and send notifications. Therefore, this approach would not fulfill the requirement.

    The option that says: Enable AWS Security Hub and configure it to send notifications to an Amazon SNS topic whenever it finds KMS key that have not been rotated for more than 90 days is incorrect. AWS Security Hub only provides a comprehensive view of security alerts and security posture across your AWS accounts. With Security Hub, you have a single place that aggregates, organizes, and prioritizes your security alerts, or findings, from multiple AWS services, such as Amazon GuardDuty, Amazon Inspector, Amazon Macie, AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) Access Analyzer, AWS Systems Manager, and AWS Firewall Manager, as well as from AWS Partner Network (APN) solutions. It does not produce findings on AWS KMS resources such as the KMS key.

  25. Question 25 of 74
    25. Question

    A company has recently migrated to AWS for its infrastructure needs and established multiple AWS accounts for various departments. The goal is to ensure that all Organizational Units (OUs) adhere to the same set of compliance and security rules and have the flexibility to update these rules across all OUs simultaneously and efficiently.

    The company requires that all Elastic Block Store (EBS) volumes be encrypted using Key Management Service (KMS) when they are created in a CloudFormation stack. Additionally, they are considering the use of AWS Control Tower for centralized governance.

    How can the company efficiently manage this multi-account environment without manually configuring each account individually? (Select TWO.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Control Tower is a service that provides the easiest way to set up and govern a new, secure, multi-account AWS environment. It establishes a landing zone based on best-practice blueprints and enables governance using guardrails you can choose from a pre-packaged list.

    AWS CloudFormation is a service that helps you model and set up your Amazon Web Services resources. You create a template that describes all the AWS resources you want, and AWS CloudFormation provides and configures those resources for you.

    AWS Control Tower manages a multi-account environment and enforces compliance and security rules across all Organizational Units (OUs). Proactive controls in AWS Control Tower enforce these rules, ensuring that all OUs adhere to the same set of compliance and security rules.

    AWS CloudFormation is used for resource creation, specifically for creating Elastic Block Store (EBS) volumes. CloudFormation hooks can trigger AWS Lambda functions. A Lambda function can be used to encrypt all EBS volumes using Key Management Service (KMS) whenever a CloudFormation stack is created. This ensures that all EBS volumes are encrypted using KMS, meeting the company’s specific requirements.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – In the multi-account environment managed by AWS Control Tower, implement proactive AWS Control Tower controls to enforce compliance and security rules across all Organizational Units (OUs).

    – Use CloudFormation hooks to trigger a Lambda function that encrypts all EBS volumes using KMS whenever a CloudFormation stack is created.

    The option that says: In the multi-account environment managed by AWS Control Tower, implement detective AWS Control Tower controls to monitor compliance and security rules across all OUs and alert when non-compliance is detected is incorrect because detective controls in AWS Control Tower are primarily used for monitoring and alerting, not for enforcement. They do not enforce any rules.

    The option that says: Use AWS Organizations to create a Service Control Policy (SCP) that enforces the encryption of all EBS volumes using KMS when they are created in a CloudFormation stack is incorrect because SCPs in AWS Organizations do not have the ability to enforce the encryption of EBS volumes using KMS when they are created in a CloudFormation stack. SCPs only provide central control over the maximum available permissions for all accounts in your organization, ensuring that your accounts stay within your organization’s access control guidelines.

    The option that says: Use CloudFormation hooks to trigger a Lambda function that automatically creates a new KMS key for each EBS volume when they are created in a CloudFormation stack is incorrect because while you can use CloudFormation hooks to trigger a Lambda function, automatically creating a new KMS key for each EBS volume when they are created in a CloudFormation stack may not be a good practice. It could lead to a large number of KMS keys that need to be managed and could potentially increase costs.

  26. Question 26 of 74
    26. Question

    A company is leveraging AWS services, including AWS Organizations and AWS IAM Identity Center, to manage its AWS accounts. The data analytics team operates an AWS account for data processing operations. The team members have been granted the AdministratorAccess AWS managed policy through permission set in the IAM Identity Center, which provides full access to AWS services and resources.

    Recently, instances of unauthorized IAM users being created within the data analytics team’s AWS account have been observed, posing potential security risks. It has been decided to implement a preventive measure to restrict the creation of new IAM users within the data analytics team’s AWS account.

    What approach should be taken to prevent the creation of unauthorized IAM users in the data analytics team’s AWS account?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Service Control Policies (SCPs) are a type of organization policy that you can use to manage permissions in your organization. SCPs offer central control over the maximum available permissions for all accounts in your organization. They do not grant permissions but rather define a permission guardrail or set limits on the actions that your organization’s IAM users and IAM roles can perform. An SCP that denies the iam:CreateUser action would effectively prevent the creation of new IAM users in the data analytics team’s AWS account, regardless of the permissions granted to the IAM entities in the account.

    It’s important to note that SCPs affect every user and role, including the root user, in every account it’s attached to. Therefore, when implementing SCPs, AWS strongly recommends that you don’t attach SCPs to the root of your organization without thoroughly testing the policy’s impact on accounts. Instead, create an organizational unit (OU) that you can move your accounts into one at a time, or at least in small numbers, to ensure that you don’t inadvertently lock users out of key services.

    SCPs are used in AWS Organizations to set fine-grained permissions for your accounts. An SCP that denies the iam:CreateUser action would effectively prevent the creation of new IAM users in the data analytics team’s AWS account, regardless of the permissions granted to the IAM entities in the account.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Use AWS Service Control Policy (SCP) to deny the iam:CreateUser action in the data analytics team’s AWS account.

    The option that says: Create a permissions boundary that restricts the iam:CreateUser and iam:CreateAccessKey actions for all IAM users in the data analytics team’s AWS account is incorrect. While a permissions boundary can restrict both iam:CreateUser and iam:CreateAccessKey actions, it’s not the most effective solution because it only applies to IAM users or roles to which the boundary is attached. If new roles or users are added without the boundary, they can still perform these actions. Additionally, users with broad permissions can bypass the boundary, making it less secure than an SCP, which enforces restrictions at the account level.

    The option that says: Monitor the IAM CreateUser event in CloudTrail logs. Set up an alarm to notify an administrator when this event occurs is incorrect because while monitoring the IAM CreateUser event in AWS CloudTrail logs and setting up an alarm can help detect the creation of unauthorized IAM users, it does not prevent their creation. This approach is reactive rather than preventive.

    The option that says: Modify the permission set associated with the data analytics team’s IAM users to exclude the iam:CreateUser action is incorrect because modifying the permission set to exclude the iam:CreateUser action would just affect the IAM entities associated with that permission set. Other IAM entities in the account could still potentially create new IAM users if their permissions allow the iam:CreateUser action. Therefore, this approach does not guarantee that new IAM users cannot be created in the account.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/organizations/latest/userguide/orgs_manage_policies_scps.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/organizations/latest/userguide/orgs_manage_policies_scps_examples.html

    27. Question

    A company has chosen AWS as its cloud platform to build its innovative software application. The DevOps engineer is responsible for setting up an AWS Control Tower landing zone to ensure a well-governed and secure environment.

    They want to implement a permission model that follows the principle of least privilege and allows each department to manage only the resources that they own. AWS Security Hub has also been enabled to check the workloads against security industry standards and best practices.

    What combination of steps must the engineer follow to meet these requirements? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Attributes for access control is the name of the page in the IAM Identity Center console where you select user attributes that you want to use in policies to control access to resources. You can assign users to workloads in AWS based on existing attributes in the users’ identity source.

    For example, suppose you want to assign access to S3 buckets based on department names. While on the Attributes for access control page, you select the Department user attribute for use with attribute-based access control (ABAC). In the IAM Identity Center permission set, you then write a policy that grants users access only when the Department attribute matches the department tag that you assigned to your S3 buckets. IAM Identity Center passes the user’s department attribute to the account being accessed. The attribute is then used to determine access based on the policy.

    You can create permissions policies that determine who can access your AWS resources based on the configured attribute value. When you enable ABAC and specify attributes, IAM Identity Center passes the attribute value of the authenticated user into IAM for use in policy evaluation. You can use access control attributes in your permission sets using the aws:PrincipalTag condition key for creating access control rules.

    In this scenario, attribute-based access control (ABAC) is utilized with aws:PrincipalTag in permission sets to ensure that the users from each department will only manage their own resources. You can implement least privilege access with this setup.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – Generate permission sets and associate them with an inline policy containing the necessary permissions. Utilize the aws:PrincipalTag/Department condition key within the policy to limit the scope of permissions.

    – Enable and configure attributes for access control. Add an attribute and enter the key Department and value ${path:enterprise.department}.

    – Create users from the IAM Identity Center console and fill in the Department input box with the corresponding department. Create groups by department. Add users to the group and associate the group with AWS accounts and permission sets within IAM Identity Center.

    The option that says: Generate permission sets and associate them with an inline policy containing the necessary permissions. Utilize the aws:ResourceTag/Department condition key within the policy to limit the scope of permissions is incorrect because this will not utilize the Department attribute of the user. This will only check the tags of resources. Although the aws:ResourceTag/Department condition can certainly help, this alone does not suffice if the aws:PrincipalTag/Department condition is missing.

    The option that says: Enable and configure attributes for access control. Add tags to resources with the key Department and the value with the resource owner’s department is incorrect because tagging resources will not enable user attributes for access control. You can enable access control by mapping the Department attribute in the IAM Identity Center Console.

    The option that says: Create users from the IAM Identity Center console. Create groups by department. Add users to the group and associate the group with AWS accounts and permission sets within IAM Identity Center is incorrect. Filling the Department input box serves as the tagging of the principal. By not filling it in, you won’t be able to use the aws:PrincipalTag/Department condition on your permission sets. Hence, you won’t be able to allow each department to manage only the resources that they own.

  28. Question 28 of 74
    28. Question

    An organization has an AWS CloudFormation stack defined using a YAML-based template that communicates status updates through an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic in a single AWS account.

    A DevOps engineer has created an AWS Lambda function designed to implement automatic tagging of specific CloudFormation stack instances. The tagging occurs only during stack status change, specifically after the stack update is successful.

    Which of the following additional steps below should the DevOps engineer take to implement this automatic tagging solution effectively?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS CloudFormation allows you to model your AWS infrastructure as code to provision and manage your resources in a predictable and repeatable manner. With CloudFormation, you can define the resources needed for your application or service in a template file written in JSON or YAML format. This template acts as a blueprint and allows you to spin up an entire environment consisting of EC2 instances, databases, load balancers, etc., with just a few commands or clicks.

    It allows deploying and updating stacks, which are logical collections of resources.

    – UPDATE_COMPLETE means all changes from the stack update were successfully applied. The stack resources have been updated to match the new template.

    – UPDATE_ROLLBACK_COMPLETE occurs when a stack update fails for some reason and goes into the UPDATE_ROLLBACK_FAILED state. This signals that CloudFormation has fully rolled back all changes from the failed update and restored the stack to its previous configuration.

    Amazon EventBridge is a serverless event bus service that allows applications to respond to events from AWS services, third-party applications, and custom applications. It can route these events to targets like Lambda functions, EC2 instances, Kinesis streams, etc., for processing. Some key AWS services integrated with EventBridge are CloudWatch, CodePipeline, CodeBuild, S3, etc.

    A Lambda function is a piece of code that can be triggered by various sources like API Gateway, S3, EventBridge, etc. Lambda functions is a service that enables you to write and execute code without worrying about managing servers. You can write Lambda functions in supported languages like Python, Node.js, Java, etc., and upload them to AWS Lambda for execution.

    Amazon SNS is a fully managed publish/subscribe messaging service for delivering messages to subscribers via protocols like SMS, email, and push notifications. It can also deliver messages to AWS endpoints like SQS queues and Lambda functions. SNS topics can be used to publish messages, and subscribers, such as mobile devices, email addresses, etc., receive those messages from the topic.

    When a CloudFormation stack updates successfully, it will emit an UPDATE_COMPLETE status event. By creating an EventBridge rule that matches this event for the stack, the Lambda function can be triggered automatically whenever a successful stack update occurs. Within the Lambda function, the engineer can then write code to retrieve information about the stack instance from the event data and use the AWS SDK to apply tags as needed.

    This allows the tagging to be applied automatically without any manual steps whenever the stack updates, meeting the goal of implementing an automatic tagging solution triggered during stack status changes after a successful update. The Lambda function is triggered by the EventBridge rule listening for the relevant CloudFormation event, making this the most effective approach.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Trigger the Lambda Function via an Amazon EventBridge rule that captures the UPDATE_COMPLETE status event for the CloudFormation stack.

    The option that says: Trigger the Lambda Function via an Amazon EventBridge rule that captures the UPDATE_ROLLBACK_COMPLETE status event for the CloudFormation stack is incorrect because the UPDATE_ROLLBACK_COMPLETE event primarily indicates that the stack update has failed and rolled back, not that it was successful. Thus, triggering the Lambda function on this status would not align with the goal of tagging after successful updates.

    The option that says: Configure another SNS topic to receive UPDATE_COMPLETE events from the CloudFormation stack. Invoke the Lambda function by subscribing to the SNS topic is incorrect. This option technically aligns with the goal of triggering the Lambda function after a successful update (UPDATE_COMPLETE). However, it typically involves setting up an additional SNS topic, which might be unnecessary if one already exists that can be configured to filter for UPDATE_COMPLETE events, assuming the current setup doesn’t already filter out these specific events.

    The option that says: Configure another SNS topic to receive UPDATE_ROLLBACK_COMPLETE events from the CloudFormation stack. Invoke the Lambda function by subscribing to the SNS topic is incorrect. Similar to the previous option, this option targets the UPDATE_ROLLBACK_COMPLETE event, which does not signify a successful update. This option does not meet the specified need.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/event-detail-stack-status-change.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/using-cfn-describing-stacks.html

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-cloudformation/

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-eventbridge/

  29. Question 29 of 74
    29. Question

    A company is enforcing a compliance policy that restricts the operation of its AWS resources to specific regions within the Asia Pacific. One of its DevOps engineers was instructed to come up with a solution that sends an alert to the admin if an activity occurs outside the Asia Pacific. Also, the solution must be applied automatically to new Regions that will be launched in the future.

    Which combination of actions should the engineer take to meet these requirements? (Select TWO.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    You can turn on a trail across all regions for your AWS account. CloudTrail will deliver log files from all regions to the Amazon S3 bucket and an optional CloudWatch Logs log group that you specify. Additionally, when AWS launches a new region, CloudTrail will create the same trail in the new region. As a result, you will receive log files containing API activity for the new region without taking any action.

    Service control policies (SCPs) are a type of organization policy that you can use to manage permissions in your organization. SCPs offer central control over the maximum available permissions for all accounts in your organization. SCPs enable you to set permission guardrails by defining the maximum available permissions for IAM entities in an account. If an SCP denies an action for an account, none of the entities in the account can take that action, even if their IAM permissions allow them to do so.

    There are three requirements in the scenario:

    1. Restrict the operation of AWS resources to specific regions within the Asia Pacific.

    2. Create a solution that sends an alert if an activity occurs outside the Asia Pacific.

    3. The solution should automatically extend its functionality to new regions.

    To solve requirement 1, you can attach the following SCP to the organization root account for example:

    This SCP denies access to any operations outside of the ap-southeast-1 and ap-southeast-2 regions. The NotAction element enables you to list services whose operations (or individual operations) are exempted from this restriction. Because global services have endpoints that are physically hosted by the us-east-1 Region, they must be exempted in this way. With an SCP structured this way, requests made to global services in the us-east-1 Region are allowed if the requested service is included in the NotAction element. Any other requests to services in the us-east-1 Region is denied by this example policy.

    Requirements 2 and 3 can be satisfied by enabling AWS CloudTrail across all regions. Then configure Cloudtrail to send log events to CloudWatch Logs. Use the metric filter to look for unapproved activities in the log data. CloudWatch Logs uses these metric filters to turn log data into numerical CloudWatch metrics that you can graph or set an alarm on.

    Hence, the correct answers are: 

    – Attach a service control policy to the organization root that allows operations from approved regions and denies access to non-global services on regions outside the Asia Pacific.

    – Enable AWS CloudTrail to deliver logs from all regions to AWS CloudWatch Logs. Then, create a metric filter that sends an alert whenever an activity in non-Asia Pacific regions occurs.

    The option that says: Write a Lambda function that scans AWS activities and sends an alert if an activity is detected in regions outside of Asia Pacific. Deploy the function in all regions. Create a scheduled rule in Amazon EventBridge to trigger the Lambda function every 30 minutes is incorrect. You don’t have to implement this and reinvent the wheel. AWS CloudTrail is specifically designed for this type of task. Additionally, this method won’t automatically extend the monitoring to new regions.

    The option that says: Create a service control policy that restricts operation access to regions within the Asia Pacific using the aws:RequestedRegion condition key. Attach the SCP to all IAM identities is incorrect because you cannot attach an SCP to IAM identities. SCPs can only be attached to the root, OU, or account that you want to attach the policy to.

    The option that says: Use Amazon Inspector to run a weekly assessment of activities done in non-Asia Pacific regions. Send an alert if an activity is detected is incorrect. Amazon Inspector is just an automated security assessment service that can help you identify vulnerabilities on your EC2 instances.

     

    References:

    https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2015/12/turn-on-cloudtrail-across-all-regions-and-support-for-multiple-trails/

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/organizations/latest/userguide/orgs_manage_policies_scps_examples.html

  30. Question 30 of 74
    30. Question

    An insurance firm has a hybrid cloud architecture where its on-premises data center and VPC are connected using an AWS Direct Connect connection. They have a patch management system hosted on-premises that automatically applies the required operating system patches of their Windows and Linux servers. A DevOps Engineer was given the task to synchronize the patch baselines being used on-premises to all of the EC2 instances in your VPC, as well as to automate the patching schedule.

    Which of the following methods should the Engineer implement to meet the above requirement with the LEAST amount of effort?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager automates the process of patching managed instances with security-related updates. For Linux-based instances, you can also install patches for non-security updates. You can patch fleets of Amazon EC2 instances or your on-premises servers and virtual machines (VMs) by operating system type. This includes supported versions of Windows, Ubuntu Server, Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL), SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES), Amazon Linux, and Amazon Linux 2. You can scan instances to see only a report of missing patches, or you can scan and automatically install all missing patches.

    A managed instance is a machine that has been configured for use with Systems Manager. Systems Manager also helps you configure and maintain your managed instances. Supported machine types include Amazon EC2 instances, on-premises servers, and virtual machines (VMs), including VMs in other cloud environments. Supported operating system types include Windows Server, multiple distributions of Linux, and Raspbian.

    AWS Systems Manager Maintenance Windows let you define a schedule for when to perform potentially disruptive actions on your instances such as patching an operating system, updating drivers, or installing software or patches. Each Maintenance Window has a schedule, a maximum duration, a set of registered targets (the instances that are acted upon), and a set of registered tasks. You can also specify dates that a Maintenance Window should not run before or after, and you can specify the international time zone on which to base the Maintenance Window schedule.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Install the SSM Agent to all of your Amazon EC2 instances. Use AWS Systems Manager Maintenance Windows to automate the patching schedule of your resources. Use AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager to manage and deploy the security patches of your EC2 instances based on the patch baselines from your on-premises network.

    The option that says: Use the AWS Systems Manager Maintenance Windows to automate the patching schedule. Set up AWS Systems Manager Session Manager to manage and deploy the security patches of your Amazon EC2 instances based on the patch baselines from your on-premises network is incorrect because the Session Manager is primarily used to comply with corporate policies that require controlled access to instances, strict security practices, and fully auditable logs with instance access details but not for applying OS patches. Using the AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager is a more appropriate solution to implement.

    The option that says: Set up scheduled jobs using AWS Lambda and AWS Systems Manager Run Command to automate the patching schedule. Set up AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager to manage and deploy the security patches of your Amazon EC2 instances based on the patch baselines from your on-premises network is incorrect. Although it properly uses AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager, it is still better to use AWS Systems Manager Maintenance Windows instead of manually creating scheduled jobs using AWS Lambda and AWS Systems Manager Run Command. Take note that the scenario specifies that you have to meet the requirement with the LEAST amount of effort, which can be met by using the AWS Systems Manager Maintenance Windows feature. In addition, installing the SSM Agent to all of your instances is also required when using the AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager, which is not mentioned in this option.

    The option that says: Automate the patching schedule to package and distribute the required patches to your EC2 instances using AWS Systems Manager Distributor. Set up AWS Systems Manager State Manager to automate the process of keeping your Amazon EC2 and hybrid infrastructure in a state that you define, which includes the OS patches that should be applied in each EC2 instance is incorrect because the AWS Systems Manager State Manager is primarily used as a secure and scalable configuration management service that automates the process of keeping your Amazon EC2 and hybrid infrastructure in a state that you define. This does not handle patch management, unlike AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager. With the State Manager, you can configure your instances to boot with a specific software at start-up; download and update agents on a defined schedule; configure network settings and many others, but not the patching of your EC2 instances.

  31. Question 31 of 74
    31. Question

    A company wants to backup all its Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volumes at the frequency specified on their corresponding backup::frequency tag values. The company’s DevOps Engineer has implemented automated backups using the AWS Backup service for all Amazon EBS volumes and grouped them based on their custom tag values.

    The backup::frequency tag can have a value of daily, weekly, or monthly. It is a common occurrence where developers forget to tag their EBS Volumes when creating them; that’s why the DevOps Engineer must implement a solution that ensures that all the EBS Volumes have this necessary tag. The engineer must verify that all EBS volumes are backed up at least weekly by default or based on the volume’s tag value.

    Which solution can satisfy all the requirements with the LEAST operational overhead?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Use AWS Config to evaluate the configuration settings of your AWS resources. You do this by creating AWS Config rules, which represent your ideal configuration settings. While AWS Config continuously tracks the configuration changes that occur among your resources, it checks whether these changes do not comply with the conditions in your rules. If a resource does not comply with the rule, AWS Config flags the resource and the rule as non-compliant.

    AWS Config Custom Rules are rules that you create from scratch. AWS Config custom rules created with Lambda are called AWS Config Custom Lambda Rules, and AWS Config custom rules created with Guard are called AWS Config Custom Policy Rules.

    AWS Config allows you to remediate noncompliant resources that are evaluated by AWS Config Rules. AWS Config applies remediation using AWS Systems Manager Automation documents. These documents define the actions to be performed on noncompliant AWS resources evaluated by AWS Config Rules. You can associate SSM documents by using AWS Management Console or by using APIs. To add automatic remediation, you can select the config rule and select Manage remediation from the actions.

    A tag is a label that you assign to an AWS resource. Each tag consists of a key and an optional value, both of which you define. Tags make it easier to manage, search for, and filter resources. Tags enable you to categorize your AWS resources in different ways, for example, by purpose, owner, or environment. This is useful when you have many resources of the same type—you can quickly identify a specific resource based on the tags you’ve assigned to it. You can assign one or more tags to your AWS resources. Each tag has an associated value.

    Tags are interpreted strictly as a string of characters and are not automatically assigned to your resources. You can edit tag keys and values, and you can remove tags from a resource at any time. You can set the value of a tag to an empty string, but you can’t set the value of a tag to null. If you add a tag that has the same key as an existing tag on that resource, the new value overwrites the old value. If you delete a resource, any tags for the resource are also deleted.

    In order to detect all EBS volumes that are not tagged with backup::frequency you should configure a custom rule and then setup automatic remediation with the AWS Systems Manager Automation document.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Enable AWS Config in the AWS account and establish a custom rule to identify non-compliant EBS Volumes that do not have the backup::frequency tag. Implement an automated remediation action through a custom AWS Systems Manager Automation runbook, ensuring the application of the backup::frequency tag with a weekly value to resolve compliance issues.

    The option that says: Enable AWS Config in the AWS account and establish a custom Lambda rule to identify non-compliant EBS Volumes that do not have the backup::frequency tag. Implement an automatic remediation action through the same custom Lambda function configured with the rule, ensuring the application of the backup::frequency tag with a weekly value to resolve compliance issues is incorrect. Although this is a possible solution and satisfies all the requirements, it is more complex and will add more operational overhead. Automatic remediation in AWS Config does not directly support AWS Lambda by default. AWS Config primarily uses AWS Systems Manager Automation runbooks for the remediation process. Using AWS Systems Manager Automation is still a better approach and can satisfy all the requirements with the least operational overhead.

    The option that says: Enable AWS CloudTrail for comprehensive API activity logging. Set up an Amazon EventBridge rule to respond to EBS CreateVolume events. Design a custom AWS Systems Manager Automation runbook for applying backup::frequency tag with weekly tag value and configure it as the event trigger is incorrect because while this can automatically enforce tagging with the newly created EBS volumes, it will leave out all of the existing untagged EBS volumes. Not all of the EBS volumes can be tagged since only the new volumes are covered.

    The option that says: Enable AWS Security Hub for comprehensive API activity logging. Set up an Amazon EventBridge rule to respond to EBS CreateVolume events. Design a custom Lambda function for applying backup::frequency tag with weekly tag value and configure it as the event trigger is incorrect. Take note that the AWS Security Hub service is not suitable for comprehensive API activity logging. AWS Security Hub is a cloud security posture management service that automates best practice checks, aggregates alerts, and supports automated remediation. Same with the previous option, using the Amazon EventBridge will leave out the existing untagged EBS volumes. Even though you can include tagging the existing EBS volumes by adding more customization to your lambda script, it will only introduce additional operational overhead to the solution.

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/evaluate-config.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/config/latest/developerguide/evaluate-config_develop-rules.html

    32. Question

    On a recent AWS resources audit on your AWS Test environment account, you have found several load balancers with minimal usage in which some of them do not have back-end EC2 instances at all. Your developers are using these load balancers to test their applications on the public Internet, but they forgot to delete them after testing. These load balancers are also showing up on AWS Trusted Advisor as unused/underutilized which incur unnecessary costs. You want to be notified whenever there are changes in the Trusted Advisor checks so that you can quickly take action based on the results.

    Which of the following options will help you achieve this? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Trusted Advisor is integrated with the Amazon EventBridge and Amazon CloudWatch services. You can use Amazon EventBridge to detect and react to changes in the status of Trusted Advisor checks. And you can use Amazon CloudWatch to create alarms on Trusted Advisor metrics for check status changes, resource status changes, and service limit utilization

    Based on the rules that you create, Amazon EventBridge invokes one or more target actions when a check status changes to the value you specify in a rule. Depending on the type of status change, you might want to send notifications, capture status information, take corrective action, initiate events, or take other actions.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    The option that says: Create a CloudWatch alarm to monitor the utilization of your load balancers using ELB metrics. Use Amazon SES to send an email notification is incorrect because you have to use the AWS Trusted Advisor metrics and not ELB metrics. Moreover, you have to use SNS and not SES for sending an email notification.

    The option that says: Use AWS Config in order to automatically detect idle load balancers. Use Amazon SNS to deliver the notifications is incorrect because AWS Config cannot detect the utilization of AWS resources. You have to use AWS Trusted Advisor instead.

    The option that says: Launch a small EC2 instance that runs a custom script that programmatically checks the utilization of your load balancers. Send out email notification via Amazon SES is incorrect because this entails a lot of manual action to develop a custom script. You can simply just use Trusted Advisor to monitor the idle load balancers. Moreover, you have to use SNS for notifications and not SES.

  33. Question 33 of 74
    33. Question

    An organization has set up a hybrid cloud by expanding its data center to AWS. To meet compliance requirements, it is necessary to constantly apply patches to the on-premises servers and Amazon EC2 instances that host internal applications. The Chief Information Officer (CIO) has instructed that operating system patching should be standardized across both environments and must not happen during business hours. To secure access to AWS Systems Manager, the DevOps Engineer will use AWS Security Token Service (STS) for temporary credentials.

    What set of actions should the DevOps Engineer perform to fulfill the requirements securely with the LEAST amount of effort? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Maintenance Windows, a capability of AWS Systems Manager, helps you define a schedule for when to perform potentially disruptive actions on your nodes such as patching an operating system, updating drivers, or installing software or patches.

    AWS Systems Manager Hybrid Activations is used to set up servers, edge devices, and virtual machines (VMs) in your hybrid environment as managed nodes. You create a managed-node hybrid activation.

    Servers and virtual machines (VMs) in a hybrid environment require an AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role to communicate with the AWS Systems Manager service. The role grants AWS Security Token Service (AWS STS) AssumeRole trust to the Systems Manager service.

    In this scenario, Maintenance Windows is utilized to schedule the patch window during non-business hours. Next is to manage the on-premises servers in AWS Systems Manager by leveraging Hybrid Activations. Finally, attach an IAM role to the EC2 instances to allow AWS Systems Manager to manage them.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – Schedule a patch window that is outside business hours by utilizing Maintenance Windows.

    – Install the SSM Agent and use Systems Manager Hybrid Activations to incorporate the on-premises servers into AWS Systems Manager.

    – Create an IAM role that will be attached to the EC2 instances, which grants AWS Systems Manager access to manage them.

    The option that says: Schedule a patch window that is outside business hours by utilizing Amazon EventBridge scheduled events is incorrect because this option primarily requires additional effort to implement. A much better option is to use Maintenance Windows because it’s already integrated with AWS Systems Manager.

    The option that says: Install the SSM Agent and apply patches to the on-premises servers and EC2 instances on an hourly basis by running an AWS Systems Manager Automation document is incorrect because the patching will just potentially happen during business hours if set on an hourly basis.

    The option that says: Enable interaction of on-premises servers to AWS Systems Manager via IAM access keys is incorrect because using IAM access keys is typically not a best practice. It is better to use IAM roles for security.

  34. Question 34 of 74
    34. Question

    A leading pharmaceutical company has several web applications and GraphQL APIs hosted in a fleet of Amazon EC2 instances. There is a private EC2 instance with no Internet access that needs to upload a new object to a private Amazon S3 bucket. However, you are getting an <code>HTTP 403: Access Denied</code> error whenever you try to fetch the objects from the instance.

    What are the possible causes for this issue? (Select TWO.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    A VPC endpoint enables you to privately connect your VPC to supported AWS services and VPC endpoint services powered by PrivateLink without requiring an Internet gateway, NAT device, VPN connection, or AWS Direct Connect connection. Instances in your VPC do not require public IP addresses to communicate with resources in the service. Traffic between your VPC and the other service does not leave the Amazon network.

    Endpoints are virtual devices. They are horizontally scaled, redundant, and highly available VPC components that allow communication between instances in your VPC and services without imposing availability risks or bandwidth constraints on your network traffic.

    There are two types of VPC endpoints: interface endpoints and gateway endpoints. You should create the type of VPC endpoint required by the supported service.

    If an IAM user has permission with s3:PutObject action on an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket and got an HTTP 403: Access Denied error when uploading an object, then there might be an issue with the bucket or VPC endpoint policy.

    If the IAM user has the correct user permissions to upload to the bucket, then check the following policies for any settings that might be preventing the uploads:

    – IAM user permission to s3:PutObjectAcl

    – Conditions in the bucket policy

    – Access allowed by an Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC) endpoint policy

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – The Amazon S3 bucket policy is not properly configured

    – The Amazon Virtual Private Cloud (Amazon VPC) endpoint policy is not properly configured

    The following options are incorrect since these will not cause an HTTP 403: Access Denied error:

    – The Cross-Region replication (CRR) feature, which is used to copy objects across Amazon S3 buckets in different AWS Regions, is enabled in the bucket.

    – The bucket has a lifecycle policy that automatically moves data to the S3 Intelligent-Tiering storage class

    – Versioning is enabled in the Amazon S3 bucket.

     

    References:

    https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/s3-403-upload-bucket/

    A gaming company runs the backend for a multiplayer game on Amazon EC2 instances managed through Amazon Elastic Container Service (Amazon ECS).     Which of the options would meet the requirements with the LEAST overhead?

    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS CodeDeploy is a deployment service that automates application deployments to Amazon EC2 instances, on-premises instances, serverless Lambda functions, or Amazon ECS services.

    With native integrations to Amazon SNS, notifications may be enabled for deployment (and even instance) events. Up to 10 triggers may be configured for each deployment group for any of the following events:

    Therefore, the correct option is: Set up an SNS topic for failed deployments. Configure a CodeDeploy trigger and set the SNS topic as destination. Have stakeholders subscribe to the SNS topic using each of their personnel emails or an appropriate distribution list.

  36. Question 36 of 74
    36. Question

    A startup using Amazon DynamoDB and API Gateway has a spiky, read-heavy traffic application that experiences throttling issues. The application uses Lambda functions to run the business logic backing the API. The management needs a solution to address the throttling issues with predictable costs.

    Which option would fit the requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon API Gateway is a fully managed service that makes it easy for developers to create, publish, maintain, monitor, and secure APIs at any scale. APIs act as the “front door” for applications to access data, business logic, or functionality from backend services. API Gateway handles all the tasks involved in accepting and processing up to hundreds of thousands of concurrent API calls, including traffic management, CORS support, authorization and access control, throttling, monitoring, and API version management.

    API Gateway performance provides a great starting point for handling incoming API requests, ie. 10,000 req/s throttle quota. However, as an application scales and experiences increased traffic, it is essential to manage duplicate work in serving requests. API Gateway helps in this regard by providing the capability to enable caching for API stages.

    In addition to the caching provided by API Gateway, applications using Amazon DynamoDB can further optimize their latencies by leveraging Amazon DynamoDB Accelerator (DAX). DynamoDB Accelerator is a fully managed, highly available, in-memory caching service for DynamoDB.

    Therefore, the correct option is: Turn on API caching for the appropriate API Gateway stage. Configure a DynamoDB Accelerator cluster with the default number of nodes.

    The option that says: Increase the reserved concurrency for the Lambda function is incorrect. Simply increasing Lambda concurrency will push the throttling issue over to DynamoDB end. Also, this option simply trades off availability for costs as the application would scale linearly with load.

    The option that says: Turn on API Caching for the appropriate API Gateway stage. Configure Elasticache for Redis (cluster mode enabled) is incorrect. Elasticache would help, but it is not purpose-fit for caching DynamoDB results.

    The option that says: Request for additional Lambda concurrency for the account. Configure a DynamoDB Accelerator cluster with the default number of nodes is incorrect. Requesting additional Lambda concurrency scales your cost with your application load. Also, adding more concurrency would aggravate the issue of throttling on the DynamoDB end.

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/apigateway/latest/developerguide/api-gateway-caching.html#enable-api-gateway-caching

  37. Question 37 of 74
    37. Question

    You are working on a web application that allows designers to create mobile themes for their android phones. The app is hosted on a cluster of Auto Scaling ECS instances and its deployments are handled by AWS CodeDeploy. ALB health checks are not sufficient to tell that new version deployments are successful, rather you have custom validation scripts that verify all APIs of the application. You want to make sure that there are no 5XX error replies on the new version before continuing production deployment and that you are notified via email if results failed. You also want to configure automatic rollback to the older version when the validation fails.

    Which combination of options should you implement to meet this requirement? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    You can use CloudWatch Alarms to track metrics on your new deployment, and you can set thresholds for those metrics in your Auto Scaling groups being managed by CodeDeploy. This can invoke an action if the metric you are tracking crosses the threshold for a defined period of time. You can also monitor metrics such as instance CPU utilization, Memory utilization, or custom metrics you have configured. If the alarm is activated, CloudWatch initiates actions such as sending a notification to Amazon Simple Notification Service, stopping a CodeDeploy deployment, or changing the state of an instance. You will also have the option to automatically roll back a deployment when a deployment fails or when a CloudWatch alarm is activated. CodeDeploy will redeploy the last known working version of the application when it rolls back.

    With Amazon SNS, you can create triggers that send notifications to subscribers of an Amazon SNS topic when specified events, such as success or failure events, occur in deployments and instances. CloudWatch Alarms can trigger sending out notifications to your configured SNS topic.

    The AfterAllowTestTraffic lifecycle hook of the AppSpec.yaml file allows you to use Lambda functions to validate the new version task set using the test traffic during the deployment. For example, a Lambda function can serve traffic to the test listener and track metrics from the replacement task set. If rollbacks are configured, you can configure a CloudWatch alarm that triggers a rollback when the validation test in your Lambda function fails.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

     – Create your validation scripts on AWS Lambda and define the functions on the AppSpec lifecycle hook to validate the app using test traffic.

     – Have AWS CloudWatch Alarms trigger an AWS SNS notification when the threshold for 5xx is reached on CloudWatch.

     – Associate CloudWatch Alarms to your deployment group to have it trigger a rollback when the 5xx error alarm is active.

    The option that says: Create your validation scripts on AWS Lambda and invoke them after deployment to validate your new app version is incorrect since you will have to trigger the Lambda validation functions before going to production traffic. This also gives you the opportunity to rollback the deployment in case it is not working as expected.

    The option that says: Have AWS Lambda trigger an AWS SNS notification after performing the validation of the new app revision is incorrect because you will need to monitor the results of each API test call from Lambda if you are going to implement this. It is better to implement results monitoring as a threshold on CloudWatch.

    The option that says: Have Lambda send results to AWS CloudWatch Alarms directly and trigger a rollback when 5xx reply errors are received during deployment is incorrect because CloudWatch Alarms can’t receive direct test results from AWS Lambda.

  38. Question 38 of 74
    38. Question

    A company manages its network infrastructure in a multi-account environment in the AWS Cloud. The company utilizes Amazon VPC Peering to handle outbound traffic, wherein all outbound traffic routes through a central network operations account. A firewall appliance inspects the traffic before forwarding it to an internet gateway in the network operations account to enhance security in transit.
    The firewall appliance sends logs to Amazon CloudWatch Logs to monitor network security and detect critical events. These logs contain event severities such as CRITICAL, HIGH, LOW, and INFO. The security team has expressed the need for immediate alerting whenever any CRITICAL events are detected in the firewall logs.
    Which solution will BEST meet the requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    You can search and filter the log data coming into CloudWatch Logs by creating one or more metric filters. Metric filters define the terms and patterns to look for in log data as it is sent to CloudWatch Logs. CloudWatch Logs uses these metric filters to turn log data into numerical CloudWatch metrics that you can graph or set an alarm on.

    With metric filters, you can look for terms and patterns in log data as the data is sent to CloudWatch.

    A metric alarm watches a single Amazon CloudWatch metric or the result of a math expression based on CloudWatch metrics. The alarm performs one or more actions based on the value of the metric or expression relative to a threshold over a number of time periods. The action can be an Amazon EC2 action, an Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling action, or a notification sent to an Amazon SNS topic.

    Set up a Cloudwatch alarm that watches the metric filter and configures a notification sent to Amazon SNS Topic for the Security Team.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Set up an Amazon CloudWatch metric filter to search for CRITICAL events in the logs. Create a custom metric based on the findings. Configure a CloudWatch alarm using the custom metric to trigger an alert. Publish the alert notification to an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic. Subscribe the security team’s email address to the SNS topic.

    The option that says: Integrate Amazon CloudWatch Synthetics with the firewall appliance and set up an Amazon CloudWatch subscription filter to search for CRITICAL events in the logs. Process logs with Kinesis Data Firehose and store to S3 Bucket. Configure an S3 Event trigger for the S3 bucket to invoke a Lambda. Publish a message to an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic using Lambda when a CRITICAL event occurs. Subscribe the security team’s email address to the SNS topic is incorrect. Although this is a possible solution, configuring Kinesis Data Firehose, S3 Bucket, and AWS Lambda will introduce unnecessary complexity. Direct CloudWatch metric filters and alarms can achieve the same result with a simple setup. Using Amazon CloudWatch Synthetics won’t help either since it just continually monitors your service via “canaries” which are modular, lightweight scripts that monitor your endpoints and APIs from the outside in.

    The option that says:  Activate Amazon GuardDuty in the network operations account. Configure the GuardDuty to monitor flow logs. Set up an Amazon EventBridge event rule triggered by CRITICAL events detected by GuardDuty. Designate an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic as the target for the EventBridge rule. Subscribe the security team’s email address to the SNS topic is incorrect. Amazon GuardDuty is a valuable service for threat detection and monitoring at the network level. However, it is not specifically designed for analyzing custom log events from the firewall appliance. While it can be helpful for overall network security, it is not the most direct and efficient solution for alerting on specific CRITICAL events in the firewall logs.

    The option that says: Set up a scheduled Amazon EventBridge rule. Create a Lambda function that retrieves and analyzes the logs from AWS Cloudwatch Logs to identify CRITICAL events. Set the Lambda as the event rule’s target. Publish a message to an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic for a CRITICAL event from Lambda. Subscribe the security team’s email address to the SNS topic is incorrect. Even though this is a possible solution, the main drawback of this approach is the time delay for alerting. Since the Lambda function is triggered based on a schedule, there can be a delay between the occurrence of a CRITICAL event and when the Lambda function runs to analyze the logs.

  39. Question 39 of 74
    39. Question

    A global company uses AWS Organizations and AWS Control Tower to manage all its accounts. The company just decided to upgrade its support plan from the Basic Support plan to the Enterprise Support plan. Account Factory for Terraform (AFT) created all the existing member accounts of its organization. The DevOps Engineer must implement a solution that provisions new accounts with the upgraded Enterprise Support Plan.

    Which solution will satisfy the requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Account Factory for Terraform (AFT) sets up a Terraform pipeline to help you provision and customize accounts in AWS Control Tower. AFT provides you with the advantage of Terraform-based account provisioning while allowing you to govern your accounts with AWS Control Tower.

    AWS accounts by default come with the AWS Basic Support plan enabled. AFT provides automated enrollment into the enterprise support level, for accounts that AFT provisions. The provisioning process opens a support ticket for the account, requesting it to be added to the AWS Enterprise Support plan.

    To enable the Enterprise Support option, set the following feature flag to True in your AFT deployment input configuration

    aft_feature_enterprise_support=false

    To re-start account provisioning customizations, you can use one of these two methods:

    1. Make any change to an existing account in the account request repo.
    2. Provision a new account with AFT.

    Hence, the correct answer is: In the AFT deployment input settings, set True for the aft_feature_enterprise_support feature flag. Apply the changes when redeploying AFT.

    The option that says: Get credentials from the newly created account. Add AWSSupportAccess, a managed policy to the IAM user profile. Using AWS CLI to run the aws support create-case command. Launch an account-part-of-organizations managed rule as an AWS Config conformance pack that automatically remediates any non-compliant accounts is incorrect. Although, this will be a possible solution assuming the account is at the Business or Enterprise On-Ramp Support plan. However, remember that the new accounts provisioned by AFT are at the Basic support plan by default. The Basic support plan does not support AWS Support API.

    The option that says: Sign in to the newly created account. Change the Support plan to Enterprise from the AWS Support Console. In AWS Control Tower, modify the control_tower_parameters input to set the AWSEnterpriseSupport parameter during account provisioning is incorrect. While this approach will upgrade the newly provisioned accounts to the Enterprise Support plan, you need to upgrade each account manually, which will take a significant amount of time. The DevOps Engineer is already using AFT which can automate this process. Keep in mind that the input you provided for control_tower_parameters can’t be changed during account provisioning.

    The option that says:  Create an EventBridge rule for the CreateManagedAccount lifecycle event. Create a Lambda function to create a case using AWS SDK. Select the created Lambda function as the target is incorrect. This will only apply to the new accounts that will be provisioned NOT to the existing accounts. It is better to utilize the existing AFT pipeline instead by setting the aft_feature_enterprise_support feature flag to True to lessen the operational overhead.

  40. Question 40 of 74
    40. Question

    A healthcare organization is developing a system that stores patient records in an Amazon S3 bucket. Three departments (Radiology, Cardiology, and Neurology) must access these records for analysis. However, each department should only see the data relevant to their specialty before they can access the records.

    What approach would best fulfill these conditions MOST cost-effectively?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon S3 Access Points are a feature of S3 that allows you to create unique hostnames with dedicated access policies for your applications or shared datasets. This means you can create an access point for each department (Radiology, Cardiology, and Neurology) with policies that only allow them to access the data relevant to their specialty. This ensures that each department can only see the data they need, providing a level of data isolation and security.

    S3 Object Lambda is a feature that allows you to add your own code to S3 GET requests to modify and process data as it is returned to an application. For this scenario, you could use S3 Object Lambda to process the patient records retrieved from the S3 bucket and filter out any data irrelevant to the department making the request. This means that when a department accesses its S3 Access Point, the S3 Object Lambda function processes the data and only returns the patient records relevant to that department’s specialty.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Use an S3 access point for each department to access their respective data. Use S3 Object Lambda access point to process the data retrieved from the S3 bucket and present only the relevant data to each department.

    The option that says: Use Amazon S3 Same-Region Replication (SRR) to replicate the data across different buckets for each department is incorrect because while it could create separate buckets for each department, it doesn’t inherently filter or process the data to ensure each department only sees the data relevant to their specialty. Also, it would increase storage costs by having a copy of the data for each department, which is not as cost-effective as filtering the data at the access point.

    The option that says: Use Amazon Kinesis data stream to capture and process the data in real-time. Instead of using S3, store all patient records directly in the Kinesis data stream. Process the data from the Kinesis data stream using an AWS Lambda function and present it to each department is incorrect because this approach would not be using S3 to store patient records as stated in the scenario. Additionally, While AWS Lambda can process data from a Kinesis data stream in real-time, this approach would require a significant amount of processing power and could potentially be more expensive. This is because every record in the Kinesis data stream would need to be processed by the Lambda function, whereas with S3 Object Lambda, you only process the data that’s being retrieved.

    The option that says: Use Amazon Athena to query the patient records directly from S3 and restrict access to the relevant data for each department is incorrect. While Athena could meet some access needs, but it lacks the fine-grained data processing capabilities provided by S3 Object Lambda. Athena does not allow custom filtering of data per department on retrieval, which is a requirement in the scenario.

     

    References:

    https://aws.amazon.com/s3/features/access-points/

    https://aws.amazon.com/s3/features/object-lambda/

    41. Question

    A company runs a large number of Kubernetes clusters using Amazon EKS. These clusters use the EKS cluster autoscaler to adjust node capacity dynamically based on workloads. The company requires a solution to notify the DevOps team of any cluster running a Kubernetes version at the end of standard support. An Amazon SNS topic has been preconfigured for this purpose. The company also has a <code>Business</code> support plan from AWS Support.

    Which option will meet the requirements MOST efficiently?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Health is a service that provides ongoing visibility into your resource performance and the availability of your AWS services and accounts. It provides relevant and timely information to help manage events in progress, as well as awareness and preparation for planned activities.

    Some externally triggered changes in AWS resources require customer action or coordination in order to avoid impact to your applications. AWS Health notifies you in advance of important changes such as:

    – Open source software end of support e.g., Amazon RDS for MySQL engine version end of support, Amazon EKS Kubernetes version end of support
    – Changes that affect AWS-owned resources that might require your action e.g., Amazon RDS Certificate Authority certificates expiration, Amazon WorkDocs Companion is reaching end of life and is no longer available.

    Using AWS Health events with Amazon EventBridge (and optionally, Amazon SQS), you get near-instant event visibility and guidance to help accelerate resolution.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Set up an Amazon EventBridge rule to filter for Health planned lifecycle events specific to Kubernetes. Configure the rule to target the preconfigured SNS topic.

    The option that says: Enable the AWS Config eks-cluster-oldest-supported-version managed rule. Configure the rule to target the preconfigured SNS topic is incorrect. The evaluation of this managed Config rule is only triggered by configuration changes. If a cluster undergoes a period where it does not get any configuration change and, in the same period, has its Kubernetes version deprecated, it will not be appropriately flagged, and no notification will be sent.

    The option that says: Create an AWS Lambda function that periodically queries a trusted external source to check for EOL versions, evaluates versions of running clusters and publishes notifications to the preconfigured SNS topic when applicable. Set up a scheduled Amazon EventBridge rule and set a preconfigured Amazon SQS queue as its target. Configure the Lambda function to consume messages from the SQS queue is incorrect. This is a valid solution, but obviously, it simply involves a lot of setup and the operational overhead of maintaining and owning a Lambda function.

    The option that says: Create an AWS Lambda function to query the AWS Health API for planned lifecycle events specific to Kubernetes and publish messages to the preconfigured SNS topic. Create an AWS Config custom rule and associate it with the Lambda function is incorrect. With a Business, Enterprise On-Ramp or Enterprise support plan, querying AWS Health API is a valid option. However, this still involves the overhead of owning and maintaining a Lambda function, so it is not the most operationally efficient.

  42. Question 42 of 74
    42. Question

    A DevOps engineer is tasked to streamline the process of creating multiple AWS accounts within an AWS Organization. Each and every organization unit (OU) must be able to launch new accounts with preapproved configurations from the security team, which will standardize the baselines and network configurations for all accounts in the organization.

    Same-Region Replication (SRR) must also be configured to copy objects across Amazon S3 buckets in the same AWS Region to centralize the application log collection. Amazon CodeGuru Reviewer and Profiler will also be used to automate the code review workflow of the company. These resources must be customized and deployed to the new accounts automatically.

    Which solution entails the least amount of effort to implement?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Control Tower provides a single location to easily set up your new well-architected multi-account environment and govern your AWS workloads with rules for security, operations, and internal compliance. You can automate the setup of your AWS environment with best-practices blueprints for multi-account structure, identity, access management, and account provisioning workflow. For ongoing governance, you can select and apply pre-packaged policies enterprise-wide or to specific groups of accounts.

    AWS Control Tower provides three methods for creating member accounts:

    – Through the Account Factory console that is part of AWS Service Catalog.

    – Through the Enroll account feature within AWS Control Tower.

    – From your AWS Control Tower landing zone’s management account, using Lambda code and appropriate IAM roles.

    AWS Control Tower offers “guardrails” for ongoing governance of your AWS environment. Guardrails provide governance controls by preventing the deployment of resources that don’t conform to selected policies or detecting the non-conformance of provisioned resources. AWS Control Tower automatically implements guardrails using multiple building blocks such as AWS CloudFormation to establish a baseline, AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs) to prevent configuration changes, and AWS Config rules to continuously detect non-conformance.

    Customizations for AWS Control Tower (CfCT) helps you customize your AWS Control Tower landing zone and stay aligned with AWS best practices. Customizations are implemented with AWS CloudFormation templates and service control policies (SCPs).

    This CfCT capability is integrated with AWS Control Tower lifecycle events so that your resource deployments remain synchronized with your landing zone. For example, when a new account is created through the account factory, all resources attached to the account are deployed automatically. You can deploy the custom templates and policies to individual accounts and organizational units (OUs) within your organization.

    In this scenario, the requirement is to simplify the creation of AWS accounts that have governance guardrails and a defined baseline in place. To save time and resources, you can use AWS Control Tower to automate account creation. With the appropriate user group permissions, you can specify standardized baselines and network configurations for all accounts in the organization.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Set up an AWS Control Tower Landing Zone. Enable pre-packaged guardrails to enforce policies or detect violations. Use the Customizations for AWS Control Tower (CfCT) feature to include all the custom resources to each new account automatically.

    The option that says: Configure AWS Resource Access Manager (AWS RAM) to launch new AWS accounts as well to standardize the baselines and network configurations for each organization unit is incorrect. The AWS Resource Access Manager (RAM) service simply helps you to securely share your resources across AWS accounts or within your organization or organizational units (OUs) in AWS Organizations. It is not capable of launching new AWS accounts with preapproved configurations.

    The option that says: Set up an AWS Config aggregator on the root account of the organization to enable multi-account, multi-region data aggregation. Deploy conformance packs to standardize the baselines and network configurations for all accounts is incorrect. AWS Config cannot provision accounts. A conformance pack is only a collection of AWS Config rules and remediation actions that can be easily deployed as a single entity in an account and a Region or across an organization in AWS Organizations.

    The option that says: Centralized the creation of AWS accounts using AWS Systems Manager OpsCenter. Enforce policies and detect violations to all AWS accounts using AWS Security Hub is incorrect. AWS Systems Manager is just a collection of services used to manage applications and infrastructure running in AWS that is usually in a single AWS account. The AWS Systems Manager OpsCenter service is just one of the capabilities of AWS Systems Manager and provides a central location where operations engineers and IT professionals can view, investigate, and resolve operational work items (OpsItems) related to AWS resources.

    The company aims to enhance the CI/CD process by implementing a notification system to provide alerts for any failures in the pipelines in AWS. A senior DevOps engineer has been assigned to review the custom event pattern in Amazon EventBridge, prepared by a junior DevOps engineer, as shown below:

    • 1.
    • 2.
