    Correct

    Incorrect

    Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, availability, and performance of AWS CodePipeline. You should collect monitoring data from all parts of your AWS solution so that you can more easily debug a multi-point failure if one occurs.

    You can use the following tools to monitor your CodePipeline pipelines and their resources:

    Amazon EventBridge — Use Amazon EventBridge to detect and react to pipeline execution state changes (for example, send an Amazon SNS notification or invoke a Lambda function).

    AWS CloudTrail — Use CloudTrail to capture API calls made by or on behalf of CodePipeline in your AWS account and deliver the log files to an Amazon S3 bucket. You can choose to have CloudWatch publish Amazon SNS notifications when new log files are delivered so you can take quick action.

    Console and CLI — You can use the CodePipeline console and CLI to view details about the status of a pipeline or a particular pipeline execution.

    Amazon EventBridge is a web service that monitors your AWS resources and the applications you run on AWS. You can use Amazon EventBridge to detect and react to changes in the state of a pipeline, stage, or action. Then, based on rules you create, Amazon EventBridge invokes one or more target actions when a pipeline, stage, or action enters the state you specify in a rule. Depending on the type of state change, you might want to send notifications, capture state information, take corrective action, initiate events, or take other actions.

    You can configure notifications to be sent when the state changes for:

    – Specified pipelines or all your pipelines. You control this by using "detail-type": "CodePipeline Pipeline Execution State Change".

    – Specified stages or all your stages, within a specified pipeline or all your pipelines. You control this by using "detail-type": "CodePipeline Stage Execution State Change".

    – Specified actions or all actions, within a specified stage or all stages, within a specified pipeline or all your pipelines. You control this by using "detail-type": "CodePipeline Action Execution State Change".

    Hence, the correct answer is: All failed deploy and build actions across all the pipelines.

    The option that says: All failed deploy and build pipelines is incorrect because the CodePipeline Action Execution State Change type only tracks action-level events in CodePipeline and not pipeline-level events.

    The option that says: All failed deploy and build stage across all the pipelines is incorrect because just as mentioned above, the configuration tracks action-level events not stage-level events. This could have been the right answer if the event type is CodePipeline Stage Execution State Change.

    The option that says: There will be no match since the custom event pattern is invalid is incorrect because the provided pattern for the EventBridge rule is simply a valid one.

  44. Question 44 of 74
    44. Question

    A tech startup has recently migrated their microservices architecture to AWS. They are utilizing Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) to orchestrate their containerized applications. For monitoring, they have chosen Amazon Managed Service for Prometheus. The applications are running in an EKS cluster in the startup’s AWS account. The startup’s engineering team wants to be notified of any critical alerts related to their applications. They have an existing Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic set up for notifications, which is in the same AWS account as the EKS cluster.

    What sequence of actions should the engineering team take to achieve this requirement? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    The Alert Manager in Amazon Managed Service for Prometheus (AMP) handles the alerts that are sent when the alerting rules are firing. It deduplicates, groups, and routes the alerts to downstream receivers. The Alert Manager configuration file in AMP has two main sections: template_files and alertmanager_config. template_files contains the templates used for messages sent by receivers. alertmanager_config contains the alert manager configuration. This configuration uses the same structure as an alert manager config file in standalone Prometheus.

    Alerting rules in AMP allow you to define alert conditions based on PromQL and a threshold. When the rule triggers the threshold, a notification is sent to the alert manager, which forwards the notification downstream to receivers such as Amazon Simple Notification Service. To use rules in AMP, you create one or more YAML rules files that define the rules. An AMP rules file has the same format as a rules file in standalone Prometheus.

    Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) integrates with AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) so that you can specify which SNS actions a user in your AWS account can perform with SNS resources. The sns:Publish permission allows a user to send messages to a topic. The sns:GetTopicAttributes permission allows a user to retrieve the properties of a topic. To enable other users or applications to publish to the topic, you should use IAM to give publish permission to the topic.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – Configure the Amazon Managed Service for Prometheus to use the alert manager configuration and set up an alerting rule for critical alerts. Amazon Managed Service for Prometheus is a monitoring service that makes it easy to monitor containerized applications at scale. The alert manager configuration and alerting rules are essential components of this service, which allow it to generate alerts based on specific conditions.

    – Update the Amazon SNS topic’s access policy to grant the Amazon Managed Service for Prometheus service the sns:Publish and sns:GetTopicAttributes permissions. The Amazon Managed Service for Prometheus needs these permissions to publish notifications to the SNS topic when an alert is triggered. By updating the access policy of the SNS topic to grant these permissions, you allow AMP to publish notifications to the SNS topic.

    – Configure the alert manager to send notifications to the Amazon SNS topic when the alerting rule is triggered. The alert manager is responsible for dispatching alerts generated by the Amazon Managed Service for Prometheus. By configuring it to send notifications to the Amazon SNS topic, the engineering team can be notified of any critical alerts related to their applications.

    The option that says: Use the OpenID Connect (OIDC) to authenticate the Amazon SNS topic is incorrect because authentication between the services via OIDC is not required for Prometheus to send notifications to SNS.

    The option that says: Set up an IAM role with the sns:Publish and sns:GetTopicAttributes permissions and associate it with the EKS cluster is incorrect because the EKS cluster does not need to publish messages to the Amazon SNS topic.

    The option that says: Configure the EKS cluster to send notifications to the Amazon SNS topic when the alerting rule is triggered is incorrect because the EKS cluster is not responsible for generating or sending alerts. This is the job of the Amazon Managed Service for Prometheus, which monitors the applications running in the EKS cluster.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/prometheus/latest/userguide/AMP-alert-manager.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/prometheus/latest/userguide/AMP-Ruler.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/sns-using-identity-based-policies.html

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-sns/

    45. Question

    A DevOps engineer needs to ensure that a compliance bucket policy is attached to specific S3 buckets. If a created bucket allows public access or has an incorrect policy, the admin should be notified via email. The incorrect policy should also be automatically replaced by the proper policy. Furthermore, the solution should involve continuous monitoring and enforcement of bucket policies.

    How can the engineer satisfy the requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Config enables continuous monitoring of your AWS resources, making it simple to assess, audit, and record resource configurations and changes. AWS Config does this through the use of rules that define the desired configuration state of your AWS resources.

    You can use AWS Config to monitor Amazon S3 bucket ACLs and policies for violations. If AWS Config finds a policy violation, an Amazon CloudWatch Event rule can trigger an AWS Lambda function which either corrects the S3 bucket ACL or notifies you via Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) that the policy is in violation and allows public read or public write access.

    Hence, the correct answer is the option that says: Use an AWS Config rule to check for noncompliant bucket policy and have it invoke a Lambda function when an S3 bucket is created. Use the Lambda function to automatically set the proper policy and trigger an SNS topic to alert the admin.

    The option that says: Use the Amazon S3 event notification feature to trigger a Lambda function when an S3 bucket is created. Use the Lambda function to automatically set the proper policy and trigger an SNS topic to alert the admin is incorrect because an S3 bucket must be created first before you can enable the S3 event notification feature. The S3 event notification provides notification for object-level events.

    The option that says: Use an Amazon EventBridge (Amazon CloudWatch Events) rule to trigger a Lambda function when an S3 bucket is created. Use the Lambda function to verify if the bucket has the correct policy. If not, modify the PublicAccessBlock and send notifications to an SNS topic to alert the admin is incorrect. The PublicAccessBlock configuration just specifies whether Amazon S3 should block public ACLs and policies. The correct way is to update the noncompliant bucket with the correct bucket policy.

    The option that says: Use an Amazon EventBridge (Amazon CloudWatch Events) rule to trigger a Lambda function when an S3 bucket is created. Use the Lambda function to verify if the bucket has the correct policy. If not, modify the PublicAccessBlock and send notifications to an SNS topic to alert the admin. Create another EventBridge (CloudWatch Events) rule that triggers an SNS topic to alert the admin when a PutBucketPolicy event occurs is incorrect. You don’t have to send a notification for every PutBucketPolicy action as this will notify the admin every time a policy is attached to a bucket — even if it’s the right policy.

    A well-known non-profit organization has a public website that serves data from an S3 bucket.     Amazon GuardDuty is a security monitoring service for AWS environments. It analyzes various data sources and features including, but not limited to, AWS CloudTrail logs, VPC flow logs, DNS logs, S3 logs, RDS login activity, and EBS volumes. GuardDuty utilizes threat intelligence feeds and machine learning to detect unauthorized and malicious activity, such as privilege escalation, credential exposure, and communication with malicious IP addresses or domains.

    Two ways to fine-tune GuardDuty monitoring are —

    1. a trusted IP list, which allows GuardDuty to skip the creation of finding if the IP in question is in the list. Thereby, reducing costs.
    2. and, on the opposite end, a threat list which makes sure GuardDuty creates a finding for the IP in question if it matches one on the list.

     

    Therefore, the correct options include:

    – In GuardDuty, set up a threat list and a trusted IP list using the respective files in S3 as sources. Activate both lists.
     – Create a Lambda function that updates the trusted IP list and the threat list in GuardDuty from the files in the S3 bucket. The function should also reactivate the updated lists. Enable event notifications to Amazon EventBridge for the S3 bucket. Create an EventBridge rule to run the Lambda function on update of the files.

    The option that says: In GuardDuty, set up a threat list using the respective S3 list as source. Disregard the trusted IP list is incorrect. This may lead to GuardDuty creating findings for IP addresses that are known to be trustworthy.

    The option that says: In GuardDuty, set up a threat list and a trusted IP list using the respective files in S3 as sources. Activate the trusted IP list is incorrect. A list, either threat or trusted IP, must be activated to effect GuardDuty findings.

    The option that says: Create a Lambda function that updates the trusted IP list and the threat list in GuardDuty from the files in the S3 bucket. Enable event notifications to Amazon EventBridge for the S3 bucket. Create an EventBridge rule to run the Lambda function on update of the files is incorrect. The updated lists need to be reactivated to take effect.

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/guardduty/latest/ug/what-is-guardduty.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/guardduty/latest/ug/guardduty_upload-lists.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/EventBridge.html

    47. Question

    A startup hosts all business logic backing API Gateway endpoints using AWS Lambda functions. A DevOps engineer is tasked with centralizing application logs to enable search across service boundaries and setting up email notifications for critical error messages found in the logs.

    Which set of options will suffice the requirements with the least overhead? (Select TWO.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS CloudWatch Logs is a service that allows you to collect, monitor, and store logs from various AWS resources and applications. CloudWatch Logs can be used to capture log data generated by services like Amazon EC2 instances, AWS Lambda functions, and custom applications, storing them for easy analysis and troubleshooting.

    CloudWatch Logs can be used for rudimentary monitoring with metrics and notifications:

    Metrics: CloudWatch Logs can extract metrics from log data, allowing you to track and visualize trends in log events over time. You can define custom metrics based on log data patterns or use built-in metrics provided by CloudWatch Logs.

    Notifications: CloudWatch Logs supports log-based event triggers, which enable you to create alarms based on specific log patterns or metrics thresholds. When an alarm is triggered, CloudWatch can send notifications via Amazon SNS, Amazon SQS, or AWS Lambda, enabling prompt response to critical events or anomalies in log data.

    CloudWatch logs can be arranged into logical groups so multiple sources can be configured and monitored as a single entity. However, in relation to the following scenario, in AWS Lambda, this is not the default, as each Lambda function sends its log to a log group having the same name. So each Lambda function must be explicitly configured to send logs to the desired log group.

    Therefore, the correct set of options are:

    – Create a CloudWatch Logs group. Configure all Lambda functions to send logs to the created log group.
     – Create an SNS topic. Set up a metric filter to aggregate error logs on the relevant log group. Create a Cloudwatch alarm and correspondingly set the metric filter and the SNS topic. Subscribe appropriate email addresses or distribution list/s to the SNS topic.

    The option that says: Create an external Lambda extension to send logs to Amazon OpenSearch Service. Configure all Lambda functions to use the Lambda extension is incorrect. Writing and maintaining an external Lambda extension is a non-trivial overhead.

    The option that says: Configure all Lambda functions to send logs to the default log group is incorrect. If you do this, then you would have as many log groups as functions and would need custom logic (hence code and infrastructure) to aggregate them another way.

    The option that says: Spin up an OpenSearch Service domain (cluster). Create an SNS topic and subscribe the appropriate email addresses or distribution list/s to it. Configure alerting in OpenSearch service, set an appropriate trigger, and set the notifications channel to the SNS topic is incorrect. An OpenSearch Service domain may be a managed service but it is not serverless, and so, common concerns like usage optimization, provisioning appropriate node types, etc., are still valid concerns.

  48. Question 48 of 74
    48. Question

    A web application hosted on Amazon Elastic Beanstalk is experiencing an unexpected increase in errors. The application logs, containing the timestamp, error code, and source IP address of each error, are stored in a log group in Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

    The DevOps team needs to investigate an incident that happened two days ago and wants to find out the total number of specific error codes that occurred over the past week.

    Which of the following options should the DevOps team use to obtain the required data?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon CloudWatch Logs Insights is a fully integrated, interactive, and pay-as-you-go log analytics service for CloudWatch. It lets you explore, analyze, and visualize your logs instantly, allowing you to troubleshoot operational problems easily. One of the powerful features of CloudWatch Logs Insights is its query language. You can use this to retrieve specific log data, filter on specific fields, calculate aggregate statistics, sort on any field, and more.

    In the context of the question, the DevOps team needs to find the total number of specific error codes that occurred over the past week. This is where the aggregation functions in CloudWatch Logs Insights come into play. Aggregation functions perform calculations on the values of the specified field, such as count, sum, avg (average), max, min, etc. In this case, the team can use the count() function in their query to count the occurrences of the specific error code in the logs. This will give them the total number of specific error codes that occurred over the past week, which is exactly what they need for their investigation.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Use an aggregation function in a CloudWatch Logs Insights query on the log group to find the total number of a specific error code.

    The option that says: Use a CloudWatch Logs Insights query on the log group with a filter pattern to find the total number of a specific error code is incorrect. While you can use a filter pattern in CloudWatch Logs Insights to filter out logs that match a specific pattern (like a specific error code), it doesn’t automatically count the number of occurrences. You would still need to use an aggregation function to count the occurrences of the error code, which makes this option less direct.

    The option that says: Use a CloudWatch Logs metric filter on the log group to find the total number of a specific error code is incorrect because CloudWatch Logs metric filters are primarily used to turn log data into numerical CloudWatch metrics that you can graph or set an alarm on. While you could create a metric filter for a specific error code, it wouldn’t directly give you the total count of that error code over a specific past time period. Metric filters are more about monitoring real-time data.

    The option that says: Set up a CloudWatch Logs subscription to stream data to a separate application for real-time processing is incorrect because CloudWatch Logs subscriptions are primarily used to stream data to other services for further processing. While you could potentially use this to send your logs to another service that could count the occurrences of a specific error code, this would be a complex and roundabout way to get the information. It’s more about real-time processing and wouldn’t necessarily give a historical count.

     

    References:

    49. Question

    A DevOps engineer is designing a continuous delivery pipeline for Docker containers. These containers are developed and pulled from the workstations of a company. The solution should include less overhead and must meet the following requirements:

    – The container images must be automatically deployed to a test environment once pushed to a container registry.

    – Changes committed on a container’s file must also be deployed automatically.

    Which action will meet these requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon Elastic Container Registry (ECR) is a fully managed container registry that makes it easy to store, manage, share, and deploy your container images and artifacts anywhere. Amazon ECR eliminates the need to operate your own container repositories or worry about scaling the underlying infrastructure.

    AWS CodePipeline is a fully managed continuous delivery service that helps you automate your release pipelines for fast and reliable application and infrastructure updates. CodePipeline automates the build, test, and deploy phases of your release process every time there is a code change, based on the release model you define.

    AWS CodeDeploy is a fully managed deployment service that automates software deployments to a variety of compute services such as Amazon EC2, AWS Fargate, AWS Lambda, and your on-premises servers. AWS CodeDeploy makes it easier for you to rapidly release new features, helps you avoid downtime during application deployment, and handles the complexity of updating your applications.

    In this scenario, we can store the Docker images to Amazon ECR and use AWS CodeCodeploy to automate the container deployment to AWS Fargate. AWS CodePipeline is the glue that ties these two services together. With CodePipeline, you can trigger a deployment in CodeDeploy for every change made to a container in the Amazon ECR. These three services are all fully managed by AWS, so the requirement for a less operational overhead is ensured.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Push the Docker images to Amazon ECR. Use CodeDeploy to launch Docker containers to an AWS Fargate cluster. Create an AWS CodePipeline pipeline that triggers a deployment whenever a new container version is committed.

    The option that says: Push the Docker images to GitHub. Use GitHub Actions to create workflows that trigger the deployment of Docker containers to Amazon ECS using CodeDeploy whenever changes are pushed is incorrect. GitHub repositories are designed for storing code and text-based files, not large binary artifacts like Docker images. Also, there is additional complexity in managing GitHub workflows compared to using AWS’s integrated services.

    The option that says: Push the Docker images to Docker Hub. Create an AWS Lambda-based web service that uses the CodeDeploy API. Use a Docker Hub webhook to trigger the Lambda function in response to a push event is incorrect. While this might work, it typically entails a lot of development effort which is not desirable for the scenario.

    The option that says: Push the Docker images to AWS Artifact. Use CodeDeploy to launch Docker containers to Amazon ECS. Create an AWS CodePipeline pipeline that triggers a deployment whenever changes are made to a container is incorrect. AWS Artifact is just a central resource for compliance-related information. It provides on-demand access to AWS’ security and compliance reports and select online agreements.

    50. Question

    A company uses a kernel plugin via eBPF for security and observability purposes on EC2. The DevOps team manages thousands of instances, each tagged with either prod, stg, or dev. Latest versions of the plugin are always applied to stg-tagged instances, dev-tagged instances, on the other hand, can use any older version up to the version with the latest critical patch, and prod-tagged instances with one version older from latest, for stability. A solution is required to retrieve an updated list of all nodes with the versions of the plugin they are installed with, along with other system information.

    Which option will fit the requirements with the LEAST operational overhead?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Systems Manager is the operations hub for AWS applications and resources and a secure end-to-end management solution for hybrid and multi-cloud environments that enables secure operations at scale.

    Systems Manager Run Command enables commands to be executed at scale using `targets`. In this scenario, all managed instances, including on-premises servers, are configured targets for a script that populates custom inventory metadata indicating the version of the plugin. With resource data sync enabled, any changes in inventory metadata are synced to the configured S3 bucket. These can then be queried and listed by Amazon Athena.

    Therefore, the correct answer is: Create a Systems Manager custom inventory for the plugin. Populate custom inventory metadata for the plugin version using a script with the Systems Manager Run command. Set target nodes with tag value of prod, stg, or dev.     The option that says: Create a Systems Manager custom inventory for the plugin. Run a script on each node to determine its instance tag and version. However, having to run a script manually on a regular basis is a significant operational overhead.

    The option that says: Turn on SSM:ManagedInstanceInventory in AWS Config. Create a Systems Manager custom inventory for the plugin. Use Amazon Athena to query inventory findings is incorrect. Aside from not specifying an action to populate the custom inventory, using AWS Config in this scenario is an overkill, if not a convoluted way of retrieving a list of inventory metadata.

    The option that says: Assign a resource tag key for the plugin. Use Systems Manager Run Command to determine the plugin version, populate the resource tag value accordingly, and export findings to S3. Use Amazon Athena to query inventory findings is incorrect. Although it is possible to utilize a custom resource tag for this purpose, this solution requires additional overhead to retrieve the same node metadata that is available to the Systems Manager Inventory by default.

  51. Question 51 of 74
    51. Question

    A company’s application stores its important assets in an Amazon S3 bucket. The security team has observed that the application is only deployed in a single region and is not protected from regional disasters. To address the issue, the company released a new policy with the following requirements:

    • important assets must always be accessible

    • deploy the application to multiple Regions

    • users must use the same endpoint to access the assets

    Which combination of steps should the DevOps Engineer implement to achieve the requirements in the MOST operationally efficient way? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS CloudFormation StackSets extends the capability of stacks by enabling you to create, update, or delete stacks across multiple accounts and AWS Regions with a single operation.

    S3 Replication enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across Amazon S3 buckets. You can replicate objects to a single destination bucket or to multiple destination buckets. The destination buckets can be in different AWS Regions or within the same Region as the source bucket. S3 Replication requires that the source and destination buckets must have versioning enabled.

    CloudFront origin group can be used to configure origin failover for scenarios when you need high availability. Use origin failover to designate a primary origin for CloudFront plus a second origin that CloudFront automatically switches to when the primary origin returns specific HTTP status code failure responses.

    Route 53 has several routing policies to choose from, which determines how Route 53 responds to queries. This includes:

    -Simple routing policy – Use for a single resource that performs a given function for your domain, for example, a web server that serves content for the example.com website. You can use simple routing to create records in a private hosted zone.

    -Failover routing policy – Use when you want to configure active-passive failover. You can use failover routing to create records in a private hosted zone.

    In this scenario, StackSets provides an operationally efficient multi-Region deployment strategy for the Region-specific Amazon S3 buckets. S3 replication then copies new and existing objects in the primary Region to multiple deployment Regions. We can leverage a CloudFront distribution to make a single endpoint available to resolve these multiple S3 origins. Since the CloudFront origin configurations are already handling the failover, we can set Route 53 to use
    a simple routing policy.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – Utilize AWS CloudFormation StackSets to provision a new S3 bucket with versioning enabled in multiple regions. Create several S3 replication rules on the new S3 bucket in the primary region to replicate all its contents to the other regions. Copy the important assets from the existing S3 bucket to the new S3 bucket in the primary region.

    – Create a CloudFront distribution and configure new origins for each bucket. Create an origin group containing all the recently created origins, then modify the default behavior of the distribution to use the new origin group.

    – Create an alias record in Route 53 and configure a simple routing policy that uses the CloudFront distribution as a target.

    The option that says: Utilize AWS CloudFormation StackSets to provision a new S3 bucket with versioning enabled in multiple regions. Copy the important assets from the existing S3 bucket to the new S3 buckets. Create a Lambda function to copy important assets that are added to the new S3 bucket in the primary Region to other regions is incorrect because it is less operationally efficient. S3 replication can provide the essential functionality without custom code. Therefore, the Lambda function is not required.

    The option that says: Create a CloudFront distribution and configure new origins for each bucket. Deploy a Lambda@Edge function to validate the availability of the origin and route the viewer request to an available nearby origin is incorrect because it involves custom code within the Lambda@Edge function. The custom code is unnecessary because of native handling within the origin configurations. Therefore, making it less operationally efficient.

    The option that says: Create an alias record in Route 53 and configure a failover routing policy that uses the newly created S3 buckets as targets is incorrect since there aren’t multiple records to benefit from failover routing, and the CloudFront origin setup is already handling the failover.

  52. Question 52 of 74
    52. Question

    A media company operates a video streaming application running across three Availability Zones to ensure high availability and fault tolerance. The architecture includes an Application Load Balancer (ALB) for traffic management, Amazon ECS for running the application, and Amazon Aurora for storing video metadata. The application is deployed through AWS CloudFormation templates, and all Docker container images are securely stored in an Amazon Elastic Container Registry (ECR) within the same AWS account and region. The process to build Docker images from Dockerfiles typically takes over an hour.

    A DevOps engineer must create a Disaster Recovery (DR) strategy in a different region, aiming for a Recovery Point Objective (RPO) of 7 hours and a Recovery Time Objective (RTO) of 1 hour.

    What is the most cost-effective and operationally efficient way to meet RTO and RPO requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Recovery Time Objective (RTO) refers to the duration of time and the level of service that a business process must be restored to after a disaster or disruption. This is done to prevent any negative consequences that may come from a break in business continuity. For instance, if a company has an RTO of 1 hour, it means that the system must be restored within 1 hour to maintain continuity of business operations.

    Recovery Point Objective (RPO) refers to the maximum targeted period in which data might be lost from an Information Technology service due to a major incident. For example, an RPO of 15 minutes means, at most, 15 minutes of data could be lost.

    Disaster Recovery refers to a pre-planned process of restoring data and system access in the event of a natural or human-induced disaster. The goal is to enable continued business operations as quickly and smoothly as possible.

    Amazon Aurora is a relational database service provided by AWS that is compatible with MySQL and PostgreSQL. It is fully managed so that setup, operation, and scaling of the database is handled by AWS.

    Amazon Aurora cross-region replication allows setting up a secondary Aurora replica in a different AWS region for disaster recovery purposes. It asynchronously replicates changes to the primary database, helping meet the specified RPO.

    Amazon ECR (Elastic Container Registry) is a fully managed container registry service provided by AWS. It allows you to securely store, manage, and deploy Docker container images and artifacts. With ECR, developers can share images within their organization or make images public. It eliminates the need to set up and manage your own container registry infrastructure.

    Elastic Container Registry (ECR) cross-region replication synchronizes Docker container image repositories across regions.

    To ensure the Recovery Time Objective (RTO) and Recovery Point Objective (RPO) requirements for disaster recovery across regions, the DevOps Engineer needs to take the following steps:

    1. Store the CloudFormation templates in an S3 bucket located in the Disaster Recovery (DR) region. This ensures that the templates are available for deployment in case of any need. The templates can be imported into CloudFormation from S3.
    2. Enable Aurora automated backups and cross-region replication to meet the RPO of 7 hours by replicating database changes to the DR region.
    3. Configure ECR cross-region replication to keep container images synchronized across regions. This allows for the quick deployment of updated applications after a failover.
    4. In case of a disaster recovery event, a new CloudFormation stack can be deployed in the DR region using the latest Aurora snapshot and ECR images. This would bring up an identical environment matching the source within the 1 hour RTO goal.
    5. Finally, redirect the DNS to the new ALB to route traffic to the recovered application with minimal customer impact.

    This approach leverages many native AWS disaster recovery capabilities like Aurora replication, ECR replication, and CloudFormation to provide an automated yet cost-effective solution meeting the recovery objectives.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Store a copy of the CloudFormation templates in an S3 bucket in the DR region. Enable Aurora’s automated backup with Cross-Region Replication and set up ECR Cross-Region Replication. During a DR event, deploy a new CloudFormation stack using the latest Aurora snapshot and Docker image from ECR. Update DNS to point to the new ALB.

    The option that says: Store a copy of the CloudFormation templates and Dockerfiles in an S3 bucket in the DR region. Configure AWS Backup for hourly Aurora cross-region snapshots. In a DR event, build the latest Docker image, upload to an ECR in the DR region, and launch a new CloudFormation stack using the latest Aurora snapshot and the Docker image. Update DNS to the new ALB.  is incorrect. Storing the CloudFormation Template and Dockerfile in an S3 bucket within the Disaster Recovery region is a good practice. Configuring Aurora to take cross-region snapshots every hour via AWS Backup aligns with the Recovery Point Objective of 7 hours. However, building a new Docker image from the Dockerfile takes over an hour, which undermines the ability to meet the Recovery Time Objective of 1 hour, potentially extending the recovery time beyond the acceptable limit.

    The option that says: Store a copy of the CloudFormation templates in an S3 bucket in the DR region. Use EventBridge to trigger a Lambda function to automate hourly snapshots of the Aurora database and the Docker image in the ECR repository. In a DR event, use these snapshots and images to launch a new CloudFormation stack is incorrect. It introduces a complex orchestration involving AWS EventBridge and AWS Lambda to automate the creation of hourly snapshots of both Aurora databases and Docker images. While this approach aims to automate and ensure regular data backup, it depends heavily on the precise functioning of event triggers and Lambda functions, which could introduce additional points of failure or delays. Moreover, the manual task of copying these snapshots and images to the DR region adds further complexity and potential delays. This combination of automated triggers and manual intervention creates a brittle setup prone to delays, risking the breach of the stipulated 1-hour RTO due to potential operational hiccups and the inherently slow and error-prone nature of manual processes.

    The option that says: Store a copy of the CloudFormation templates in an S3 bucket in the DR region. Use AWS DataSync to synchronize Docker images, and Aurora snapshots hourly to a backup ECR and RDS in the DR region. In a DR situation, deploy a new CloudFormation stack using these resources. Update DNS to the new ALB is incorrect. AWS DataSync isn’t capable of synchronizing changes directly between two Amazon Elastic Container Registry (ECR) repositories and RDS snapshots across multiple regions.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/whitepapers/latest/disaster-recovery-of-on-premises-applications-to-aws/recovery-objectives.html

    https://disaster-recovery.workshop.aws/en/services/containers/ecr/ecr.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/Welcome.html

     

    Check out the following Cheat Sheets:

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/amazon-aurora/

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-well-architected-framework-disaster-recovery/

  53. Question 53 of 74
    53. Question

    A startup wants to run integration tests in AWS for their monolith backend, starting with tests against its database. They need to implement a process where the service is tested against a snapshot of the production database to ensure compatibility between changes in the database schema and changes in application code. The tests should be run only for changes that have passed rudimentary source checks (e.g., linting and static type checking) and unit tests. The pipeline must also use a single database instance for all build executions. Also, executions must be allowed to finish even as newer inbound executions arrive.

    Which combination of steps would achieve the required solution? (Select TWO.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS CodePipeline is a continuous delivery service for modeling, visualizing, and automating the steps required to release your software.

    The building blocks of CodePipeline are pipelines, stages, and actions. Pipelines are workflows that describe how software changes go through a release process. Each pipeline is made up of a series of stages. Stages, on the other hand, are logical groups of actions that can be mapped roughly to environments and are used to limit concurrent changes in that environment.

     In this scenario, the integration tests are run using a test action and served by a CodeBuild project. CodeBuild handles the environment where the database is set up. If the pipeline execution mode were to be set to PARALLEL, multiple executions would be able to use the database concurrently, possibly leading to data corruption and flaky tests. In order for a pipeline stage to be locked to a single execution, the pipeline execution mode must be set to either QUEUED or SUPERSEDED. However, since there is also a requirement to allow executions to finish even in the face of incoming executions, the execution mode must be set to QUEUED.

    Therefore, the correct steps include:

    – Create a CodeBuild project to run the integration tests. Set up a Test-type action in the CodePipeline pipeline using the created CodeBuild project.
    – Set CodePipeline execution mode to QUEUED.

    The option that says: Set CodePipeline execution mode to SUPERSEDED is incorrect. This is already the default execution mode for CodePipeline pipelines. Also, this is not the mode to use if the desired behavior is to run an execution to completion, even if a newer one is incoming.

    The option that says: Create a separate CodePipeline stage for integration tests in CodeBuild is incorrect. It is technically possible but unnecessary as there is no requirement that warrants a separate environment and, thus, a CodePipeline stage.

    The option that says: Set up an SQS queue and a Lambda function between the repository and the CodePipeline pipeline to serialize the use of the database is incorrect. This is unnecessary as the stage is locked to the current execution. At least in SUPERSEDED and QUEUED execution modes, two pipeline executions can’t occupy the same stage at the same time, and since the pipeline has only one (implicit) stage, there is only one execution running and using the database at any given time.

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codepipeline/latest/userguide/welcome.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codepipeline/latest/userguide/actions-variables.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codepipeline/latest/userguide/concepts.html#concepts-stages

     

    Check out these AWS CodePipeline and AWS CodeBuild Cheat Sheets:

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-codepipeline/

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-codebuild/

    54. Question

    A bank uses an EC2 instance to host its web application which mainly serves the purpose of storing sensitive information in an S3 bucket. The security team mandated that all objects in the bucket be duplicated and stored in a separate bucket located in a different AWS account and region.

    Which of the following actions should the DevOps Engineer implement to enable cross-region replication? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    When you configure replication, you add replication rules to the source bucket. Replication rules define which source bucket objects to replicate and the destination bucket or buckets where the replicated objects are stored. A destination bucket can be in the same AWS account as the source bucket, or it can be in a different account.

    Replication requires the following:

    -The source bucket owner must have the source, and destination AWS Regions enabled for their account. The destination bucket owner must have the destination Region enabled for their account.

    -Both source and destination buckets must have versioning enabled.

    -Amazon S3 must have permission to replicate objects from the source bucket to the destination bucket or buckets on your behalf.

    -If the owner of the source bucket doesn’t own the object in the bucket, the object owner must grant the bucket owner READ and READ_ACP permissions with the object access control list (ACL).

    -If the source bucket has S3 Object Lock enabled, the destination buckets must also have S3 Object Lock enabled.

    -Set up an AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that Amazon S3 can assume to replicate objects on your behalf.

    Setting up replication when source and destination buckets are owned by different AWS accounts is similar to setting replication when both buckets are owned by the same account. The only difference is that the destination bucket owner must grant the source bucket owner permission to replicate objects by adding a bucket policy.

    Add the following bucket policy on the destination bucket to allow the owner of the source bucket to replicate objects. Be sure to edit the policy by providing the AWS account ID of the source bucket owner and the destination bucket name.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – In the source AWS account, create an IAM role that Amazon S3 can assume to replicate objects. Enable versioning in both buckets.

    – Create a bucket policy in the destination bucket that grants the source bucket permission to replicate objects.

    – Configure a replication rule within the source bucket to activate the replication process.

    The option that says: In the destination AWS account, create an IAM role that Amazon S3 can assume to replicate objects. Enable versioning in both buckets is incorrect because the IAM role must be created in the AWS account with the source bucket.

    The option that says: Create a bucket policy in the source bucket that grants the destination bucket permission to replicate objects is incorrect because the bucket policy should be attached to the destination bucket instead. Furthermore, the bucket policy must grant the source bucket permission to replicate objects in the destination bucket.

    The option that says: Configure a replication rule within the destination bucket to activate the replication process is incorrect because the replication rule must be created in the source bucket.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/replication.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/replication-walkthrough1.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/replication-walkthrough-2.html

  55. Question 55 of 74
    55. Question

    A DevOps Engineer has implemented an AWS CloudFormation stack to orchestrate a continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipeline for a complex web application. The Engineer has also written an AWS Lambda function that triggers drift detection for all supported resources in the CloudFormation stack and terminates the process.

    In the AWS account, an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic has been previously configured. Notifications from this SNS topic are being actively received by the engineer. Additionally, the Engineer has set up an Amazon EventBridge scheduled rule. This rule is designed to activate the Lambda function at 15-minute intervals.

    The Engineer is required to be notified immediately when a drift is detected in the CI/CD pipeline configuration.

    Which of the following solutions will fulfill these requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Config is a service that enables you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. The cloudformation-stack-drift-detection-check managed rule in AWS Config continuously monitors the CloudFormation stack for drift. Drift in AWS CloudFormation refers to the difference between the expected configuration of a resource defined in CloudFormation and the actual configuration of that resource in AWS.

    Amazon EventBridge is a serverless event bus service that makes it easy to connect applications together using data from your applications, integrated Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) applications, and AWS services. In this case, an additional EventBridge rule is established that activates upon detecting a compliance change event concerning the CloudFormation stack. This ensures that the process is immediate and the Engineer is notified as soon as a drift is detected.

    Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) is a web service that coordinates and manages the delivery or sending of messages to subscribing endpoints or clients. In this scenario, the existing Amazon SNS topic is set as the target for the new EventBridge rule. This means that when the EventBridge rule is triggered (i.e., when a drift is detected), a message is published to the SNS topic, which then sends a notification to the Engineer.

    AWS Config continuously monitors the CloudFormation stack for drifts. A drift occurs when a resource’s actual configuration deviates from its expected configuration. When such a drift is detected, AWS Config triggers a compliance change event. This event is then picked up by Amazon EventBridge, which acts as the central hub for your system’s events. The EventBridge rule, specifically set up for compliance change events, gets activated and takes the next action in the workflow. The action defined in the EventBridge rule is to send a message to an Amazon SNS topic. Amazon SNS is a messaging service that handles the delivery of messages to subscribing endpoints. In this case, the endpoint is the Engineer who needs to be notified about the drift.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Set up an AWS Config and employ the cloudformation-stack-drift-detection-check managed rule to oversee the CloudFormation stack. Establish an additional EventBridge rule that activates upon detecting a compliance change event concerning the CloudFormation stack. Direct this new EventBridge rule to notify the existing Amazon SNS topic as its action.

    The option that says: Use the DetectStackResourceDrift API operation to trigger the drift detection process for each individual resource in the CloudFormation stack. Then, configure the AWS Lambda function to send a notification to the Amazon SNS topic when a drift is detected. Modify the Amazon EventBridge rule to trigger the Lambda function is incorrect because while the DetectStackDrift API operation can trigger the drift detection process, it does not provide real-time notifications. The process of configuring the AWS Lambda function to send a notification to the Amazon SNS topic when a drift is detected is not immediate and does not fulfill the requirement of the Engineer being notified immediately when a drift is detected.

    The option that says: Set up a CloudWatch alarm that triggers when drift is detected in the CloudFormation stack. Configure the alarm to send a notification to the SNS topic. Modify the Amazon EventBridge rule to trigger the Lambda function is incorrect because CloudWatch alarms do not natively support CloudFormation stack drift detection.

    The option that says: Use Amazon Inspector to check for drift in the CloudFormation stack. Configure Inspector to send a notification to the SNS topic when drift is detected. Modify the Amazon EventBridge rule to trigger the Lambda function is incorrect because Amazon Inspector is used for security vulnerability assessments and not for detecting configuration drifts in AWS CloudFormation stacks.

    56. Question

    A local animation film production company stores its video animations in multiple Amazon S3 buckets. A DevOps Engineer was instructed to set up a monitoring system that will notify the IT Operations team if there are any existing or new buckets that have public read or public write access. The Security Team will verify if the detected S3 buckets are indeed intended to be accessed publicly or not.

    Which of the following is the MOST suitable solution that you can do in order to meet this requirement with the LEAST amount of effort?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    The s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited are AWS Config managed rules that check if your Amazon S3 buckets do not allow public read access and write access. These rules check the Block Public Access settings, the bucket policy, and the bucket access control list (ACL).

    The rule is compliant when both of the following are true:

    1. The Block Public Access setting restricts public policies or the bucket policy does not allow public read/write access.

    2. The Block Public Access setting restricts public ACLs or the bucket ACL does not allow public read/write access.

    The rule is non-compliant when:

    1. The Block Public Access setting does not restrict public policies, AWS Config evaluates whether the policy allows public read/write access. If the policy allows public read/write access, the rule is noncompliant.

    2. If the Block Public Access setting does not restrict public bucket ACLs, AWS Config evaluates whether the bucket ACL allows public read/write access. If the bucket ACL allows public read/write access, the rule is noncompliant.

    Since they are managed rules, we can simply use them on the fly. Without these rules, we would need to implement our own custom-managed rule using a Lambda function. The next step would be to configure a CloudWatch Events rule that watches for AWS Config events whenever it detects a non-compliant S3 bucket. Finally, we specify an SNS topic as a trigger for CloudWatch events to send alerts to the team.

    Hence, the correct answer is Create s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed rules in AWS Config. Configure a CloudWatch Events rule that sends a notification to an SNS topic when AWS Config detects an S3 bucket ACL or policy violation. 

    The option that says: Develop a script that queries the settings of all buckets using the S3 API. Upload the script in a new AWS Lambda function and integrate it with CloudWatch Events in order to run it on a daily basis. Configure the script to ensure that the Amazon S3 Block Public Access option is always enabled in all of the S3 buckets. Send an email notification to the IT Operations team for all publicly accessible buckets using Amazon SNS is incorrect because it entails a lot of effort to develop a custom script. A better solution is to use AWS Config instead.

    The option that says: Consolidate all of the company’s AWS accounts using AWS Organizations. Create a Service Control Policy that will restrict all users from uploading public objects to any S3 bucket. Launch a Lambda function to detect if there is an attempt made by a user to upload a public object. Create an Amazon SNS topic that will notify the IT Operations team is incorrect because a service control policy (SCP) simply determines what services and actions can be delegated by administrators to the users and roles in the accounts that the SCP is applied to. In addition, setting up AWS Organizations and SCPs are not suitable in this scenario since they do not provide proper compliance monitoring as required in the scenario. The best solution here is to use AWS Config.

    The option that says: Create a Lambda function that sends a notification to SNS topic whenever it detects the PutBucketAcl API event in CloudTrail is incorrect. CloudTrail will record this API event if the ACL of an existing bucket has been modified. But this is not enough to tell whether the bucket is compliant or not.

    A company is transitioning its open-source-centric business model to a licensing-centric one. A DevOps specialist is tasked with migrating the repository, along with the entire commit history of one of its applications, from an existing Git repository to AWS CodeCommit.

    Which combination of steps would achieve this securely? (Select THREE.)

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS CodeCommit is a version control service hosted by Amazon Web Services that can be used to privately store and manage assets (such as documents, source code, and binary files) in the cloud.
    In relation to the scenario, the necessary steps to migrate an existing repository to CodeCommit include:

    – Complete the initial setup required for CodeCommit.

    – Create a CodeCommit repository.

    – Clone the repository and push it to CodeCommit.

    On the point of using an IAM role vs. an IAM user for migrating, IAM roles allow specific permissions to be defined for the task at hand without granting unnecessary access. Unlike users, roles can be assumed by entities such as AWS services or by users themselves, granting temporary permissions to perform specific actions. This is useful for one-time tasks like repository migration, as permissions can be granted only for the duration of the migration process.

    Therefore, the correct set of options are:

    – Create an IAM role for CodeCommit. Assign appropriate (managed) policies to the IAM role. Configure a local machine to assume the newly created role temporarily.
     – Create a CodeCommit repository.
    – Clone the existing repository to the local machine with the--mirror flag. Push to the newly created CodeCommit repository.

    The option that says: Create an IAM user for CodeCommit. Configure a local machine for access is incorrect.     The option that says: Configure the CodeCommit repository to block contributions from the public is incorrect. CodeCommit is a private repository by default.

    The option that says: Clone the existing repository to the local machine with the -depth=1 flag. Create a new branch. Push the branch to the newly created CodeCommit repository is incorrect. the-depth=1 flag performs a shallow clone, which only includes the latest commit and lacks the complete commit history and tags. This approach does not meet the requirement to transfer the entire commit history.

  58. Question 58 of 74
    58. Question

    A company has a food delivery application that uses AWS Lambda, Amazon SQS, and Amazon DynamoDB. Orders are initially placed in an SQS queue, then processed by a Lambda function with reserved concurrency. The processed orders are saved into a DynamoDB table with Auto Scaling enabled for read and write capacity. The company is receiving feedback from customers saying that they’re facing a delay issue in displaying the order status from their order history page.

    How can the issue be possibly identified and fixed?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Concurrency is the number of requests that your function is serving at any given time. When your function is invoked, Lambda allocates an instance of it to process the event. When the function code finishes running, it can handle another request. If the function is invoked again while a request is still being processed, another instance is allocated, which increases the function’s concurrency. Reserved concurrency creates a pool of requests that can only be used by its function, and also prevents its function from using unreserved concurrency.

    The ApproximateAgeOfOldestMessage measures the number of seconds since the creation of the oldest message in the queue. This SQS metric is effective because if it goes up, it means that messages are not being processed quickly enough. It can also show you the messages that your consumers can’t handle and are stuck in your queue.

    WriteThrottleEvents are requests to DynamoDB that exceed the provisioned write capacity units for a table or a global secondary index.

    In this scenario, the ApproximateAgeOfOldestMessage and the WriteThrottleEvents metrics will give you insight into which requests (orders) are experiencing delays. The ApproximateAgeOfOldestMessage metric can give you an idea that the reserved concurrency of the Lambda function is not enough to handle the volume of the orders which causes the delay. Another possible fix is to increase the write capacity of the DynamoDB table. If the orders are not saved to the database then processed orders won’t show up to the application. You can check the WriteThrottleEvents metrics in DynamoDB and see if there are requests being throttled. If you’ve confirmed that the allotted write capacity isn’t enough then you can allocate a higher write capacity.

    Hence, the correct answer is the option that says: Go to the AWS CloudWatch Logs to check for the ApproximateAgeOfOldestMessage SQS metric and WriteThrottleEvents DynamoDB metric. Increase the reserved concurrency of the Lambda function and the maximum write capacity units of the DynamoDB table.

    The option that says: Go to the AWS CloudWatch Logs to check for the Throttles SQS metric and WriteThrottleEvents DynamoDB metric. Set a redrive policy on the SQS queue and increase the DynamoDB table’s maximum write capacity units. is incorrect. The redrive policy just specifies how failed messages from a source queue are moved to a dead letter queue. This won’t really solve the issue.

    The option that says: Go to the AWS CloudWatch Logs to check for the NumberOfMessagesSent SQS metric and WriteThrottleEvents DynamoDB metric. Increase the SQS visibility timeout and the DynamoDB table’s maximum write capacity units is incorrect. The visibility timeout just prevents consumers (AWS Lambda) from processing the same order within a given period of time. This will not help in resolving the delay.

    The option that says: Go to the AWS CloudWatch Logs to check for the ApproximateAgeOfOldestMessage SQS metric and WriteThrottleEvents DynamoDB metric. Increase the Lambda function’s execution timeout and the maximum write capacity units of the DynamoDB table is incorrect. The Lambda function’s execution timeout limit just defines how long a Lambda function can process an order before it stops running. This won’t likely solve the issue. Based on the scenario, the issue is just about a delay and not a failed order — it means that the orders are processed successfully at the Lambda function but the processed orders are somewhat being impeded when they’re written to the DynamoDB table level.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSSimpleQueueService/latest/SQSDeveloperGuide/sqs-available-cloudwatch-metrics.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/amazondynamodb/latest/developerguide/metrics-dimensions.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/configuration-concurrency.html

    59. Question

    A media company runs a video streaming app that allows users to upload and watch videos. The videos are stored in an Amazon S3 bucket in the us-east-1 Region. The DevOps team has been tasked with setting up a secondary deployment of the app in the us-west-2 Region to ensure high availability and disaster recovery. The requirements include keeping the data consistent between the S3 buckets in both Regions and enabling failover between the Regions without data loss.

    Which of the following options will meet these requirements with the MOST operational efficiency?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR) is an Amazon S3 feature that automatically replicates data between buckets across different AWS Regions. With CRR, you can set up replication at a bucket level, a shared prefix level, or an object level using S3 object tags. CRR can be used to enable faster data access in different geographic regions or to meet compliance requirements for storing copies of data hundreds of miles apart. Additionally, CRR can also be used to change account ownership for the replicated objects to protect data from accidental deletion.

    Amazon S3 Batch Replication is a feature in Amazon S3 that allows you to replicate a large number of objects in a single operation. This can be useful when you need to replicate a large dataset or migrate data between S3 buckets. To use Batch Replication, you need to create an IAM role with the necessary permissions, and the job must be initiated from the same AWS Region as the replication source bucket.

    AWS offers S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR) as a fully managed service that automatically replicates objects across S3 buckets in different Regions, ensuring data consistency. With bidirectional replication, changes made to objects in either bucket are automatically replicated to the other, maintaining data consistency between the Regions. Additionally, S3 Batch Replication is designed for the initial replication of existing objects from a source bucket to a destination bucket, making it efficient for setting up CRR for the first time or migrating data between buckets. Lastly, AWS recommends using an IAM role with the necessary permissions for CRR and S3 Batch Replication operations to ensure the replication process has the required access and follows the principle of least privilege.

    Leveraging these AWS-managed services and features enables the media company to achieve data consistency and enable failover between Regions without data loss in a highly operationally efficient manner, as the replication process is automated and managed by AWS, reducing the need for custom scripts or periodic synchronization processes which can be more complex and error-prone.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Create a bidirectional S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR) configuration between the source S3 bucket in us-east-1 and the destination S3 bucket in us-west-2. Perform an initial replication of existing objects from the source bucket to the destination bucket using S3 Batch Replication. Use an IAM role with permissions for S3 replication and S3 Batch Operations.

    The option that says: Use AWS DataSync to periodically synchronize the contents of the source S3 bucket in us-east-1 with the destination S3 bucket in us-west-2, and vice versa, creating a two-way synchronization process is incorrect. While DataSync can synchronize data between S3 buckets, it requires periodic scheduling and may not provide real-time data consistency. Additionally, it introduces an additional service and potential operational overhead.

    The option that says: Use AWS Lambda functions triggered by S3 object creation or modification events, copying objects between the source S3 bucket in us-east-1 and the destination S3 bucket in us-west-2 is incorrect because this approach would require custom development and maintenance of Lambda functions to handle object creation and modification events, introducing complexity and potential points of failure. It may also incur additional costs for Lambda execution.

    The option that says: Use AWS Backup to create scheduled backups of the source S3 bucket in us-east-1 and restore them to the destination S3 bucket in us-west-2, ensuring data consistency through periodic backups and restores is incorrect. While AWS Backup can create scheduled backups and restores, it is primarily designed for backup and recovery purposes, not for maintaining real-time data consistency between Regions. This approach would not provide the desired level of data consistency and failover capabilities required by the media company.

  60. Question 60 of 74
    60. Question

    A multinational corporation is implementing AWS services across multiple departments, each with distinct operational needs and security measures. The corporation uses AWS Organizations to manage its AWS accounts centrally.

    The DevOps team must implement preventive and detective controls to manage the security and governance of all accounts, including both existing and new accounts in the future.

    Which approach will best allow the DevOps to achieve these requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Control Tower is a service that simplifies the setup and management of multi-account AWS environments, securely following AWS best practices.

    Landing Zone: When you set up a landing zone in AWS Control Tower, it creates multiple managed resources in your management account for the accounts in the landing zone. This includes setting up AWS Organizations, AWS IAM Identity Center, and other core services to establish a well-architected, multi-account environment.

    Controls (Guardrails): AWS Control Tower provides a set of pre-defined controls, also known as guardrails, that help govern your AWS environment. These controls can be preventive, detective, or proactive:

    – Preventive controls establish intent and prevent the deployment of non-compliant resources.

    – Detective controls continuously monitor deployed resources for non-conformance.

    – Proactive controls use AWS CloudFormation Hooks to proactively identify and block the deployment of non-compliant resources.

    AWS Organizations is a service that allows you to centrally manage and govern your environment as you grow and scale your AWS resources. It enables you to create groups of accounts, automate account creation, apply policies to those groups, and simplify billing by using a single payment method for all of your accounts.

    AWS SCP (Service Control Policies) is a feature offered by AWS Organizations that enables you to manage policies centrally. These policies help you control the maximum permissible permissions for all accounts within your organization. SCPs allow you to impose restrictions on the AWS resources, services, and individual API actions that users and roles can access in each account.

    An organizational unit (OU) in AWS is a group of AWS accounts within an AWS organization. OUs provide a way to organize accounts hierarchically, enabling you to apply policies and controls to a subset of accounts in your organization.

    By deploying Control Tower, the corporation establishes a landing zone, which includes a baseline environment with predefined OUs for different security and operational needs, SCPs for policy enforcement, and automated workflows for ongoing account provisioning and management. This approach addresses both preventive measures (through SCPs) and detective measures (through the governance mechanisms provided by Control Tower), ensuring that all current and future accounts are managed consistently and in compliance with the company’s policies.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Deploy AWS Control Tower to establish a landing zone that includes predefined Organizational Units (OUs) with attached Service Control Policies (SCPs) tailored to each department’s needs. Automatically apply these controls to existing accounts by enrolling them in the appropriate OUs, and set up Control Tower to handle new account provisioning automatically.

    The option that says: Configure AWS Config across all accounts to implement uniform security controls and rules, utilizing AWS CloudTrail for monitoring and AWS Lambda for automated remediation actions is incorrect. While AWS Config, combined with AWS CloudTrail and AWS Lambda, provides a powerful suite of tools for configuration compliance, monitoring, and automated remediation, it does not inherently manage account structures or enforce initial security postures at the account creation level. This setup would require significant manual configuration and ongoing management to ensure alignment with the company’s varied department needs and is, therefore, less optimal for initial setup and preventive controls compared to Control Tower.

    The option that says: Configure Organizations to group department accounts under separate Organizational Units (OUs), applying Service Control Policies (SCPs) to each OU to enforce security policies. Manually set up each new department account within the Organizations structure is incorrect. This approach typically involves labor-intensive setup processes for each new account, prone to human error and not scalable as organizational needs grow. Moreover, it lacks the comprehensive governance framework provided by AWS Control Tower, which offers predefined best practices and compliance controls from the outset. AWS Control Tower makes a more efficient choice for establishing a well-architected environment, ensuring consistent security and governance across all accounts without the drawbacks of manual configuration.

    The option that says: Use AWS Firewall Manager to centrally configure and manage firewall rules across all department accounts. Apply security policies consistently and automatically enforce new policies as accounts are added is incorrect. AWS Firewall Manager is primarily used for managing firewall rules across multiple AWS accounts and resources, particularly for organizations using AWS WAF and AWS Shield. However, it is not suitable for general account management, nor does it handle the broad scope of security and governance needs, such as SCPs and organizational compliance, that Control Tower addresses. Firewall Manager’s focus is more on network security, not on overall account management and governance.

  61. Question 61 of 74
    61. Question

    A multi-tier enterprise web application is hosted in an Auto Scaling group of On-Demand Amazon EC2 instances across multiple Availability Zones behind an Application Load Balancer. For its database tier, Amazon Aurora is used in storing thousands of transactions and user data. A DevOps Engineer was instructed to implement a secure and manageable method in obtaining the database password credentials as well as providing access to AWS resources during deployment.

    Which among the following options is the MOST suitable setup that the Engineer should use?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Secrets Manager is an AWS service that makes it easier for you to manage secrets. Secrets can be database credentials, passwords, third-party API keys, and even arbitrary text. You can store and control access to these secrets centrally by using the Secrets Manager console, the Secrets Manager command line interface (CLI), or the Secrets Manager API and SDKs.

    In the past, when you created a custom application that retrieves information from a database, you typically had to embed the credentials (the secret) for accessing the database directly in the application. When the time came to rotate the credentials, you had to do much more than just create new credentials. You had to invest time to update the application to use the new credentials. Then you had to distribute the updated application. If you had multiple applications with shared credentials and you missed updating one of them, the application would break. Because of this risk, many customers have chosen not to regularly rotate their credentials, which effectively substitutes one risk for another.

    Secrets Manager enables you to replace hardcoded credentials in your code (including passwords), with an API call to Secrets Manager to retrieve the secret programmatically. This helps ensure that the secret can’t be compromised by someone examining your code, because the secret simply isn’t there. Also, you can configure Secrets Manager to automatically rotate the secret for you according to a specified schedule. This enables you to replace long-term secrets with short-term ones, which significantly reduces the risk of compromise.

    An IAM role is an IAM identity that you can create in your account that has specific permissions. An IAM role is similar to an IAM user, in that it is an AWS identity with permission policies that determine what the identity can and cannot do in AWS. However, instead of being uniquely associated with one person, a role is intended to be assumable by anyone who needs it. Also, a role does not have standard long-term credentials such as a password or access keys associated with it. Instead, when you assume a role, it provides you with temporary security credentials for your role session.

    You can use roles to delegate access to users, applications, or services that don’t normally have access to your AWS resources. For example, you might want to grant users in your AWS account access to resources they don’t usually have, or grant users in one AWS account access to resources in another account. Or you might want to allow a mobile app to use AWS resources, but not want to embed AWS keys within the app (where they can be difficult to rotate and where users can potentially extract them). Sometimes you want to give AWS access to users who already have identities defined outside of AWS, such as in your corporate directory. Or, you might want to grant access to your account to third parties so that they can perform an audit on your resources.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Store the sensitive database credentials from AWS Secrets Manager. Create an IAM role for your EC2 instances that allows access to other AWS services. Configure your instances to use the IAM Role and retrieve the credentials from the AWS Secrets Manager.

    The option that says:Store the sensitive database credentials and access keys from AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store as SecureString parameters. Configure your instances to retrieve the credentials and access keys from the Parameter Store is incorrect because you should use an IAM role instead of directly using access keys. AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store is primarily used to store passwords, database strings, and license codes as parameter values.

    The option that says: Using the AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store service, store the sensitive database credentials as SecureString parameters and the access keys as plaintext parameters. Configure your instances to retrieve the credentials and access keys from the Parameter Store is incorrect. Although it is valid to store the database credentials to AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store, you still need to use an IAM Role to allow EC2 instances to access your AWS resources and not by using access keys.

    The option that says: Create an IAM role for your EC2 instances that allows access to other AWS services. Configure your instances to use the IAM Role and store the database credentials in an encrypted configuration file in an Amazon S3 bucket with SSE is incorrect because it is not appropriate to store sensitive database credentials to S3 even if it is using Server Side Encryption. You should use either AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or AWS Secrets Manager to store the credentials.
