    62. Question

    A Philippine-based startup is presently operating its e-commerce web application on AWS in a single region. The application runs on Amazon EC2 instances in an Auto Scaling group that spans multiple Availability Zones and is placed behind an Application Load Balancer. The startup relies on an Amazon Aurora database instance to store its data. In response to increased demand, the startup has decided to expand its operations to the United States and, therefore, needs to deploy the application to a closer AWS region. Due to compliance regulations, the startup must adhere to the following deployment requirements:

    • Utilize a single product catalog throughout all AWS regions.

    • Maintain transaction records in their respective regions.

    Which of the following will fulfill the requirements with the LEAST amount of changes to the e-commerce application?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon Aurora provides built-in security, continuous backups, serverless compute, up to 15 read replicas, automated multi-Region replication, and integrations with other AWS services.

    Read Replicas provide enhanced performance and durability for Amazon RDS database (DB) instances. They make it easy to elastically scale out beyond the capacity constraints of a single DB instance for read-heavy database workloads. You can create one or more replicas of a given source DB Instance and serve high-volume application read traffic from multiple copies of your data, thereby increasing aggregate read throughput. Read replicas can also be promoted when needed to become standalone DB instances.

    In this scenario, using the same Amazon Aurora database engine is the LEAST application change, and deploying additional Aurora instances in each respective region ensures the transaction records are kept in the local region, which meets the requirement.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Leverage Amazon Aurora with read replicas for the product catalog. Deploy additional Aurora instances at a local level in every region to handle transaction records.

    The option that says: Leverage Amazon Aurora for the product catalog. Deploy an Amazon DynamoDB global table to handle transaction records is incorrect because using Amazon DynamoDB global table will fail the requirement to maintain transaction records in their respective regions as DynamoDB global tables will replicate transaction records between regions. Additionally, changing the database to DynamoDB will entail major application changes, which is contrary to the requirement of the LEAST application changes.

    The following options are incorrect because switching to DynamoDB or DocumentDB would necessitate significant modifications to the application. It does not meet the requirement of the LEAST application change.

    – Create an Amazon DynamoDB global table to handle the product catalog, and set up regional tables to manage transaction records

    – Create an Amazon DocumentDB to handle the product catalog and set up Amazon DynamoDB tables to manage transaction records in each respective region

    63. Question

    Your development team uploads a new version of the company’s web store app on Amazon ECR. To simplify tracking of versions, they tag the latest image as “store-prd:latest”. You are automating the deployment of the new version using AWS CLI command so that the new image will be pulled from ECR and deployed on your ECS Fargate cluster. However, the latest image is not being deployed when you run the following aws cli command:

    Which of the following options will solve this problem?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    You can update a running service to change the number of tasks that are maintained by a service, and which task definition is used by the tasks, or if your tasks are using the Fargate launch type, you can change the platform version your service uses. If you have an application that needs more capacity, you can scale up your service. If you have the unused capacity to scale down, you can reduce the number of desired tasks in your service and free up resources.

    If your updated Docker image uses the same tag as what is in the existing task definition for your service (for example, my_image:latest), you do not need to create a new revision of your task definition. You can update your service with your custom configuration, keep the current settings for your service, and select Force new deployment. The new tasks launched by the deployment pull the current image/tag combination from your repository when they start. The Force new deployment option is also used when updating a Fargate task to use a more current platform version when you specify LATEST. For example, if you specified LATEST and your running tasks are using the 1.0.0 platform version, and you want them to relaunch using a newer platform version.

    By default, deployments are not forced but you can use the forceNewDeployment request parameter (or the –force-new-deployment parameter if you are using the AWS CLI) to force a new deployment of the service. You can use this option to trigger a new deployment with no service definition changes. For example, you can update a service’s tasks to use a newer Docker image with the same image/tag combination (my_image:latest) or to roll Fargate tasks onto a newer platform version.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Add --force-new-deployment option to the AWS CLI command so that ECS re-deploys your cluster pulling the new image.

Although modifying the task definition will cause a new version to be deployed, no further deployments will be made by ECS since the ARN or the image revision remain unchanged.

    The option that says: Add --platform-version=latest option to your AWS CLI command so that ECS re-deploys the cluster pulling the new image is incorrect because this option is primarily used to specify the Fargate platform that will be used by ECS and not the image version you want to deploy.

    64. Question

    An organization has a hybrid infrastructure across various AWS regions and its own data centers, which includes Amazon EC2 instances, AWS IoT Greengrass devices, and on-premises servers. A cloud consultant is tasked with streamlining resource management and ensuring devices are secured with the latest patches. The goal is to automate patch management and have regular scheduled maintenance to keep software current.

    The organization has ensured that AWS Systems Manager is available in all AWS regions hosting their resources and in the region nearest to their data centers.

    What are the steps to meet this operational management need? (Select TWO.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Systems Manager is a service that provides a secure end-to-end management solution for hybrid and multi-cloud environments enabling operations at scale. It serves as a central operations hub to logically group resources and perform automated tasks with complete visibility and control.

    At re:Invent 2021, AWS released integration between AWS Systems Manager and AWS IoT Greengrass, simplifying the management and maintenance of system software for edge devices. AWS Systems Manager allows secure management of devices, including OS patching and application deployment.

    In AWS Systems Manager, you can create an activation to allow on-premises servers (managed instances) to communicate with AWS services. This provides an Activation Code and an Activation ID. These codes act as credentials for your managed instances to communicate securely with AWS. Setting this up allows for a secure communication of the AWS Systems Manager and the device, enabling different tasks to be performed, including applying patches and installing software.

    AWS Systems Manager uses IAM to securely access resources that it needs to manage. For EC2 instances within AWS, an instance profile needs to be specified during the instance launch. The instance profile will have the attached IAM role that allows AWS System Manager permissions to manage the instances. For IoT Greengrass devices and on-premises servers, an IAM service role that is configured with a trusted entity resource has to be set up. The role can be used by Greengrass devices or on-premises servers for communication with AWS services such as AWS Systems Manager. In addition to the service role that authorizes service-level access, a token exchange role should be assigned to Greengrass core devices. The token exchange role is a separate IAM role that controls how Greengrass components can access AWS services.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – Set up an IAM instance profile for a custom IAM role with Systems Manager as a Trusted Entity. Attach this instance profile to all EC2 instances that will be managed. Use Systems Manager Patch Manager to schedule patching of the EC2 instances.

    – Generate an activation code and ID in Systems Manager or via the AWS Command Line Interface (CLI). Set up an IAM service role with appropriate permissions and policies to allow Systems Manager to interact with the IoT Greengrass devices and on-premises servers. Assign a token exchange role to Greengrass core devices. Initiate token exchange and establish a secure connection by installing the Systems Manager Agent (SSM Agent) on the on-premises servers and IoT Greengrass devices. Use Systems Manager Patch Manager to schedule patching of the on-premises servers and the IoT Greengrass devices.

    The option that says: Create an IAM policy defining permission for Systems Manager Session Manager. Attach the policy to an IAM role which includes ssm.amazonaws.com as a trusted entity. Associate the IAM role to the IoT Greengrass devices and on-premises servers to allow Session Manager to push scheduled patches to the devices is incorrect. Systems Manager Session Manager is primarily used for interactive shell access to EC2 instances and not for handling patch management. Although it can be used to run commands on managed instances, it’s not the recommended tool for scheduling regular patching tasks.

    The option that says: Create a custom IAM policy defining permissions to Systems Manager Run Command. Attach the policy to an IAM role which includes ssm.amazonaws.com as a trusted entity. Associate the IAM role to the EC2 instances. Use Systems Manager Run Command to use the IAM role to run scheduled patching commands to the EC2 instances is incorrect. While Systems Manager Run Command can be used to execute commands or scripts at scale, it does not have a scheduling capability and would require the setup of additional AWS services like EventBridge. It is also not the recommended tool for scheduling regular patching tasks.

    The option that says: Create a custom state configuration with AWS Systems Manager State Manager. Associate the state configuration with the EC2 instances, IoT devices, and the on-premises servers. State Manager will continuously monitor the state of the resources and apply the latest patches when available is incorrect. State Manager is mainly used to improve the management and governance of AWS resources and reduce configuration drift. It does not provide capabilities to schedule and automate patch management.

  65. Question 65 of 74
    65. Question

    A multinational organization operates its IT resources via AWS Organizations, with several OUs dedicated to specific business sectors and geographic areas. Currently, the organization maintains strict data security across its services, especially for sensitive data stored within a dozen Amazon S3 buckets, which are spread across various AWS accounts under different OUs.

    The DevOps team needs to update access controls for the dozen S3 buckets to allow connectivity only from a new IP address range  (172.16.100.0/24) and to revoke access for the Finance Division and Operations Division OUs.

    Which solution should the DevOps team implement to effectively meet the given requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon S3 Bucket Policies A bucket policy is a resource-based AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) policy that you can use to grant permissions to control access to your Amazon S3 bucket and the objects in it. Bucket policies use JSON-based access policy language.

    Amazon S3 supports IP address condition operators that you can use in bucket policies to control access based on the requester’s IP address.

    AWS Organizations is a service that allows you to centrally manage and govern your environment as you grow and scale your AWS resources. It enables you to create groups of accounts, automate account creation, apply policies to those groups, and simplify billing by using a single payment method for all of your accounts.

    AWS SCP (Service Control Policies) is a feature offered by AWS Organizations that enables you to manage policies centrally. These policies help you control the maximum permissible permissions for all accounts within your organization. SCPs allow you to impose restrictions on the AWS resources, services, and individual API actions that users and roles can access in each account.

    An organizational unit (OU) in AWS is a group of AWS accounts within an AWS organization. OUs provide a way to organize accounts hierarchically, enabling you to apply policies and controls to a subset of accounts in your organization.

    There are two steps the DevOps team can effectively restrict access to the S3 buckets to the specified IP range and revoke access for the ‘Finance Division’ and ‘Operations Division’ OUs: Configure bucket policies: Update the bucket policies for all the relevant S3 buckets to allow access only from the IP range 172.16.100.0/24 using the aws:SourceIp condition operator. Create and attach an SCP: Create a new SCP that denies access to the S3 buckets, and attach it to the ‘Finance Division’ and ‘Operations Division’ OUs. This SCP will override any other permissions granted to these OUs, effectively revoking their access to the S3 buckets. By implementing this solution, the DevOps team can meet the given requirements.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Configure bucket policies in all S3 buckets to restrict access to the IP range 172.16.100.0/24. Create a new Service Control Policy (SCP) that denies access to the S3 buckets, and attach it to the Finance Division and Operations Division OUs.

    The option that says: Create a new SCP that permits S3 bucket access exclusively from the IP range 172.16.100.0/24 and apply this SCP directly to the Finance Division and Operations Division OUs is incorrect. Service Control Policies (SCPs) are designed to restrict permissions rather than grant them. They act as a guardrail, not a gateway. Applying an SCP that specifies access from a certain IP range does not inherently enable that access; it only means that any access must conform to this restriction if it is already allowed by other policies. Additionally, it does not address the requirement to restrict access to the S3 buckets from other IP ranges.

    The option that says: Configure bucket policies in all S3 buckets to permit access only from the IP range 172.16.100.0/24. Set a permissions boundary for the OrganizationAccountAccessRole in the Finance Division and Operations Division OUs to restrict access to the S3 buckets is incorrect. Setting a permissions boundary on the OrganizationAccountAccessRole in specific OUs impacts only those IAM roles that are used within these OUs. A permissions boundary acts as a maximum permissions limit that an IAM role can exercise, but it does not directly control access at the OU level or manage access based on IP addresses. While configuring S3 bucket policies to limit access to a specific IP range is appropriate, using a permissions boundary does not guarantee that all possible role configurations within these OUs will prevent access to the S3 buckets. Additionally, it does not address the requirement to revoke access for the Finance Division and Operations Division OUs.

    The option that says: Create an SCP with two statements: one permitting access to the S3 buckets from the IP range 172.16.100.0/24 and another denying access from any other IP addresses. Attach this SCP to all OUs except Finance Division and Operations Division is incorrect. Similar to the previous option, applying an SCP that specifies access from a certain IP range does not inherently enable the required access. Additionally, it would still allow access to the S3 buckets for the ‘Finance Division’ and ‘Operations Division’ OUs, which is the opposite of the requirement to revoke their access. Lastly, attaching the SCP to all other OUs is not necessary.

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/organizations/latest/userguide/orgs_manage_policies_scps.html

    66. Question

    An organization operates a web application on multiple Amazon EC2 instances behind an Application Load Balancer. This application heavily relies on local disk storage for user files and media. The application must maintain uptime to ensure a positive customer experience and continuous business operations.

    During a recent patching cycle, some instances failed due to low disk space. The company uses AWS Systems Manager Automation for task execution across its EC2 fleet.

    A DevOps engineer must find a low-overhead solution to ensure that all EC2 instances have adequate disk space available for future patching cycles.

    Which combination of actions should be implemented to meet these requirements? (Select TWO.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon CloudWatch Agent is a software agent that you install on each EC2 instance that collects system-level metrics and resource utilization data and sends it to CloudWatch. This allows you to monitor resources on your instances and set alarms. Some examples of metrics collected include CPU utilization, disk reads/writes, network traffic, etc.

    An Amazon CloudWatch alarm watches a metric over a time period that you specify, and performs one or more actions based on the value of the metric relative to a given threshold over a number of time periods. This helps trigger notifications or other actions when a metric breaches a certain threshold.

    AWS Systems Manager Automation automates common administrative tasks like patching, software installation, etc., across your EC2 instances. You can create automation documents that define the steps, parameters, and approval requirements for a task. This ensures tasks are performed consistently at scale.

    The CloudWatch agent is a necessary tool for collecting and sending metrics from EC2 instances to CloudWatch. In a scenario where we need to monitor disk space metrics and receive notifications if disk space falls below a certain threshold, we can use a CloudWatch alarm.

    To set up this alarm, we can configure it in Amazon CloudWatch to track disk space availability across all EC2 instances. This will enable us to monitor disk space usage and receive an alert when a certain threshold is reached.

    As an additional precautionary measure, we can integrate this CloudWatch alarm with the Systems Manager Automation task. This task can take corrective actions on instances that breach the disk space limit, such as stopping or terminating them. This will help prevent future patching failures and ensure the smooth running of our system.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – Check that all Amazon EC2 instances have Amazon CloudWatch Agent installed and configured.

    – Set up an Amazon CloudWatch alarm to monitor disk space on all EC2 instances. Configure it to trigger an AWS Systems Manager Automation task to run a cleanup script when disk usage exceeds a specified threshold.

    The option that says: Deploy a cron job for all Amazon EC2 instances to clear temporary files periodically is incorrect. While deleting temporary files may temporarily alleviate disk space issues, it does not provide a systematic, monitored approach to ensure there is enough disk space during critical operations like patching.

    The option that says: Configure an AWS Lambda function to automate the archival of old user files to Amazon S3 is incorrect. This option helps manage disk space by moving older, less frequently accessed files to S3, but it does not directly address the immediate management of disk space required for patching cycles. It’s a good long-term strategy but does not provide the urgent response needed.

    The option that says: Configure AWS Config to monitor changes in the EC2 environment, focusing on storage allocation and utilization patterns is incorrect because AWS Config is more suited for compliance and governance monitoring rather than operational response to resource availability issues.

    67. Question

    A company has developed a serverless application that processes user requests using AWS Lambda. The Lambda functions are designed to connect to an Aurora PostgreSQL database cluster for data retrieval and storage. Initially, the functions connected directly to the Aurora cluster, but this approach led to connection timeouts due to the high volume of short-lived connections generated by the Lambda functions. The DevOps engineer must consider a scalable and higher-performance solution.
    What combination of steps should the engineer do in the following options to meet these requirements? (Select THREE.)

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.
    • 5.
    • 6.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon RDS Proxy is a service that allows applications to pool and share database connections, improving their ability to scale and making them more resilient to database failures. When an application connects to an RDS Proxy, the proxy maintains a pool of connections to the database and reuses these connections across requests.

    RDS Proxy handles unpredictable spikes in database traffic and queue connections when the maximum limit is reached. This maintains predictable performance for the database. The proxy also enforces AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) authentication for databases and securely stores credentials in AWS Secrets Manager.

    To use RDS Proxy with Lambda functions, you first need to create a proxy and grant necessary permissions to the Lambda execution role. Then modify the Lambda function code to connect to the proxy endpoint instead of the database endpoint. No other code changes are required. The proxy takes care of connection pooling and throttling traffic between the Lambda function and the database.

    This provides an efficient and scalable solution for Lambda functions that need to query databases on each invocation.

    Database connection pooling refers to the practice of establishing and managing a pool of database connections that can be reused across multiple clients and requests instead of opening a new connection for each request.

    Even if connections are long-lived, an application-side pool can optimize connection usage and ensure they are retrieved and returned quickly between queries for workloads with frequent open/close activity. Pools also make it easier to centrally configure connection properties for all database clients.

    Using an RDS proxy allows implementing connection pooling through the proxy. It maintains a pool of connections to the database that can be reused across Lambda invocations. The proxy can also enforce maximum connection limits and throttle requests to prevent overloading the database. This provides a more scalable and higher performance solution for the Lambda function querying the Aurora database.

    Hence, the correct answers are:

    – Implement Amazon RDS Proxy to manage database connections, connect them to the Aurora cluster’s reader and writer endpoint , and set a maximum connection threshold.

    – Integrate database connection pooling within the Lambda function’s code and set the number maximum connection of database connections pool.

    – Configure the Lambda function to connect to the RDS Proxy endpoint.

    The option that says: Optimize the SQL queries within the Lambda function is incorrect because optimizing SQL queries, while beneficial for reducing execution time, does not directly address the issue of connection management under high concurrency.

    The option that says: Utilize Amazon ElastiCache to cache query results and decrease the direct read operations from the Aurora database is incorrect because it addresses reducing read operations rather than connection management and performance under high concurrency.

    The option that says: Increase the memory and timeout settings of the Lambda function to handle higher throughput is incorrect because the problem is related to database connection management and not the compute resources of the Lambda function. While increasing memory and timeout might help the function process data more efficiently, it does not address the core issue of database connection management and may still result in high latency.

  68. Question 68 of 74
    68. Question

    A government agency is planning to launch a distributed system in AWS that processes thousands of transactions every day. The agency purchased a proprietary software with 100 licenses, which can be used by a maximum of 100 application servers. A DevOps Engineer needs to set up an automated solution that dynamically allocates the software licenses to the application servers. The Engineer also needs to provide a way to see the list of available licenses that are not in use.

    Which of the following options below is the MOST suitable way to accomplish this task?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    You can use AWS CloudFormation to automatically install, configure, and start applications on Amazon EC2 instances. Doing so enables you to easily duplicate deployments and update existing installations without connecting directly to the instance, which can save you a lot of time and effort.

    AWS CloudFormation includes a set of helper scripts (cfn-init, cfn-signal, cfn-get-metadata, and cfn-hup) that are based on cloud-init. You call these helper scripts from your AWS CloudFormation templates to install, configure, and update applications on Amazon EC2 instances that are in the same template.

    The EC2 instances in an Auto Scaling group have a path, or lifecycle, that differs from that of other EC2 instances. The lifecycle starts when the Auto Scaling group launches an instance and puts it into service. The lifecycle ends when you terminate the instance, or the Auto Scaling group takes the instance out of service and terminates it.

    Lifecycle hooks enable you to perform custom actions by pausing instances as an Auto Scaling group launches or terminates them. When an instance is paused, it remains in a wait state until either you complete the lifecycle action using the complete-lifecycle-action command or the CompleteLifecycleAction operation, or the timeout period ends (one hour by default).

    For example, your newly launched instance completes its startup sequence and a lifecycle hook pauses the instance. While the instance is in a wait state, you can install or configure software on it, making sure that your instance is fully ready before it starts receiving traffic. For another example of the use of lifecycle hooks, when a scale-in event occurs, the terminating instance is first deregistered from the load balancer (if the Auto Scaling group is being used with Elastic Load Balancing). Then, a lifecycle hook pauses the instance before it is terminated. While the instance is in the wait state, you can, for example, connect to the instance and download logs or other data before the instance is fully terminated.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Prepare a CloudFormation template that uses an Auto Scaling group to launch the EC2 instances with an associated lifecycle hook for Instance Terminate. Store the 100 license codes to a DynamoDB table. Pull an available license from the DynamoDB table using the User Data script of the instance upon launch. Use the lifecycle hook to update the license mapping after the instance is terminated. 

    The option that says: Prepare a CloudFormation template that uses an Auto Scaling group to launch the EC2 instances with an associated lifecycle hook for Instance Terminate. Store the 100 license codes to a public S3 bucket. Pull an available license from the bucket using the User Data script of the instance upon launch. Use the lifecycle hook to update the license mapping after the instance is terminated is incorrect because using a public S3 bucket to store the license codes is a security risk since it can be seen by anyone. You should use a DynamoDB table instead.

    The option that says: Prepare a CloudFormation template that uses an Auto Scaling group to launch the EC2 instances with an associated lifecycle hook for Instance Terminate. Store the 100 license codes to AWS Certificate Manager (ACM). Pull an available license from ACM using the User Data script of the instance upon launch. Use the lifecycle hook to update the license mapping after the instance is terminated is incorrect because you cannot upload license codes to ACM. Take note that the AWS Certificate Manager is simply a service that lets you easily provision, manage, and deploy public and private Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security (SSL/TLS) certificates for use with AWS services and your internal connected resources.

    The option that says: Prepare a CloudFormation template that uses an Auto Scaling group to launch the EC2 instances. Store the 100 license codes to AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store. Pull an available license from the Systems manager using the instance metadata script of the instance upon launch. Configure the metadata script to update the license mapping after the instance is terminated is incorrect because you should use a user data script instead of a metadata script to update the license mapping. In addition, you should set up a lifecycle hook for Instance Terminate in order to execute the mapping update before the instance is terminated.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/cfn-init.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/deploying.applications.html

  69. Question 69 of 74
    69. Question

    A company assigns its DevOps engineer to streamline the deployment process for a web application hosted on AWS. The DevOps engineer must formulate a deployment strategy that fulfills the following conditions:

    – New application releases should be packaged and deployed as Docker containers

    – If applicable, the use of managed AWS Services must be utilized

    – Common Git commands (e.g., git clone, git push, git pull) must be used for interacting with their code repository

    Which solution will meet these conditions?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS CodePipeline is a fully managed continuous delivery service that helps you automate your release pipelines for fast and reliable application and infrastructure updates. CodePipeline automates the build, test, and deploy phases of your release process every time there is a code change based on the release model you define.

    AWS CodeBuild runs your builds in preconfigured build environments that contain the operating system, programming language runtime, and build tools (e.g., Apache Maven, Gradle, npm) required to complete the task. You just specify your source code’s location and select settings for your build, such as the build environment to use and the build commands to run during a build.

    In this scenario, you should use AWS CodePipeline to trigger a deployment process when application files are pushed to a code repository. You can use GitHub as it supports standard GIT commands.

    When selecting a build stage for CodePipeline, you can either choose a Jenkins build server or AWS CodeDeploy. However, a Jenkins build server is more complex to set up and maintain than just using AWS CodeBuild. CodeBuild is serverless. It automatically provisions the infrastructure and build environment needed for testing and building your software packages. In this case, CodeBuild is responsible for building the Docker image from the Docker file committed in the code repo. Then, this Docker image will be deployed as a Docker container to Amazon ECS.

    When you create an Amazon ECS service that’s fronted by an Application Load Balancer, you have to designate a target group for your service. Ordinarily, you would create a target group for each of your Amazon ECS services. However, the approach we’re going to explore here involves creating two target groups: one for the blue version of your service and one for the green version of your service. We’re also using a different listener port for each target group so that you can test the green version of your service using the same path as the blue service.

    With this configuration, you can run both environments in parallel until you’re ready to cut over to the green version of your service. You can also do things such as restricting access to the green version to testers on your internal network, using security group rules and placement constraints. For example, you can target the green version of your service to only run on instances that are accessible from your corporate network.

    When you’re ready to replace the old blue service with the new green service, call the ModifyListener API operation to swap the listener’s rules for the target group rules. The change happens within a few seconds. Afterward, the green service is running in the target group with the port 80 listener and the blue service is running in the target group with the port 8080 listener. The diagram above is an illustration of the approach described.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Configure AWS CodePipeline to start a pipeline execution when a new version is pushed to a GitHub repository. CodePipeline will run CodeBuild to create a Docker image. Next, the Docker container will be deployed to a secondary Application Load Balancer target group consisting of ECS clusters. The primary target group is replaced by swapping its listener port with the secondary target group.

    The option that says: Configure AWS CodePipeline to start a pipeline execution when a new version is pushed to a private GitHub repository. CodePipeline will run a Jenkins CI server to create a Docker image. Next, the Docker container will be deployed to a secondary Application Load Balancer target group consisting of ECS clusters. The primary target group is replaced by swapping its listener port with the secondary target group is incorrect. AWS CodeBuild should be used as the CI service instead of Jenkins because a managed service is preferable. AWS CodeBuild is a fully managed continuous integration service that primarily compiles source code, runs tests, and produces software packages that are ready to deploy.

    The option that says: Configure a Jenkins pipeline to start a pipeline execution when a new version is pushed to a private DockerHub repository. CodePipeline will run CodeBuild to create a Docker image. Next, the Docker container will be deployed to a secondary Application Load Balancer target group consisting of ECS clusters. The primary target group is replaced by swapping its listener port with the secondary target group is incorrect because CodePipeline is a fully-managed service and easier to set up than Jenkins.

    The option that says: Configure AWS CodePipeline to start a pipeline execution when a new version is pushed to a Bitbucket repository. CodePipeline will run CodeBuild to create a Docker image. Next, the Docker container will be deployed to a secondary Application Load Balancer target group consisting of a Kubernetes cluster in an EC2 instance. The primary target group is replaced by swapping its listener port with the secondary target group is incorrect. Managing a Kubernetes cluster in an EC2 instance implies greater overhead than just using a managed service like Amazon ECS.

     

    References:

    https://aws.amazon.com/codepipeline/

    https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/compute/bluegreen-deployments-with-amazon-ecs/

    https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/devops/build-a-continuous-delivery-pipeline-for-your-container-images-with-amazon-ecr-as-source/

  70. Question 70 of 74
    70. Question

    An insurance firm has its on-premises data center integrated with its VPC in AWS Cloud via a Direct Connect connection. All of their financial records are stored on-premises and then uploaded to an Amazon S3 bucket for backup purposes. There is a new mandate by the IT Security team that only a trusted group of administrators can change the objects in the bucket including the object permissions. The team instructed a DevOps Engineer to develop a solution that provides near real-time, automated checks to monitor their data. How should the Engineer satisfy this requirement?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    When an event occurs in your account, CloudTrail evaluates whether the event matches the settings for your trails. Only events that match your trail settings are delivered to your Amazon S3 bucket and Amazon CloudWatch Logs log group.

    You can configure your trails to log the following:

    Data events: These events provide insight into the resource operations performed on or within a resource. These are also known as data plane operations.

    Management events: Management events provide insight into management operations that are performed on resources in your AWS account. These are also known as control plane operations. Management events can also include non-API events that occur in your account. For example, when a user logs in to your account, CloudTrail logs the ConsoleLogin event.

    You can configure multiple trails differently so that the trails process and log only the events that you specify. For example, one trail can log read-only data and management events so that all read-only events are delivered to one S3 bucket. Another trail can log only write-only data and management events, so that all write-only events are delivered to a separate S3 bucket.

    You can also configure your trails to have one trail log and deliver all management events to one S3 bucket and configure another trail to log and deliver all data events to another S3 bucket.

    Data events provide insight into the resource operations performed on or within a resource. These are also known as data plane operations. Data events are often high-volume activities.

    Example data events include:

    -Amazon S3 object-level API activity (for example, GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject API operations)

    -AWS Lambda function execution activity (the Invoke API)

    Data events are disabled by default when you create a trail. To record CloudTrail data events, you must explicitly add the supported resources or resource types for which you want to collect activity to a trail.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Set up an Amazon S3 data events in CloudTrail to track any object changes. Create a rule to run your Lambda function in response to an Amazon S3 data event that checks if the user who initiated the change is an administrator.

    The option that says: Create a new AWS Config rule with a Periodic trigger type that queries the Amazon S3 Server Access Logs for changes on a regular basis. Configure the rule to check if the user who initiated the change is an administrator is incorrect because the Amazon Server access logging only provides detailed records for the requests that are made to the S3 bucket only and not the IAM Policy changes. Moreover, the AWS Config rule will only run on a specific schedule which means that it won’t provide near real-time monitoring in comparison to Amazon S3 data events.

    The option that says: Use Amazon CloudWatch to monitor any changes to the Amazon S3 object-level and bucket-level permissions. Create a custom metric that checks if the user who initiated the change is an administrator is incorrect because CloudWatch is not a suitable service to use in monitoring your configuration changes. Moreover, you can’t directly create a custom metric that automatically checks if the user, who initiated the change, is indeed an administrator.

    The option that says: Create a new AWS Config rule with a Configuration changes trigger type that tracks any changes to the Amazon S3 bucket-level permissions. Modify the rule to use Step Functions check if the user who initiated the change is an administrator is incorrect because you can’t directly use Step Functions in conjunction with AWS Config. Although this type of trigger will cause the AWS Config to run evaluations when there is any change in Amazon S3, the use of Amazon S3 Data Event is still a more preferred way to track the changes in near real-time.

     

    References:

    https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/aws/cloudtrail-update-capture-and-process-amazon-s3-object-level-api-activity/

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/awscloudtrail/latest/userguide/logging-management-and-data-events-with-cloudtrail.html#example-logging-all-S3-objects

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/awscloudtrail/latest/userguide/logging-data-events-with-cloudtrail.html

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-cloudtrail/

  71. Question 71 of 74
    71. Question

    A development team is maintaining the resources of a web application stack in a CloudFormation template. They need to deploy some of the application’s resources to private subnets belonging to a separate network stack managed by the network team. Both teams are required to use resource-level change-set reviews before updating stacks. The development team does not have permission to create and modify network resources on their stack.

    How can the web application stack use the private subnets?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    When you organize your AWS resources based on lifecycle and ownership, you might want to build a stack that uses resources that are in another stack. You can hard-code values or use input parameters to pass resource names and IDs. However, these methods can make templates difficult to reuse or can increase the overhead to get a stack running. Instead, use cross-stack references to export resources from a stack so that other stacks can use them. Stacks can use the exported resources by calling them using the Fn::ImportValue function.

    For example, you might have a network stack that includes a VPC, a security group, and a subnet. You want all public web applications to use these resources. By exporting the resources, you allow all stacks with public web applications to use them.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Export the private subnets from the network CloudFormation template. Use the Fn::ImportValue function to reference the private subnets to the web application stack.

    The option that says: Export the private subnets from the network CloudFormation template. Use the Fn::GetAtt function to reference the private subnets to the web application stack is incorrect. The Fn::GetAtt only returns the value of an attribute from a resource in the template. This is not the correct intrinsic function to be used in this problem.

    The following options are both incorrect. This is not how you make a cross-stack reference. To make a cross-stack reference, you must specify a reference for the target resource in the Stack A using the Export field under the Output section. Then, use the Fn::ImportValue intrinsic function to import the values to Stack B that have been exported by Stack A.

    – Make a cross-stack reference for the private subnets in both stacks by using a nested stack.

    – Make a cross-stack reference for the private subnets in both stacks by using a stack set.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/walkthrough-crossstackref.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSCloudFormation/latest/UserGuide/best-practices.html#cross-stack

  72. Question 72 of 74
    72. Question

    A DevOps Engineer recently completed the CI/CD automation process in an organization. The Engineer used GitHub, AWS CodeBuild, AWS CodeDeploy, and AWS CodePipeline to build, test, and deploy applications automatically to several On-Demand instances on Amazon EC2. A new task was assigned to include a step that performs a security assessment scan of the operating system on every application deployment.

    How should the Engineer automate the security check?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Through integration with Amazon EventBridge, customers can now create events that automatically trigger Amazon Inspector assessments to run against your environments. Within Amazon EventBridge, you can create event rules targeting your Amazon Inspector assessment templates. When that EventBridge rule triggers, Amazon Inspector will automatically be notified to run the specified assessment.

    Amazon Inspector assessments can be triggered by any EventBridge rule. You can set up a recurring Schedule event with either a simple fixed recurring rate or a more detailed Cron expression, or create an event pattern which monitors other AWS services for actions to trigger an assessment.

    For example, you can create an event that monitors AWS Auto Scaling for new EC2 Instances being launched, or monitors AWS CodeDeploy notifications for when a code deployment has been successfully completed. Once the EventBridge rule has been configured against Amazon Inspector templates, these assessment events will be displayed in the Inspector console as part of your assessment templates so you can see all of the automated triggers for that assessment.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Monitor the CodeDeploy notifications when a code deployment has been successfully completed using EventBridge. Configure EventBridge to trigger an Inspector scan to your instances.

    The option that says: Monitor the Auto Scaling event notifications for launching new EC2 instances using Amazon EventBridge. Configure the EventBridge rule to trigger an Amazon Inspector scan for your instances is incorrect because you simply have to monitor the event notifications from CodeDeploy instead of your Auto Scaling group.

    The option that says: Monitor the Auto Scaling event notifications for launching new EC2 instances using EventBridge. Configure the EventBridge rule to trigger an AWS X-Ray scan to your instances is incorrect because you have to use Amazon Inspector instead of AWS X-Ray. Moreover, it is more suitable to monitor the event notifications from CodeDeploy. Keep in mind that the AWS X-Ray service is primarily used by developers to analyze and debug applications.

    The option that says: Monitor the CodeDeploy notifications for launching new EC2 instances using EventBridge. Configure the EventBridge rule to trigger an AWS X-Ray scan to your instances is incorrect because using Amazon Inspector to run assessment scans of your EC2 instances is typically a more appropriate solution instead of using AWS X-Ray.

     

    References:

    https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2017/07/amazon-inspector-adds-event-triggers-to-automatically-run-assessments/

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/inspector/latest/userguide/inspector_assessments.html

  73. Question 73 of 74
    73. Question

    An international investment firm hosts its application on several Amazon EC2 instances inside an Amazon VPC. A known security vulnerability was discovered in the outdated Operating System of the company’s Amazon EC2 fleet that needs to be patched as soon as possible. The issue was only resolved after a week.

    The DevOps engineer has been tasked with mitigating this vulnerability to safeguard the firm’s systems from various cybersecurity attacks that might lead to data leaks. There is also a requirement to record all of the changes to patches and association compliance statuses.

    Which of the following is the MOST operationally-efficient option that can meet the above requirements?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager automates the process of patching managed instances with security-related updates. For Linux-based instances, you can also install patches for non-security updates. You can patch fleets of Amazon EC2 instances or your on-premises servers and virtual machines (VMs) by operating system type. This includes supported versions of Windows, Ubuntu Server, Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL), SUSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES), Amazon Linux, and Amazon Linux 2. You can scan instances to see only a report of missing patches, or you can scan and automatically install all missing patches.

    Since you are also required to record all of the changes to patch and association compliance statuses, you can use AWS Config to meet this requirement. AWS Config is a service that enables you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. Config continuously monitors and records your AWS resource configurations and allows you to automate the evaluation of recorded configurations against desired configurations.

    Therefore, the correct answer is: Use AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager to deploy the OS security patches on the EC2 instances. Use AWS Config to manage, detect and record the security compliance of the EC2 instances.

    The option that says: Create a new AMI that automatically installs the OS security patches every week on the provided maintenance window using the EC2 Image Builder. Roll out the new AMI to the Amazon EC2 instances fleet is incorrect. This approach is possible but is not recommended because you won’t have control over each particular patch that needs to be installed. And it will be cumbersome to have a rollback operation in case a certain update broke the normal operations of your servers.

    The option that says: Set up Amazon Control Tower to deploy OS security updates to the Amazon EC2 instances. Create an Amazon Managed Grafana dashboard to visualize the security compliance of the EC2 instance fleet. Deploy the Customizations for AWS Control Tower (CfCT) template for a more granular patch control over your instances is incorrect. Amazon Control Tower is used to automate the setup of your multi-account AWS environment, not install security patches. In addition, the Customizations for AWS Control Tower (CfCT) feature is not primarily used to have a more granular patch control over your instances. This is usually implemented if you want to customize your AWS Control Tower landing zone and stay aligned with certain AWS best practices.

    The option that says: Use AWS Systems Manager State Manager to ensure that OS security patches are installed on the Amazon EC2 instances. Use Amazon OpenSearch service to record, monitor, and visualize the patch statuses of the entire EC2 instance fleet is incorrect. AWS Systems Manager State Manager is designed to be a  configuration management service that automates the process of keeping your managed nodes and other AWS resources in a state that you define. Although it may be possible to use it to install security patches, AWS SSM Patch Manager is the recommended service for installing OS updates to your EC2 instances.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/systems-manager/latest/userguide/systems-manager-patch.html

    https://aws.amazon.com/config/

     

    Check out this AWS Systems Manager and AWS Config Cheat Sheet:

    https://tutorialsdojo.com/aws-systems-manager/

  74. Question 74 of 74
    74. Question

    A company is running a web application on AWS using AWS Elastic Beanstalk. The environment consists of an Elastic Load Balancer (ELB) that distributes traffic across a fleet of Amazon EC2 instances. The EC2 instances are managed by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling groups to ensure the application scales to meet demand and maintain high availability.

    The operations team requires notifications for any scaling activities, such as instance launches or terminations, to respond promptly to changes in the application’s infrastructure. The team members should receive these notifications via email.

    Which solution will meet this requirement?

    • 1.
    • 2.
    • 3.
    • 4.

    Correct

    Incorrect

    Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS) is a fully managed messaging service designed to simplify creating, managing, and delivering notifications in the cloud. It enables applications, services, and AWS resources to send messages to various endpoints, including HTTP/S, email, SMS, and more. In AWS Auto Scaling, SNS is crucial in notifying stakeholders about events such as instance launches or terminations.

    For AWS Auto Scaling groups, configuring notifications through SNS involves creating a topic where notifications for specific events are published. Subscribers, such as email addresses in this case, can be added to the SNS topic to receive these notifications. This approach ensures that the operations team is not just reactive but proactive, receiving email notifications promptly whenever scaling activities occur, and facilitating proactive monitoring and response to application infrastructure changes.

    Using SNS for Auto Scaling notifications offers several advantages, including simplicity in setup, scalability to handle varying notification volumes, and flexibility in delivering notifications to multiple endpoints simultaneously. It abstracts the complexities of handling notifications and ensures reliable delivery, helping operations teams maintain visibility and responsiveness in managing the application’s scalability and availability.

    Hence, the correct answer is: Add a new Amazon SNS topic and create a subscription. Add to the subscriptions the email addresses of all operations team members. Configure the Auto Scaling groups to apply the autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_LAUNCH and autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_TERMINATE notification types and set the configuration to send notifications to the SNS topic for scaling events.

    The option that says: Configure AWS Lambda Functions to monitor Auto Scaling group activities and send emails to the operations team members when scaling events occur is incorrect. Although Lambda could process events, Auto Scaling is already capable of directly sending notifications to SNS, which can then forward the messages via email. Using Lambda for this task would introduce additional configuration steps and does not offer any unique benefits for this scenario.

    The option that says: Set up an Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) queue to capture scaling events. Configure an EC2 instance to poll the queue and send email notifications to the operations team is incorrect. This method introduces additional components that are unnecessary for this use case. It would simply increase costs and maintenance without any added benefit, as notifications can be directly sent to SNS for email delivery.

    The option that says: Set up an Amazon Simple Queue Service (SQS) queue. Configure an AWS Lambda function to trigger new messages in the SQS queue. Set the Auto Scaling groups to send autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_LAUNCH and autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_TERMINATE notifications to this SQS queue is incorrect. Configuring an SQS queue and using AWS Lambda to trigger new messages for sending email notifications adds unnecessary complexity and requires additional configuration. While Lambda can handle event-driven processes, setting up SQS and Lambda for this purpose just involves more steps and management than the direct integration capabilities of SNS. It introduces potential delays in notification delivery and increases the operational burden compared to the simplicity of using SNS for email notifications.

     

    References:

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/autoscaling/ec2/userguide/ec2-auto-scaling-sns-notifications.html

    https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sns/latest/dg/welcome.html
